#2020-06-0921:55aviüëã hi all, hopefully quick question, about HoneySQL support for create table statements. My impression is that it‚Äôs currently either impossible; difficult+tricky+unsupported; and/or undocumented. Can anyone confirm which of those is the case, if any? Thanks!#2020-06-0922:02seancorfield@aviflax create table syntax varies wildly from database to database -- HoneySQL's goal is to support SQL-92 / portable SQL so it doesn't attempt to do any DDL stuff.#2020-06-0922:04seancorfieldFWIW, clojure.java.jdbc has some very basic support for creating the DDL for that, but I omitted it from next.jdbc because it really wasn't any better than just bashing strings together...#2020-06-0922:04seancorfieldhttps://clojure.github.io/java.jdbc/#clojure.java.jdbc/create-table-ddl#2020-06-0922:07seancorfieldSo many column declarations require strings due to spaces or punctuation -- and all it does really is (clojure.string/join " " (map name col-spec)) on each column spec and then (clojure.string/join ", " cols) across the sequence of column descriptions...#2020-06-0923:07Chris O‚ÄôDonnell@aviflax if you're using postgres, https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres has them.#2020-06-0923:10aviThanks! I‚Äôm using SQLite tho.#2020-06-1000:35Chris O‚ÄôDonnellAh well. If you're set on using honeysql for ddl, you could probably adapt the definitions from postgres.#2020-06-1000:36aviI‚Äôll take a look. Thank you!#2020-06-1000:46seancorfield@aviflax Outside of the tests in clojure.java.jdbc, I've never used the DDL helpers -- they just don't add enough.#2020-06-1001:21Chris O‚ÄôDonnellI don't use them, either. I tend to put ddl in raw sql migration files.#2020-06-1001:26seancorfield@codonnell Yeah, that's the route we've gone at work, so it's easier to roll a database up for testing to a specific "version".#2020-06-1001:43aviThat makes sense. Thanks! FWIW, I was just hoping to find some kind of ‚Äústandardized‚Äù way to represent a create table statement as a data structure rather than as a string, because I am working on a function that will eventually return something that has generated create table statement in its metadata, and I want to be able to write equality checks in my tests without worrying about string formatting. I whipped this up on the fly, thinking this might work: 
[:create-table
 "technologies"
 "name varchar(255) not null primary key"
 "links-main text"]
But my SQL is so rusty I don‚Äôt have much confidence in something so simple being actually viable. üòÖ#2020-06-1001:45seancorfieldI would probably use a hash map: {:create-table :technologies :columns ["name varchar(255) not null primary key", "links_main text"]}#2020-06-1001:46seancorfieldthen you can (clojure.string/join ", " ...) on the columns and then it's just (str "CREATE TABLE" (:create-table data) "(" column-string ")")#2020-06-1001:47aviI like that. More forwards-compatible. Thanks!#2020-06-1014:14kwrooijenHello. I'm trying to create a new row, and return the generated primary key (or complete row). 
(-> (insert-into :person)
    (values [{:name "foo"}])
    (sql/format)
    (->> (jdbc/execute! *database*)))
This inserts the row as expected, but returns (1) instead of the new row. Is there any way I can get the primary key? I also saw that there was a jdbc/insert! , but this takes a map instead of an SQL string. Meaning I can't use honeysql with this. Any tips?#2020-06-1015:50gonyou can use 'returning id' clause at the end of the insert if your db implements it#2020-06-1016:27kwrooijenAh ok, I also need to use jdbc/query instead of jdbc/execute! if I want it to return data#2020-06-1017:18seancorfieldUse :return-keys true#2020-06-1017:18seancorfield(As an option passed to execute!#2020-06-1116:26kwrooijenThanks! I tried next-jdbc and that seems to work.#2020-06-1117:04seancorfieldAh, you were using clojure.java.jdbc? Yeah, that's a bit fussy about which functions you use since they nearly all invoke different JDBC methods under the hood. next.jdbc deliberately simplifies that, so everything goes through .execute() under the hood, which means execute! is much more broadly useful (and next.jdbc.sql/query is just an alias for next.jdbc/execute! really).#2020-06-1118:13kwrooijenYeah I'm exploring my options with SQL (and other Clojure libs). At work we use raw jdbc and HugSQL, but I'd like to use something other than that for my personal project. I'm really impressed with HoneySQL though üôÇ#2020-06-1118:14kwrooijennext.jdbc sounds like a good option to use from now on#2020-06-1118:50seancorfieldHugSQL has built-in support for next.jdbc via an adapter. next.jdbc's docs also have a Quick Start guide for using it with HugSQL.#2020-06-1314:52wombawombaHow can I build a INSERT INTO foo SELECT ... FROM ... statement with HoneySQL?#2020-06-1315:14dharrigan
(-> (insert-into [:foo (-> (select :*) (from :bar))]) sql/format)
["INSERT INTO foo SELECT * FROM bar"]
#2020-06-1315:16wombawomba@dharrigan thx!#2020-06-1319:42seancorfieldCross-posting from #sql for anyone who is here but not there...#2020-06-1320:03kwrooijenCool!#2020-06-1410:54borkdudeNow released as 0.1.2#2020-08-0819:53viestiHmm, is there a way to use CTE and UNION together, so that I could refer to the CTEs from the UNION clauses?#2020-08-0819:57viestisomething like this in sql: 
WITH cte AS (
  SELECT
    *
  FROM
    shared
)
SELECT
  cte.id,
  f.x
FROM
  cte
  LEFT JOIN foo f ON f.id = c.id
UNION
SELECT
  cte.id,
  b.x
FROM
  cte
  LEFT JOIN bar b ON b.id = c.id;
#2020-08-0820:07viestiah, hmm, just using a map {:with ... :union [...]} and referring to the cte's in the :union by name seems to work#2020-08-0820:07viestithe dsl tripped me off a bit#2021-01-2016:39dharriganCan honeysql do multiple or's if a vector is passed in, ["A" "B"] -> select foo from bar where baz = "A" or baz = "b"?#2021-01-2018:00seancorfieldWhy not [:in :baz ["A" "B"]]#2021-01-2019:00dharrigangood idea!#2021-01-2103:25NassinWhat would be the structure for from weather w, cities c ....?#2021-01-2103:34seancorfield@kaxaw75836 are you using the helper functions or just the raw data structure?#2021-01-2103:35Nassinraw#2021-01-2103:36seancorfieldIn general with HoneySQL, if :foo is a SQL entity then [:foo :bar] is a SQL entity with an alias.#2021-01-2103:39Nassin:from [:foo :bar :baz :bat] produces from foo, bar, baz, bat#2021-01-2103:40Nassinah#2021-01-2103:41NassinI see what you mean [[:foo :bar] [:baz :bat]] thx!#2021-01-2103:44Nassinmissed it cause I was ignoring the "vanilla helpers" in the docs#2021-01-2103:51seancorfieldI prefer the helpers. I wish more people used them.#2021-01-2103:51seancorfieldIt's really hard to get the raw data structures right. The helpers... well... help.#2021-01-2104:20Nassinnoted, you use it for all your queries or just dynamic ones?#2021-01-2104:26seancorfieldJust dynamic ones. We don't use HoneySQL for static queries. And we only use the helpers, not the raw data structure. And we're heavy users of HoneySQL -- one of my colleagues did a Clojure/West talk about it in 2015 (I think).#2021-01-2104:51markaddlemanfwiw, I code honey using the data structures directly. the only real problem is that, when i get something wrong, the resulting error message isn't terribly helpful but i can generally visually spot the problem in a minute or two of examining the data structure. i'm looking forward to honey 2.0 and spec. not only do i expect the error messages to get better, i think spec will make it easier to programmaticly manipulate queries.#2021-01-2614:47jimi hendrixIs there any support for postgres's CTE?#2021-01-2617:22markaddlemanfwiw, I have extended honeysql to support BigQuery CTEs (which are similar to Postgres CTEs). It was pretty easy#2021-01-2617:22markaddleman
(defmethod fmt/format-clause ::with [[_ ctes] _]
  (str "WITH " (fmt/comma-join (map (fn [[cte alias]]
                                      (try (str (fmt/to-sql alias) " AS " (fmt/to-sql cte))
                                           (catch Exception e
                                             (throw (ex-info "Unable to format"
                                                             {:alias alias :cte cte}
                                                             e)))))
                                    ctes))))
#2021-01-2618:17seancorfieldFYI with will be built-in with v2.#2021-01-2615:20orestisYes, via ‚Äúwith‚Äù#2021-01-2615:20orestisIirc the merge helper is missing #2021-01-2615:21orestisAFK right now so can‚Äôt help with sample code#2021-01-2617:35athomasoriginal@nasikebuli156 :with and :with-recurive are supported by HSQL. I also build the HSQL manually and without helpers‚Ä¶a habit I would like to break because I imagine that they are actually ‚Äúhelpful‚Äù#2021-01-2617:41Janne SauvalaHoneySql 2 looks promising. The v2 branch mostly works but there are some features from v1 not implemented yet -- still figuring out the best approach. Several features will behave differently but v2 uses different namespaces (and will have a different Maven coordinate: seancorfield/honeysql) so you can load both v1 and v2 into your project and migrate piecemeal.#2021-01-2710:41Janne SauvalaGood to know I can use them at the same time - I might go that route if I feel that v2 seems to be more superior üôÇ#2021-01-2718:02seancorfieldI'm hoping to have something "usable" next week. If I can get that working this weekend and get all the tests to pass, then I'll probably ask folks to test it -- if I can also get enough documentation in place.#2021-01-2618:14seancorfieldI don't consider it even "alpha" yet and I'm not yet trying to use it at work üôÇ#2021-01-2710:44Janne SauvalaI think Clojure has spoiled me with the definition of ‚Äúalpha‚Äù in our community. HoneySQL already allows you to compose partial queries -- and we rely on that at work (one of my former colleagues gave a talk about it at Clojure/West one year).#2021-01-2812:41Yang XuHI, I want to know whether exists a library of Java that similar to HoneySQL?#2021-01-2813:14dharriganPerhaps you may want to consider JOOQ#2021-01-2813:14dharriganI use JOOQ in Kotlin and Java, works really well. It's not quite like HoneySQL, but I would use JOOQ over JPA anyday.#2021-01-2813:40Yang XuThank you, let me look.#2021-02-0100:24seancorfieldMajor milestone: HoneySQL v2 repo now passes all the tests (for the first time!). The next two days will be about documentation!#2021-02-0100:24seancorfieldI plan to incorporate a bunch of new tests from a recent v1 PR into the v2 test base as well.#2021-02-0100:25seancorfieldI hope to cut a v2 alpha by the end of Tuesday.#2021-02-0100:33seancorfield(I also need to substantially clean up the code üôÇ but that will be an ongoing process now that I have a passing test suite)#2021-02-0116:43Chris O‚ÄôDonnellHey @seancorfield, just ran into surprising behavior with the way honeysql formats :values clauses. We were inserting a collection of maps that didn't all have the same keys and discovered after a period of confusion that honeysql picks the columns based off the first map in the :values vector. Would you be amenable to changing this so that honeysql picks the columns to be the union of all keys present in :values maps? Happy to provide a PR.#2021-02-0116:58seancorfield@codonnell I'll fix that for v2 but not for v1 at this point. It's the same behavior as clojure.pprint/print-table BTW.#2021-02-0116:59seancorfield(I don't think it's a bug but I agree it could be a bit surprising -- feel free to open an issue on GH so I don't forget)#2021-02-0117:03Chris O‚ÄôDonnellWill do, thanks.#2021-02-0117:06Chris O‚ÄôDonnellhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/291#2021-02-0117:44seancorfieldThanks! I'll probably work on that for v2 later today.#2021-02-0117:45dharriganJust a shout out for a big thanks for @seancorfield for doing the work for honeysql v2. Looking forward to it! üôÇ#2021-02-0118:46seancorfield@codonnell That is fixed on the v2 branch.#2021-02-0118:49Chris O‚ÄôDonnellThanks a bunch!#2021-02-0121:29seancorfield@codonnell BTW, the 1.x readme says "the first map defines the columns to insert, and the remaining maps must have the same set of keys and values" (but this restriction is gone in 2.x).#2021-02-0123:44Chris O‚ÄôDonnellSorry, I totally missed that! Maybe it's just me, but I don't often consult the Readme anymore except to glance at an example when I don't remember syntax. I'm sure I read the prose some time ago, but didn't remember that detail. Definitely appreciate that is documented.#2021-02-0122:57seancorfieldToday I have mostly worked on docstrings for the public API and updating the README to ensure it's all up-to-date and has examples of several new pieces of syntax, as well as ensuring all the tests pass on Clojure 1.9/1.10/1.11 (master) and ClojureScript and that the README example code also all passes (as tests). Code-wise, I'm pretty much at a 2.0.0 Alpha 1 state now for anyone who feels adventurous enough to try it out üôÇ#2021-02-0122:58seancorfieldseancorfield/honeysql {:git/url "" :sha "4cbeb170ddf4ba0d7238c43b092ffb0a33062474"} updated to latest SHA#2021-02-0122:58seancorfieldAnd follow the README here https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/tree/v2 (not the develop branch)#2021-02-0123:01seancorfieldI'm about to start fleshing out the "differences between v1 and v2" document and then I'll move on to full-blown documentation of v2 later today and most of tomorrow and at some point when I think there's at least enough documentation to support more widespread testing, I'll cut a 2.0.0-alpha1 release on Clojars for folks to use with Leiningen.#2021-02-0123:03seancorfieldThere's still a lot of work to do but at this point I believe v2 has reached general feature parity with v1 -- although I have deliberately not implemented several of the v1 formatting options (so I'm looking forward to some discussions about what folks rely on from v1 that I would prefer not to implement in v2 üôÇ ).#2021-02-0300:59seancorfield(writing documentation is taking me longer than I'd hoped so I'm not going to cut an alpha release to http://clojars.org just yet -- but folks are still welcome to try it out via {:git/url "" :sha "4cbeb170ddf4ba0d7238c43b092ffb0a33062474"} üôÇ )#2021-02-0301:00seancorfieldSpecial syntax docs https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/doc/special-syntax.md#2021-02-0319:49seancorfieldIf anyone does take v2 for a spin, please provide feedback -- good or bad.#2021-02-0319:59dharriganHi Sean. I plan to do a bit of playing around in the next few days with it. Slightly busy at work atm.#2021-02-0319:59dharriganHopefully I'll have positive feedback üôÇ#2021-02-0321:52markaddleman@seancorfield Where did you land regarding spec and v2? Personally, I'd love to have a honeysql spec. I do a lot of programmatic SQL generation and transformation. I believe that having a spec will help create a honeysql AST that will make transformations easier.#2021-02-0322:01seancorfield@markaddleman Still on the roadmap but it's much harder than I initially thought -- since it's basically the Spec equivalent of SQL's entire syntax üôÇ#2021-02-0322:01markaddlemanha. Yeah, that was the conclusion I came to. I was hoping you had some magic up your sleeve#2021-02-0322:02seancorfieldWriting a Spec that just says "this data structure is acceptable to HoneySQL" is fairly tractable but that's very lax -- HoneySQL can format all sorts of otherwise rather dubious "SQL" üôÇ No guarantee the SQL itself is valid, however...#2021-02-0322:06seancorfieldSince I want v2 to accept as much of the existing data structure DSLs out there which are used by v1, there are some inconsistencies I don't want to fix. At the same time, I've made v2 a bit more lenient in some cases where there's no ambiguity.#2021-02-0322:09seancorfieldFor example, (format {:select :id :from :table :where [:= :x 42]}) works in v2 because it makes sense -- folks expect that. But if you want aliases, you can't just do (format {:select [:id :a] :from [:table :t]:where [:= :x 42]}) because both :select and :from really expect sequences of identifiers and aliases need to be nested inside that sequence, as (format {:select [[:id :a]] :from [[:table :t]]:where [:= :x 42]})#2021-02-0322:10seancorfieldThere's no good way to consistently make the "mistake" genuinely illegal without also prohibiting strange-but-legal stuff...#2021-02-0322:11seancorfieldI certainly could make v2 stricter (and disallow '{select id from table where (= x 42)}) but it would also make it more complex and probably less easy to use üòê#2021-02-0322:12seancorfield(and v2 deliberately accepts symbols and lists where v1 only accepted keywords and vectors -- because folks want the quoted datalog-style query format)#2021-02-0322:16markaddlemanUnderstood. I encountered similar issues. I author queries by hand using using honeysql's syntax but the very first thing my transformation system does is "normalize" it (eg, all column projections have aliases, all tables have aliases, where clause expressions are converted to SqlCall records, etc).#2021-02-0322:17markaddlemanI despair of writing a spec for the unnormalized structure but the normalized data wouldn't be too bad#2021-02-0322:09seancorfieldFor example, (format {:select :id :from :table :where [:= :x 42]}) works in v2 because it makes sense -- folks expect that. But if you want aliases, you can't just do (format {:select [:id :a] :from [:table :t]:where [:= :x 42]}) because both :select and :from really expect sequences of identifiers and aliases need to be nested inside that sequence, as (format {:select [[:id :a]] :from [[:table :t]]:where [:= :x 42]})#2021-02-0421:51wombawombaI'm looking for, but can't find any examples of how to build CTE queries in HoneySQL. Any pointers?#2021-02-0422:45seancorfield@wombawomba Do you mean like this https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/test/honeysql/format_test.cljc#L62-L76 ?#2021-02-0422:49wombawombayup, thanks!#2021-02-0422:52seancorfieldOn the bright side, the v2 docs will list all the supported clauses https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/doc/clause-reference.md (when I get time to work on the docs some more).#2021-02-0722:00seancorfieldAs I've been continuing with https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/doc/clause-reference.md I've also been fixing a few bugs I've run across and also adjusting a few things to make usage easier (e.g., :with for CTE no longer requires the extra wrapping as a sequence since there can only ever be one WITH clause in an expression as far as I can tell from the SQL Server docs, although it still accepts the old 1.x format; :order-by now allows the direction to be omitted when you order by an expression although it still needs to be wrapped to disambiguate it).#2021-02-0817:09enn@seancorfield I think you‚Äôre right that you can only have one WITH clause, but it can define multiple tables ‚Ä¶ is that supported by the new syntax? e.g. the first example here: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/queries-with.html#2021-02-0818:02seancorfield@enn Ah, thanks for that link -- I had only been looking at SQL Server and the docs seemed to indicate only one CTE can be defined but that PostgreSQL example makes it clear you can define multiple ones. I'll create and issue to reverse that optimization and make sure that example can be done with HoneySQL 2.0!#2021-02-0818:04seancorfield(issue 298)#2021-02-0818:13ennthank you!#2021-02-1100:36seancorfieldProgress report! WITH is back to supporting multiple CTEs (and there's even a test for it); I have "finished" the clause reference mentioned above; I have incorporated all of the SQL portions from the nilenso/honeysql-postgres library (although some of the syntax has ended up a little different (HoneySQL v2's :insert-into supports an alias out of the box so insert-into-as is not needed, and do-update-set! is not needed because HoneySQL v2's :do-update-set clause supports both the simple excluded case and the full SET-like version). See https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/test/honey/sql/helpers_test.cljc#L281-L332 for the HoneySQL v2 tests of helpers like the nilenso functions.#2021-02-1100:37seancorfieldNext up: add the DDL from nilenso/honeysql-postgres (and document those clauses) and comb through the source and tests in that library to see if there's anything that isn't documented in the README.#2021-02-1100:39seancorfieldThen I'll continue on through the open issues for v2 and documentation and figure out at what point it will be worth cutting an alpha release to clojars. The latest SHA for anyone playing with the :git/url version is e157aec976769e4cfad0e63f0bad665ba5068e01.#2021-02-1121:02dharriganSo, just getting round to "port" my existing application to honeysql v2. Am I right in thinking that this style is no longer in use (or rather no longer encouraged)...#2021-02-1121:02dharrigan
(-> (select :device-id)
        (helpers/from :trip)
        (where [:= :vrn vrn]
               [:= :tenant-id tenant-id]
               [:>= :start-datetime (db/datetime->sql from)]
               [:<= :end-datetime (db/datetime->sql to)])
        (limit 1)
        sql/format)))
#2021-02-1121:03dharriganand should be replaced with {} maps?#2021-02-1121:12dharrigani.e.,#2021-02-1121:12dharrigan
(sql/format
  {:select [:device-id]
   :from [:trip]
   :where [:and [:= :vrn "asd"]
                [:= :tenant-id "tenant-id"]
                [:>= :start-datetime "from"]
                [:<= :end-datetime "to"]]
   :limit 1})
;; ["SELECT device_id FROM trip WHERE (vrn = ?) AND (tenant_id = ?) AND (start_datetime >= ?) AND (end_datetime <= ?) LIMIT ?"
;;  "asd"
;;  "tenant-id"
;;  "from"
;;  "to"
;;  1]
#2021-02-1121:40seancorfieldhoney.sql.helpers has all the helpers you are used to.#2021-02-1121:44seancorfield@dharrigan 
user=> (-> (select :device-id)
  #_=>         (helpers/from :trip)
  #_=>         (where [:= :vrn vrn]
  #_=>                [:= :tenant-id tenant-id]
  #_=>                [:>= :start-datetime (db/datetime->sql from)]
  #_=>                [:<= :end-datetime (db/datetime->sql to)])
  #_=>         (limit 1)
  #_=>         sql/format)
["SELECT device_id FROM trip WHERE (vrn = ?) AND (tenant_id = ?) AND (start_datetime >= ?) AND (end_datetime <= ?) LIMIT ?" "vrn" 42 #inst "2021-02-11T21:43:31.289-00:00" #inst "2021-02-11T21:43:31.289-00:00" 1]
üéâ#2021-02-1207:29dharriganüôÇ#2021-02-1216:51dharriganConverted my application to honeysql v2#2021-02-1216:52dharriganslowly working through it to find any breakage#2021-02-1216:53dharriganI notice now that function calls are uppercased, i.e., in honey v1, [:ST_SetSRID....] now becomes ST_SETSRID(... when formatted in honey v2#2021-02-1216:54dharrigan(just an observation, natch it's fine as sql is case insensitive unless quoted)#2021-02-1216:55dharriganModified about 15 files that used honeysql calls, so let's see what happens üôÇ#2021-02-1216:57dharriganI am liking the natural use of [:foo being a function call#2021-02-1216:58seancorfieldRe: uppercase -- yeah, v1 was a bit inconsistent about that, depending on how it treated the context so you'd get lowercase for some things that were clearly built-in and "should" be uppercase, you'd get mixed case in some situations, and then you'd get uppercase for other things üòê So I just took the position that your own "vars" (tables and column names) should be left as is (modulo the - -> _ thing) and pretty much everything else should be uppercase.#2021-02-1216:59dharriganconsistency is key! üôÇ#2021-02-1217:00seancorfieldHaving to wrap things in (sql/call ..) in v1 was probably the most common thing I got support questions and GitHub issues about: because [:foo 1 2 3] worked in "most" situations but there were lots of edge cases where it didn't quite work and you needed to "help" HoneySQL figure it out. And that's why I went with all the other "special syntax" as plain "function" calls too: raw, inline, param, etc.#2021-02-1217:01seancorfield(I'm going to make coffee and feed cats but will be back to answer any Qs in 10 mins)#2021-02-1217:20seancorfield(back)#2021-02-1217:46dharriganI think it's looking good, question.#2021-02-1217:46dharriganhow does the on-conflict, do-nothing work (previously I was using a defhelper to default a clause)#2021-02-1217:47dharriganFigured it out#2021-02-1217:47dharriganMan, working with the repl, rich comment blocks is fantastic, such quick feedabck#2021-02-1217:47dharrigan(on-conflict (do-nothing))#2021-02-1217:48dharrigan(insert-sql {:id 1}) ;; ["INSERT INTO investigation (id) VALUES (?) ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING" 1]#2021-02-1217:49dharrigan(as an aside, conjure on vim recently gained the ability to put the evaluation into a comment beside the form - that's what you're seeing there - makes capturing the result of a RCF fantastic and easy to look back upon)#2021-02-1217:56dharriganWell, so far so good, the happy path of my application works with honey v2#2021-02-1217:56dharriganwill check over the data in due course#2021-02-1218:29seancorfieldNice. Yeah, I haven't documented the helpers yet -- even tho' I prefer those over working with raw data -- but, as you're finding out, they're a lot more comprehensive than in v1 (there is literally a helper now for every single clause -- and a couple of helpers for special syntax forms as well).#2021-02-1219:14seancorfieldOnce I've finished implementing all the parts of nilenso/honeysql-postgres I'll add a specific section to the docs that talks about the differences between HoneySQL v2 and that lib -- there are a few things that just made sense to do a bit differently @dharrigan#2021-02-1219:34dharrigannp, looking forward to it. So far, the upgrade has been relatively straightforward. The main thing for me was replacing "sql/call" and "sql/raw" statements#2021-02-1219:35dharriganwill do some testing over the weekend, apart from some temporal differences, the data produced v1 vs v2 should be the same#2021-02-1219:52seancorfieldMuch appreciated! I will continue working on the docs over the weekend, after completing the PG DDL stuff.#2021-02-1220:47dharriganso far, data produced is identical, apart from a datetime stamp (of creation)#2021-02-1220:48dharriganencouraging! üôÇ#2021-02-1220:50dharriganthe two results are about +135,000 lines long, comprised of various sql reports, so only 2 lines differ, and that's the date of when the request to generate the reports was done üôÇ#2021-02-1220:58seancorfieldSounds like some serious testing -- thank you!#2021-02-1220:58dharriganmore testing adhoc over the weekend on the CD of CRUD actions üôÇ#2021-02-1220:58dharriganoh and U too üôÇ#2021-02-1220:59seancorfieldIt should now support stuff like delete from multiple tables, delete using, insert into as, and various other stuff that v1 omitted (or had only partially added).#2021-02-1221:00seancorfieldIt also has all the OVER / PARTITION BY / WINDOW stuff built in now.#2021-02-1221:00dharriganmy inserts do various joins over several tables#2021-02-1221:00dharriganand my reports do use OVER window functions too, so that appears to be tickity-boo for me atm#2021-02-1221:01dharriganI've replaced all the honeysql-postgres extensions from nilenso too#2021-02-1221:02dharriganright, ttfn! off to re-re-re-read LOTR!#2021-02-1300:24seancorfieldQ for folks using nilenso/honeysql-postgres: how many of you actually use alter-table (and the undocumented rename-table)? It looks like it doesn't currently let you have multiple altering clauses (e.g., alter table foo add column id int, drop column ident; type stuff). Would a syntax allowing multiple clauses be appreciated?#2021-02-1300:28seancorfieldI'm thinking of something like: 
{:alter-table :foo :add-column [:id :int]} ; single clause case
(-> (alter-table :foo) (add-column :id :int)) ; single clause helper version
;; proposed:
{:alter-table [:foo {:add-column [:id :int]} {:drop-column :ident}]} ; multi-clause case
(alter-table :foo (add-column :id :int) (:drop-column :ident)) ; multi-clause helper version
#2021-02-1321:29kwrooijenYes it would be nice to have!#2021-02-1321:30kwrooijenI actually had to write my own to get it to work in Gungnir üòÖ https://github.com/kwrooijen/gungnir/blob/ef0c9a25bb00792e27a6d07871bb82feb8aaf50d/src/clj/gungnir/extension/honeysql_postgres.clj#L46-L60#2021-02-1321:31kwrooijenIf Honeysql would get first class support for creating / altering tables etc. It would simplify it for my library and I'd get rid of an extra dependency üôÇ#2021-02-1321:32kwrooijen(I currently use this to implement my migration system)#2021-02-1322:10seancorfield@UG9U7TPDZ Thanks for the feedback -- I'm most of the way through integrating and testing the last few parts of the nilenso library this afternoon (`do update set` is giving me fits! üëÄ ) but by Monday this should all be sorted out and documented (integrating all these clauses in a consistent manner has led to some divergence -- so I plan to write a full "differences" page in the documentation).#2021-02-1305:38seancorfieldAnd another PG Q about that library: is anyone actually using create-extension and/or drop-extension? What on earth do those even mean?#2021-02-1306:26Chris O‚ÄôDonnellI don't use honeysql for ddl, but create and drop extension are for enabling and disabling postgres extensions (https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/external-extensions.html), which are basically plug-ins adding functionality to postgres. For example, PostGIS is a popular extension adding spatial and geographic data types.#2021-02-1320:50kwrooijenI use it to enable uuids#2021-02-1307:47dharriganMorning - whilst I don't use alter table/rename table clauses, perhaps in the name of completeness they should be included (if minimal work involved!)#2021-02-1307:47dharriganYeah, create and drop extensions are for installing extensions within schemas#2021-02-1307:47dharriganfor example "create extension postgis schema foo"#2021-02-1307:47dharriganwould install the postgis extension into schema foo#2021-02-1307:48dharriganthere are lots of extensions#2021-02-1307:53dharriganThe problem, perhaps, with alter table (including it's rename variant) is there are tonnes of options on how to alter/create the table. #2021-02-1307:54dharriganWould it be too much effort?#2021-02-1307:55dharriganThe way I use those clauses (create schema, alter table etc...) is only in my migration scripts (I use flywaydb). Since i would expect these to run on application start.#2021-02-1317:09seancorfield@dharrigan Thanks for that feedback. I ended up implementing add/drop/modify/rename column and add/drop index. I may implement more if folks request it. I'll go ahead and implement create/drop extension then since nilenso does have it.#2021-02-1317:09seancorfieldI also added rename table (that's in the nilenso library but not documented -- seems there are quite a few things implemented and not documented there, so at least they'll all get documented now in HoneySQL v2!)#2021-02-1317:13dharriganI've finished off testing my application, works perfectly with minimal changes to support honeysql v2#2021-02-1317:15seancorfieldBrilliant! Thank you!#2021-02-1317:16seancorfieldToday I'm going to post over the nilenso test suite and adjust it to work with v2 to check I have everything implemented.#2021-02-1317:19dharriganyou're most welcome üôÇ#2021-02-1406:18seancorfieldOK, seancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-alpha1"} is available for early testing... or [seancorfield/honeysql "2.0.0-alpha1"]... unfortunately http://cljdoc.org doesn't like this release so you can find the docs at https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/doc/getting-started.md (I'm working on fixing broken links etc so please let me know if you hit any problems).#2021-02-1409:17kwrooijenReading the docs now. I'm really happy with some of these changes (written in differences-fromt-1-x.md ) üòç#2021-02-1409:18kwrooijenThe removal of the reader literals is especially great#2021-02-1409:19kwrooijenThe new :cast keyword is actually going to fix a nasty bug for me#2021-02-1409:21kwrooijenIf you try to insert an empty array in Postgres without casting the type it'll actually fail. (Not sure why Postgres needs to know the type of the data if it's empty but ok). Now that I don't need to use sql/call this might actually be easier for me#2021-02-1409:32kwrooijenIt's going to be some work to upgrade to 2.0. Mainly because of this https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/276 @seancorfield any chance you thought about this? Of if you'd want to implement something like this at all?#2021-02-1418:06seancorfield@kevin.van.rooijen I'm open to suggestions while it's still in alpha.#2021-02-1418:08seancorfieldMy initial reading of Gungnir's purpose is that it feels like something that should applied to SQL execution rather than SQL generation.#2021-02-1512:10kwrooijenWhat do you mean by execution? Simple Gungnir usecase: Query: 
{:select :* :from :user :where [:= :user/email "
Transformation: 
string/lower-case :user/email
Result: 
{:select :* :from :user :where [:= :user/email "
#2021-02-1517:42seancorfield@kevin.van.rooijen I mean that the transformation "doesn't matter" until the value is about to be stored into the DB or has just been retrieved from the DB. You've attached Gungnir to SQL generation but a similar transformation could be done against next.jdbc around the setting of parameters and the reading of SQL values back from the DB.#2021-02-1517:57seancorfieldI'll take a deeper look at Gungnir over the next week or two and discuss my thoughts in more detail after that -- but my gut reaction is that attaching this to the set parameter / read result set functionality in next.jdbc would be "better" because then it would operate on things like update! and insert! from next.jdbc.sql.#2021-02-1519:14kwrooijenI mean that the transformation "doesn't matter" until the value is about to be stored into the DB or has just been retrieved from the DB. I don't think this is correct. Because I'm lower-casing the email in my query, not the resulting values. This is so that I don't have any case matching issues#2021-02-1519:17kwrooijenBut maybe this can be solved in next.jdbc as you said#2021-02-1519:34seancorfieldYou misunderstand: You need the parameter lowercased before you store it into the parameter, as part of the prepared statement setup, for your query. Which could happen in next.jdbc's set-parameter -- and which would then apply to all of the ways you could run queries, not just those that go through HoneySQL.#2021-02-1519:35seancorfieldAnd if this was wrapped around next.jdbc, Gungnir could also transform values coming back from the DB if needed -- although that is orthogonal.#2021-02-1519:39seancorfieldTo illustrate my point: if you do (jdbc/execute! ds (-> (select :*) (from :user) (where [:= :user/email " Gungnir would intercept that but if you did (sql/find-by-keys ds :user {:user/email " it wouldn't -- with Gungnir based on HoneySQL; but Gungnir could intercept the second version as well if it was based on next.jdbc. Does that make more sense?#2021-02-1520:37kwrooijenRight, so basically what I'm doing now could be handled with set-params. I'll take a look at that this week then, sounds like a much better solution#2021-02-1520:44seancorfieldFeel free to ping me if you have Qs -- the qualified name is not present by the time set-parameter is called but the metadata, available through the PreparedStatement, may provide enough information.#2021-02-1520:45seancorfieldAnd although clojure.java.jdbc has a different protocol, the machinery should be the same, so you could have one ns for next.jdbc and a separate ns for c.j.j if you wanted to support both libraries.#2021-02-1520:49kwrooijenI'm already using some features from next.jdbc so it's already required üôÇ#2021-02-1520:49kwrooijenThanks for the tip#2021-02-1520:54seancorfieldI just took another look at it and I don't think there's enough metadata to figure it out: the parameter metadata only has type information and no concept of naming; and the result set metadata is about what comes back not what goes in.#2021-02-1520:56seancorfieldWhich means the level you need access to is above the SQL statement / parameters, unfortunately. üòû#2021-02-1521:05kwrooijenHmm that's unfortunate#2021-02-1521:07kwrooijenIs it possible to patch this to add the extra metadata?#2021-02-1521:07kwrooijenWould be a good excuse for me to dive into next.jdbc#2021-02-1521:24seancorfieldYes, you could extend the protocol via metadata on a value-by-value basis -- the trick I've been using is to wrap the value in a function (`constantly`) so the protocol implementation can easily retrieve the original value.#2021-02-1521:25seancorfieldThat's how the next.jdbc.types type adapters work.#2021-02-1521:26seancorfieldI've just been looking at the Gungnir source code: it looks like it overrides a specific set of operators within HoneySQL to provide the before-read transform of the values associated with certain (qualified) keywords -- is that accurate?#2021-02-1521:28seancorfield(and it also wraps some of next.jdbc to achieve the same thing directly with insert! and update!?)#2021-02-1522:03kwrooijenRight, with Gungnir you can transform specific qualified-keywords defined in the model https://kwrooijen.github.io/gungnir/model.html It supports three things: :before-save - Done within gungnir, separate from HSQL / NJ :before-read - Patched version of HSQL (linked in the issue of HSQL) :after-read - custom result-set builder with NJ https://github.com/kwrooijen/gungnir/blob/master/src/clj/gungnir/database/builder.clj#2021-02-1522:04kwrooijenYou can read me model document for the use cases / how they are implemented by the end-user. It's all based on qualified keywords#2021-02-1522:06seancorfieldGiven HoneySQL v2's recursive descent formatting -- which is independent of the actual operators/function calls being used -- it's certainly a lot harder to implement a hook like that. I'll continue to give it some thought.#2021-02-1522:10kwrooijenAll right. I'm a bit in between projects right now so Gungnir doesn't have my highest priority at the moment. Worst case I'd have to walk the HSQL datastructure but hopefully we can prevent that#2021-02-1522:34seancorfieldWhat would you do with an expression like this in Gungnir? (where [:= :user/email [:|| "KEVIN" "@" ""]])#2021-02-1522:35seancorfield(it would produce ["... WHERE email = CONCAT(?, ?, ?)" "KEVIN" "@" ""])#2021-02-1607:11kwrooijenthe [;|| "KEVIN" "@" ""] part would be in the user defined part. So you'd for example have this (end-user defined) 
(defmethod gungnir.model/before-read :string/lower-case [_k v]
  (clojure.string/lower-case v))
And v woul be [;|| "KEVIN" "@" ""] . So the end-user can decide what to do with it#2021-02-1607:12kwrooijen(In this example it would fail because we're using string/lower-case on a vector, but the user could change that)#2021-02-1616:58seancorfield@kevin.van.rooijen Ah, good to know. OK, that gives me some ideas then...#2021-02-1616:58kwrooijenLet me know if you need any more info (sorry for the occasional late replies, timezones üòÑ )#2021-02-1617:00seancorfieldTo be expected when I'm on Pacific time and you're on Dutch(?) time üôÇ#2021-02-1617:04kwrooijenYep#2021-02-1418:42seancorfieldI have fixed the docs on http://cljdoc.org now: https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha1/doc/readme#2021-02-1421:47athomasoriginalJust upgraded my side project to V2 (10k loc all clojure)! Thank you!#2021-02-1421:49seancorfieldWhat database are you using @tkjone?#2021-02-1421:49athomasoriginalPostgres üòâ#2021-02-1421:49athomasoriginalBecause of the upgrade I was able to ‚Ä¢ simplify helper functions built around sql/call, ‚Ä¢ remove nilenso ‚Ä¢ gain clarity on my queries using postgres specific functions#2021-02-1421:49seancorfieldDo you use the nilenso lib?#2021-02-1421:51athomasoriginalhaha well, not anymore üôÇ#2021-02-1421:53athomasoriginalThe areas I can see future upgraders maybe having challenges is if, as you mentioned, there is use of nilenso but one forgot which keywords were nilenso specific. Not a big deal, I just totally forgot I was using exists [UPDATE]: The above issue is unrelated to the nilenso library. It was undocumented behaviour from HoneySQL V1. See the convo in the thread below#2021-02-1421:56athomasoriginalOnly other points of momentary confusion: ‚Ä¢ The switch from hsql/call to :function-name - but you have that well documented, I for some reason spaced when reading it ‚Ä¢ Switch from format/value to :lift - again, well documented, but I was looking for it in the V1 to V2 transition guide. Again, my assumption getting the best of me haha#2021-02-1421:56seancorfieldThe only references to exists I see in the nilenso lib are as part of the if-exists / if-not-exists around create/drop table/extension?#2021-02-1421:57athomasoriginalhmm. One sec. Let me look at the sql that was failing one more time.#2021-02-1422:07athomasoriginalThis is the line I was successfully using with nilenso 
(->> {:exists
        {:select [:datname]
         :from   [:pg_catalog.pg_database]
         :where  [:= :datname dbname]}}
       (hsql/format)))
and when I run the above with hsql 2 I get this exception: 
"Unknown SQL clauses: :exists"
#2021-02-1422:08athomasoriginalTo get it to work I updated it to 
{:select [[[:exists {:select ...}]]]}
#2021-02-1422:10seancorfieldHmm, interesting. I can't find any mention of that in nilenso's code.#2021-02-1422:11seancorfieldAh, it's an undocumented part of HoneySQL 1.x!#2021-02-1422:12athomasoriginalShoot! My bad!! but that makes sense! After a while, I would have to read H1 source more and more to figure out how to do something.#2021-02-1422:12seancorfieldBut I did migrate it -- it just needs to be added to the migration doc and probably elsewhere: 
;; EXISTS should never have been implemented as SQL syntax: it's an operator!
  #_(is (= (format {:exists {:select [:a] :from [:foo]}})
           ["EXISTS (SELECT a FROM foo)"]))
  ;; select function call with an alias:
  (is (= (format {:select [[[:exists {:select [:a] :from [:foo]}] :x]]})
         ["SELECT EXISTS (SELECT a FROM foo) AS x"]))
#2021-02-1422:13seancorfield(that's from the v2 tests)#2021-02-1422:14athomasoriginalNice, so it won‚Äôt be allowed to be used as SQL syntax, correct?#2021-02-1422:17seancorfieldIt never should have been allowed -- that was a bug in how it was added üòû#2021-02-1422:18seancorfieldIt was added way back in 0.5.3#2021-02-1422:19athomasoriginalüôà#2021-02-1422:19seancorfieldI added it to the differences doc: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/commit/2af7d0b6902b149c442f43d1ecf23473108fb585#2021-02-1422:20athomasoriginalVery nice!!!#2021-02-1421:58seancorfieldAh, I totally missed format/value -- I'll add that to the migration doc and the :lift special syntax. Thanks.#2021-02-1422:00seancorfield(docs updated)#2021-02-1611:42zackteoHello! I was looking for a query builder for PostGIS and was directed to HoneySQL. I understand that there is no PostGIS support but might something like this work through JDBC? 
(def postgis-map {:select [:city/name :state/name :city/geom]
                  :from   [:city]
                  :join   [:state (sql/raw ["ST_Intersects(" :city/geom ", " :state/geom ")"])]})

(sql/format postgis-map :namespace-as-table? true)
;; => ["SELECT city.name, state.name, city.geom FROM city INNER JOIN state ON ST_Intersects(city.geom, state.geom)"]
Am trying to see if I can compose PostGIS queries by simply using sql/raw and sql/forma which seems to work üôÇ Any advice on how I might want to improve my approach to this? And just wondering if there is anything I should be aware of when linking up to JDBC to PostgreSQL + PostGIS (extension)#2021-02-1611:42dharriganThat's the approach I take#2021-02-1611:42dharriganIt works fine#2021-02-1611:43dharriganWith honeysql v2, out in due course, it becomes a lot easier#2021-02-1611:44dharrigani.e.,#2021-02-1611:44dharrigan
(defn location->st-point
  [{:keys [lat lng] :as location}]
  [[:ST_SetSRID [:ST_MakePoint (round6 lng) (round6 lat)] [:cast 4326 :integer]]])
#2021-02-1611:44dharrigananything starting with a : is interpreted as a function call#2021-02-1611:45dharrigan(that is in honeysql v2 syntax)#2021-02-1613:14zackteoCool, excited to get this working! üôÇ#2021-02-1613:15zackteoOn a sidenote, is there a place I can look at the unstable(?) implementation of honeysql v2?#2021-02-1613:23dharriganyes#2021-02-1613:24dharriganseancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-alpha1"}#2021-02-1613:24dharriganand https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha1/doc/readme#2021-02-1616:59seancorfield@zackteo Even 1.x supports PostGIS expressions -- there's a section in the README about it: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/#postgis /cc @dharrigan#2021-02-1616:59seancorfield(and, yes, 2.x makes this even easier)#2021-02-1703:59seancorfieldseancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-alpha2"} is available for testing. It's mostly an overhaul and expansion of the documentation around v2 but also includes a number of small bug fixes and improvements, mostly around the insert/upsert syntax for PostgreSQL. Everything in nilenso/honeysql-postgres is built-in for this release and mostly documented (there are some small differences) -- see: https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/getting-started/postgresql-support and nearly all of the helper functions have docstrings now -- see: https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/api/honey.sql.helpers#2021-02-1704:03seancorfieldAt this point, the core API feels pretty stable to me and the overall shape and scope of the library also feels fairly well "baked" so I think it's mostly a matter of documentation to reach a "gold" 2.0 release, although I'm still ploughing though the open issues from the 2.0 milestone: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/milestone/7#2021-02-1706:23zackteoWhoops. I think I might have glanced past that - and I think I might have been trying out how other forms of PostGIS queries might work. Looks like I can use sql/call for the most part then üôÇ and tap into sql/raw and sql/format for finer manipulation#2021-02-1717:42seancorfield@zackteo Yup, in 2.0 it's easier because you never need sql/call and sql/raw has just become a :raw "function" (and :inline is more powerful now too).#2021-02-1721:42borkdudeIs there an option in honeysql to convert a sqlvec string (with question marks) and values into one string with the values embedded? This might be an anti-pattern but for shelling out I want to use this (just for a demo)#2021-02-1722:01borkdude
:parameterizer
does what I want, I think :)#2021-02-1722:08seancorfieldIn 1.x, yes, :parameterizer but in 2.x, you can just pass :inline true to sql/format and it attempts to inline all parameters.#2021-02-1722:10borkdudewow... I'll try!#2021-02-1722:16borkdude@seancorfield That worked. With babashka! I'm writing a small demo for a presention. 1) First I show how shitty it is to write manual sql using string functions and send that through java.shell to sqlite. 2) Then I show that you can use honeysql to take care of the sql. 
(defn insert-sql [animals]
  (sql/format (-> (h/insert-into :animals)
                  (h/columns :name :scientific_name)
                  (h/values (map (juxt :name :scientific-name)
                                 animals)))
              {:inline true}))

(defn insert-rows! [animals]
  (let [sql (insert-sql animals)
        {:keys [:exit :err]}
        (query (first sql))]
    (when (not (zero? exit))
      (println "Error inserting var!" err)
      (System/exit exit))))

(insert-rows! [{:name "Bison" :scientific-name "Bos gaurus"}
               {:name "Duck"  :scientific-name "Anas Platyrhynchos"}])
3) And then I show how to use the pod-babashka-sqlite3 pod so you don't need the :inline true option but can interact with sqlite as if it's a local library.#2021-02-1722:17seancorfieldLMK if you run into anything in 2.0.0 that causes problems or you'd like to see enhanced.#2021-02-1722:17borkdudewill do, so far so good#2021-02-1722:19borkdudeI was looking for something around create, I guess most people just do that as a raw string and not using data structures?#2021-02-1722:20borkdudeI don't really need it, I just wondered if there was something#2021-02-1722:24seancorfieldAs in create table?#2021-02-1722:25seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/getting-started#ddl-statements which leads you to https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/getting-started/postgresql-support (because the DDL stuff all used to be in the nilenso library, but now it is supported in core).#2021-02-1722:26seancorfieldDDL documentation is the first section here: https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference and the helpers are all listed here https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/api/honey.sql.helpers#2021-02-1722:26borkdudeooh, thanks#2021-02-1722:27seancorfieldYou can't -- currently -- add clauses to a create table statement after the column definitions, but that is coming maybe in the next alpha (since I need it for MySQL).#2021-02-1722:30borkdudeWorked. 
(defn create-db! []
  (when (not (.exists (io/file db)))
    (query (first
            (sql/format
             (-> (h/create-table :animals)
                 (h/with-columns [[:name :text]
                                  [:scientific-name :text]])))))))
#2021-02-1722:31borkdudeSo for values in v1 I needed to do: 
(h/values (map (juxt :name :scientific-name)
                                 animals))
Does v2 maybe accept maps?#2021-02-1722:32borkdudeeh, I guess it does, reading this in the README now#2021-02-1722:34borkdudeoh yes, it only works when you leave out the h/columns clause, is this expected?#2021-02-1722:34seancorfieldYes -- because the column names come from the (union of) the hash maps instea.#2021-02-1722:35borkdudeI guess h/columns could act as select-keys maybe?#2021-02-1722:35seancorfieldMaybe? Or maybe throw an exception if the h/columns are not in the hash map keys?#2021-02-1722:35seancorfieldI can see arguments for both.#2021-02-1722:36borkdudeyeah, maybe the user should just map a select-keys over the maps first#2021-02-1722:36borkdudeso the current behavior could stay as it is#2021-02-1722:36borkdudenot sure#2021-02-1722:38borkdudebut right now it yields invalid sql when you combine columns + maps#2021-02-1722:39borkdudemaybe throw in that case with a message like: you should explicitly format the maps yourself with the desired columns#2021-02-1722:43borkdudeAfk now. Thanks for the improvements so far!#2021-02-1910:08agile_geekMorning, I am looking for an example of how to add an as alias to a subquery?#2021-02-1910:20dharriganLike this?#2021-02-1910:20dharrigan
user=> (sql/format {:with [[:query {:select [:foo] :from [:bar]}]]})
["WITH query AS (SELECT foo FROM bar)"]
#2021-02-1910:20dharrigan#2021-02-1910:21dharriganIf not, maybe some of the tests might give a clue?#2021-02-1910:39borkdude#2021-02-1910:54agile_geekThx @dharrigan @borkdude. I think that {:with ‚Ä¶}example might work but thru trial and error I found this worked: 
{:select [:sub.id]
                 :from
                 [[{:select [:id :name1 :name2]]
                    :from [:table1]
                    :modifiers [:distinct-on :name1 :name2]
                    :order-by [:name1 :name2]} :sub]]}
Suitably anonymised table names and columns plus sub query is simplified.#2021-02-1911:02borkdudeSorry, the video wasn't related to your question, I just posted it here because it was about honeysql#2021-02-1911:03agile_geekInformation is good, more information is better!#2021-02-1911:04agile_geekI need to look at babashka as I think it may solve a bunch of issues with observability and debugging in my current client.#2021-02-1911:00dharriganfantastic! üôÇ#2021-02-1914:34aratareHi there. (-> (insert-into :properties)
    (values [{:name "John" :surname "Smith" :age 34}
             {:name "Andrew" :surname "Cooper" :age 12}
             {:name "Jane" :surname "Daniels" :age 56}])
