The trouble is that the suffix has a param named group , which needs to be quoted, otherwise PG is unhappy. Roughly it goes something like this: 
(let [suffix (first (hsql/format {:upsert {:on-conflict [:id] :do-update-set [:a :group :b]}}))
      insert-multi (sql.builder/for-insert-multi table cols rows {:suffix suffix :column-fn (fn [col] (format "\"%s\"" col))})]
  (jdbc/execute! ...))
#2021-02-2222:49devni may just rename the column, but im curious if anyone has any bright ideas#2021-02-2223:08seancorfieldHoneySQL can do quoting for different databases: it's an option to hsql/format#2021-02-2223:09seancorfieldIf you're still using HoneySQL 1.0 or earlier: (hsql/format .. :quoting :ansi) If you're already using HoneySQL 2.0: (hsql/format .. {:quoted true}) (the ANSI dialect is the default).#2021-02-2223:09seancorfield^ @devn does that solve your problem?#2021-02-2223:21devnunfortunately, no. I tried that.#2021-02-2223:21devnit‚Äôs alright, I went ahead and renamed the column#2021-02-2223:21seancorfieldWhich version of HoneySQL are you using?#2021-02-2223:22devnactually, you know what, let me try one more time because i see you have :quoting :ansi bare there (with no wrapping {})#2021-02-2223:23devnah yes, that‚Äôll do it ‚Äî however it still is a bit of a mess to also add in the column-fn transformation. if we run into another instance of this i‚Äôll consider switching it up#2021-02-2223:24seancorfieldI realized you must be using 1.0 and the honeysql-postgres extension lib -- :upsert üôÇ#2021-02-2223:25seancorfieldIn 2.0, you don't need the extension lib and it's just 
user=> (sql/format 
  #_=>  {:on-conflict [:id] :do-update-set [:a :group :b]} {:quoted true})
["ON CONFLICT (\"id\") DO UPDATE SET \"a\" = EXCLUDED.\"a\", \"group\" = EXCLUDED.\"group\", \"b\" = EXCLUDED.\"b\""]
user=>
#2021-02-2223:25devn
[honeysql "1.0.444"]
                 [nilenso/honeysql-postgres "0.2.6"]
#2021-02-2223:25devnah, nice!#2021-02-2223:25devnthen /that/ is what i‚Äôll do to finish out my day üôÇ#2021-02-2223:25devnthanks#2021-02-2223:25seancorfieldAlso, since you're on 1.0, make sure you update to 1.0.461 for the important bug fix.#2021-02-2223:26devnyep, saw that#2021-02-2223:27seancorfieldYou can use 1.0 and 2.0 side-by-side and migrate piecemeal: different maven coords and different namespaces üôÇ#2021-02-2223:28devn:male-cook: üíã ü§å#2021-02-2223:28seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/differences-from-1-x#2021-02-2418:58Jeff Evanshow can I create an insert-into query where one of the column names has a dot in it? running into this when upgrading from 0.9.4 to ~the latest~ 1.0.461. ex: 
(-> (apply h/columns [:name_first (keyword "name.last") :col2])
    (h/insert-into :properties)
    (h/values
      (lazy-seq [["Jon" "Smith" 34]
                 ["Andrew" "Cooper" 12]
                 ["Jane" "Daniels" 56]]))
    (honeysql.format/format))
=>
["INSERT INTO properties (name_first, name.last, col2) VALUES (?, ?, 34), (?, ?, 12), (?, ?, 56)"
 "Jon"
 "Smith"
 "Andrew"
 "Cooper"
 "Jane"
 "Daniels"]
#2021-02-2418:59Jeff EvansI want the SQL to be INSERT INTO properties (name_first, "name.last", col2) VALUES (?, ?, 34), (?, ?, 12), (?, ?, 56)#2021-02-2419:01Jeff Evanswell, really, all of the column names could be quoted, that would be nice#2021-02-2419:03seancorfield@jeffrey.wayne.evans Which "latest"? 1.0 or 2.0?#2021-02-2419:04Jeff Evanssorry. 1.0.461#2021-02-2419:18seancorfieldLooking over the 1.0 code, I don't think there's any way to prevent the dot-splitting -- it seems to be guarded by quoting being OFF so it looks like you definitely cannot have quoting ON and avoid the splitting.#2021-02-2419:22seancorfieldYou can't avoid it in 2.0 either since insert column names are a context where the namespace portion of a name is ignored -- and you can only avoid dot-splitting if you have a namespace-qualified name, e.g., properties/name.last in your case.#2021-02-2419:23seancorfieldIt's pretty deeply baked into HoneySQL, in both versions, that foo.bar means "table foo, column bar".#2021-02-2419:24Jeff Evanshmm, interesting. thanks for checking. I need to do a bit more homework to understand how it was doing what we wanted before#2021-02-2419:28seancorfieldThere were certainly some big changes in how names were handled in the 0.9.x series of releases -- some changes had to be reverted, some spawned extra options and/or dynamic vars.#2021-02-2419:29seancorfieldI don't think I've ever seen a DB schema where column names contain dots tho'...#2021-02-2421:01Jeff Evansoh, I‚Äôve seen every godawful thing like that. and I‚Äôm guessing some of my coworkers have too, since there is a test written for it#2021-02-2421:44Chris O‚ÄôDonnellCould you do (sql/raw "\"name.last\"") as a workaround?#2021-02-2421:48seancorfield@codonnell Not in the middle of a column name list, no. But you could, possibly, pass a string into columns maybe? (I haven't tried -- that just occurred to me)#2021-02-2421:51seancorfieldNope, that won't work.#2021-02-2421:52seancorfieldOh, yeah -- @codonnell wins the prize after all! 
user=> (-> (insert-into :properties) (columns :name_first (sql/raw "name.last") :col2) (values [["Jon" "Smith" 34] ["Andrew" "Cooper" 12] ["Jane" "Daniels" 56]]) (sql/format))
["INSERT INTO properties (name_first, name.last, col2) VALUES (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?)" "Jon" "Smith" 34 "Andrew" "Cooper" 12 "Jane" "Daniels" 56]
user=>
#2021-02-2421:52seancorfieldAlthough it will not quote it: 
user=> (-> (insert-into :properties) (columns :name_first (sql/raw "name.last") :col2) (values [["Jon" "Smith" 34] ["Andrew" "Cooper" 12] ["Jane" "Daniels" 56]]) (sql/format :quoting :ansi))
["INSERT INTO \"properties\" (\"name_first\", name.last, \"col2\") VALUES (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?)" "Jon" "Smith" 34 "Andrew" "Cooper" 12 "Jane" "Daniels" 56]
user=>
#2021-02-2421:53seancorfieldSo you'd need to do that manually: 
user=> (-> (insert-into :properties) (columns :name_first (sql/raw "\"name.last\"") :col2) (values [["Jon" "Smith" 34] ["Andrew" "Cooper" 12] ["Jane" "Daniels" 56]]) (sql/format))
["INSERT INTO properties (name_first, \"name.last\", col2) VALUES (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?)" "Jon" "Smith" 34 "Andrew" "Cooper" 12 "Jane" "Daniels" 56]
user=>
#2021-02-2421:53Jeff Evansaha, thanks to both of you! should work#2021-02-2421:54Chris O‚ÄôDonnellWhew! üòÖ#2021-02-2421:54Jeff Evansgranted, we are actually passing in things that reify ToSql already, so it will take me a bit of time to figure out how to adjust things. but that‚Äôs my problem#2021-02-2421:54seancorfieldAnd in v2: 
user=> (-> (insert-into :properties) (columns :name_first [:raw "\"name.last\""] :col2) (values [["Jon" "Smith" 34] ["Andrew" "Cooper" 12] ["Jane" "Daniels" 56]]) (sql/format))
["INSERT INTO properties (name_first, \"name.last\", col2) VALUES (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?)" "Jon" "Smith" 34 "Andrew" "Cooper" 12 "Jane" "Daniels" 56]
#2021-02-2421:58seancorfield@jeffrey.wayne.evans I'm curious what things you have reifying ToSql? That whole system goes away in v2 (and as you can see, sql/raw becomes just a regular "function call" expression -- a.k.a "special syntax" -- in v2).#2021-02-2422:03Jeff Evanswell, I‚Äôm still quite new to this codebase, so I definitely can‚Äôt answer any type of historical/‚Äúwhy‚Äù questions, but the relevant sections are https://github.com/metabase/metabase/blob/master/test/metabase/test/data/sql/ddl.clj#L85-L89 and https://github.com/metabase/metabase/blob/master/src/metabase/util/honeysql_extensions.clj#2021-02-2422:06Jeff Evanser, sorry, this particular one (the Identifier ) is a defrecord, not a reify#2021-02-2521:29Jeff Evanswell, this is curious‚Ä¶ 
(honeysql.helpers/columns (honeysql.core/raw "col1") (honeysql.core/raw "\"col.2\"") (honeysql.core/raw "col.3"))
=> #sql/raw"col1"
(honeysql.helpers/columns (keyword "col1") (honeysql.core/raw "\"col.2\"") (honeysql.core/raw "col.3"))
=> {:columns (:col1 #sql/raw"\"col.2\"" #sql/raw"col.3")}
#2021-02-2521:33seancorfieldYeah, I suspect there's an edge case with merging data on that first column. Put {} before the first column name.#2021-02-2521:34Jeff Evansaha, yep, that did it#2021-02-2521:34Jeff Evansbetter than what I was planning#2021-02-2521:34seancorfield
user=> (columns (sql/raw "col1") (sql/raw "col.two") (sql/raw "col:three"))
#sql/raw "col1"
user=> (columns {} (sql/raw "col1") (sql/raw "col.two") (sql/raw "col:three"))
{:columns (#sql/raw "col1" #sql/raw "col.two" #sql/raw "col:three")}
#2021-02-2521:34seancorfieldNormally you'd thread a hash map into the helper call.#2021-02-2521:35seancorfield
user=> (-> {} (columns (sql/raw "col1") (sql/raw "col.two") (sql/raw "col:three")))
{:columns (#sql/raw "col1" #sql/raw "col.two" #sql/raw "col:three")}
#2021-02-2521:35seancorfieldNearly all the helpers expect to be used in that context.#2021-02-2521:35Jeff Evansah, right. hence the insert-into example from the README#2021-02-2521:36seancorfieldHoneySQL v2 gets it right: 
user=> (columns [:raw "col1"] [:raw "col.two"] [:raw "col:three"])
{:columns [[:raw "col1"] [:raw "col.two"] [:raw "col:three"]]}
#2021-02-2522:26Jeff Evansthanks a lot, Sean! this is extremely helpful. I will definitely be looking for us to upgrade to v2 once it‚Äôs released üôÇ#2021-02-2522:28Jeff Evansin the meantime, I can finally explain the hiccup we ran into in the 0.9.4->1.0.461 upgrade in 0.9.4: 
(honeysql.helpers/columns {} (honeysql.core/raw "col1"))
=> {:columns (#sql/raw"col1")}
(honeysql.helpers/columns (honeysql.core/raw "col1"))
=> {:columns (#sql/raw"col1")}
in 1.0.461: 
(honeysql.helpers/columns (honeysql.core/raw "a.b"))
=> #sql/raw"a.b"
(honeysql.helpers/columns {} (honeysql.core/raw "a.b"))
Execution error (IllegalArgumentException) at honeysql.helpers/check-varargs (helpers.cljc:264).
columns takes varargs, not a single collection
#2021-02-2522:28Jeff Evansi.e. this patch: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/commit/4ca74f2b0d0f87827ce34d9baf8dcc8d086ce18e#2021-02-2522:28Jeff Evansso now that I clearly understand it, I can work around#2021-02-2523:38seancorfieldAh, back in 0.9.7... yeah, with hindsight there was a lot more churn in the 0.9.x releases than there should have been and definitely not enough test coverage üòû#2021-02-2523:40seancorfieldFYI, re: 2.0 -- the main thing blocking a "gold" release is actually documentation, to be honest. At this point the functionality isn't going to change (beyond supporting more ANSI SQL and probably more PostgreSQL syntax).#2021-02-2523:40seancorfield(but I understand some folks are reluctant to use an alpha in production)#2021-03-0210:33borkdudeAs a bit of user feedback: It's been several times now that I've been reading the README and I have trouble resolving mentally where some vars are coming from due to the use of :refer :all. E.g. right now I'm searching where insert-into is coming from (again). Can the README maybe use an alias, or an explicit :refer [...]? Or can all of these functions maybe be part of the honey.sql namespace?#2021-03-0217:32seancorfieldThe helpers have always traditionally been in a separate ns and that folks can either :refer specific ones or use an alias as they prefer. I think the DSL reads much more clearly with referred symbols than with using an alias. In v2 there are only two namespaces: honey.sql for working with the data structure and format'ing it, honey.sql.helpers with all the helper functions. In v2, honey.sql has one primary API: the format function, and you only care about the other public functions if you're extending HoneySQL.#2021-03-0217:40seancorfieldI get the impression that only a minority of HoneySQL users rely on the helpers at all -- most folks seem to prefer to work with the data structures and just sql/format. I'm still working on the docs (the major piece of work blocking a "gold" release) and I'll definitely make a couple more passes over the readme. The readme already has [honey.sql.helpers :refer :all :as h] (v1 had :as helpers instead of :as h and used that alias in precisely one place, to disambiguate update).#2021-03-0415:45iarenazaOne data point: we use the data structures, unless we need to resort to using sql/raw for certain Postgresql-specific constructs not supported in HoneySQL 1.x. Sometimes we need to dig into the code a bit to find the exact shape of the data structures because the README mainly uses helpers (e.g., to do a multi-JOIN) but the code is extremely clear and helpful (thanks a lot for that!)#2021-03-0415:46iarenazaLooking forward to migrating to v2, as some rough edges of 1.x have been polished quite a bit!#2021-03-0417:20seancorfieldThanks, I hope the new SQL Clause Reference docs in v2 solve the "exact shape of the data structures" issue?#2021-03-0217:43seancorfield(as for moving the helpers into honey.sql -- definitely not, at this point)#2021-03-0218:14borkdude@seancorfield I was using insert-into since I didn't know how to do this using data structures#2021-03-0218:14borkdudeThere were no examples I could find on this#2021-03-0218:16seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#insert-into#2021-03-0218:19borkdude@seancorfield I'm referring to the main README where I ctrl-f-ed on insert which only comes up with examples with insert-into (from the namespace I had to guess)#2021-03-0218:20borkdudeif :insert-into is preferred, maybe the main README should suggest this instead?#2021-03-0218:20borkdudeI had no idea it existed#2021-03-0218:21seancorfieldEverything has always been available as data structures. The helpers in v1 don't even cover all of the clauses. When I overhaul the README I will link more heavily to the reference doc sections.#2021-03-0218:22seancorfieldI will also make the whole data structure vs helper DSL thing clearer (the v2 readme is still modeled after the v1 readme, for the most part).#2021-03-0218:22borkdudeThanks!#2021-03-0218:25seancorfield(this is good feedback esp. since you're a new-to-HoneySQL user, right?)#2021-03-0218:26borkdudeyeah#2021-03-0218:27borkdudeI'm using it now from babashka mainly to poke at our work database, since this is faster than pgadmin which is annoyingly slow right now when connecting to a database in the US region (from Europe)#2021-03-0218:28seancorfieldFeel free to add any and all readme/doc thoughts to https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/307 so I don't lose track of any suggestions.#2021-03-0304:48Chris O‚ÄôDonnellI tend to use the query data structure directly, personally. When the readme just shows how a helper is used, I usually evaluate it at the repl to see the structure of the map it returns.#2021-03-0312:26borkdudeDoes / should honeysql support inlining arrays? 
(def sql (sql/format (-> (h/insert-into :users)
                         ;; (sql/columns :foo)
                         (h/values [{:foo (into-array [1 2 3])}]))
                     {:inline true}))
["INSERT INTO users (foo) VALUES ([Ljava.lang.Long;@34b3d918)"]
#2021-03-0317:22seancorfieldDoes it work in v1 and just not in v2?#2021-03-0321:17borkdude@seancorfield Just tried with v1, same thing#2021-03-0321:30seancorfieldThere are some situations where HoneySQL expands collections and others where it assumes the JDBC library will handle the value.#2021-03-0321:32seancorfieldOh, is this just about inlining? What should an array inline into? And is it portable across other databases?#2021-03-0321:32seancorfield(I'm pretty sure the answer to 3) is "no")#2021-03-0321:40borkdudeThere is an ANSI array standard now. I tried this: 
(def array-sql2
  (sql/format {:insert-into :foo
               :values [{:foo [:raw (format "array [%s]" (str/join "," [1 2 3]))]}]}))
and that worked, but I haven't tested with e.g. postgres#2021-03-0321:46borkdudecan I do something like this? 
:select [:raw "ARRAY['hello','bob','and','sally']"]
This comes back with: column :raw does not exist#2021-03-0321:50rwstauneri think there's a (sql/raw "...")#2021-03-0321:51borkdudeAnyway, this seemed to work: 
(pg/execute! db ["select ARRAY['hello','bob','and','sally'] from users limit 1"])
so I think the standard (ANSI) sql notation for arrays is ARRAY[1,2,3]. Maybe :inline could do that. More research needed probably.#2021-03-0322:07seancorfield{:select [[[:raw ...]]]} because SELECT takes a sequence of things, and those things can be aliases (which are wrapped in a sequence) and the thing you would alias is a function call [:raw ...]#2021-03-0322:08seancorfieldThat looks slightly less weird with the select helper but still a bit odd.#2021-03-0322:08seancorfieldand in v2 there's :array#2021-03-0322:08seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha2/doc/getting-started/sql-special-syntax-#array#2021-03-0322:17borkdudeconfirming that :select [[[:raw "ARRAY['hello','bob','and','sally']"]]] works. also :select [[[:array [1 2 3]]]] works and also [:array (into-array [1 2 3])] works. TIL!#2021-03-0322:19borkdudeI'm not sure how this would compose with :inline still, e.g. when you insert values. Can you do {:values [{:foo [:array [1 2 3]]}]}?#2021-03-0322:20borkdudeit worked!#2021-03-0322:20borkdude
(def sql (sql/format {:insert-into :foo
                      :values [{:foo [:array [1 2 3]]}]}
                     {:inline true}))
["INSERT INTO foo (foo) VALUES (ARRAY[1, 2, 3])"]
#2021-03-0322:20borkdudeThis lib is truly amazing ;)#2021-03-0322:25seancorfieldYeah, :inline knows how to inline basic stuff: strings, numbers, booleans, but not much else.#2021-03-0322:26seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/src/honey/sql.cljc#L149-L155#2021-03-0322:27seancorfieldSince [:array [1 2 3]] itself expands to ARRAY[?, ?, ?] and params, then :inline can handle it (by just inlining those numbers back into the SQL).#2021-03-0421:15Scott StarkeyHi all - I have set up a postgresql server with my web host provider (Bluehost) and I‚Äôm trying to figure out the steps to basic database access. Is there a ‚ÄúHello world!‚Äù guide to how to get set up with HoneySQL (or any other SQL)? I‚Äôve set up a database and a user, but I‚Äôm a little lost on how to connect to it.#2021-03-0421:23seancorfieldHoneySQL just turns Clojure data into SQL. It doesn't have anything to do with actually connecting to a database.#2021-03-0421:23seancorfieldYou need to use next.jdbc to actually run any SQL against a database.#2021-03-0421:24seancorfieldYou would generally define a hash map that describes your database setup: {:dbtype "postgres" :dbname "whatever" :user "dbauser" :password "secret" :host "ip-or-hostname"}#2021-03-0421:25seancorfieldThen you can run SQL against the DB via (next.jdbc/execute! db-spec (sql/format {:your :honeysql :data :here}))#2021-03-0421:26seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/next.jdbc/1.1.613/doc/getting-started @scotto#2021-03-0821:19Scott StarkeyHi Sean and others. I‚Äôm starting to take a hack at this, and I appreciate any help you could provide. I‚Äôve done the basics at the link above, and got the following error message: 
db-hello-world.core> (def ds (jdbc/get-datasource testmap))
;; => #'db-hello-world.core/ds
db-hello-world.core> (jdbc/execute! ds ["
create table address (
  id int auto_increment primary key,
  name varchar(32),
  email varchar(255)
)"])

Execution error (SQLException) at java.sql.DriverManager/getConnection (DriverManager.java:689).
No suitable driver found for ***My IP Address***:***My port number***/***My db  name***
I‚Äôm not sure whether this is an error with my host provider giving me the wrong IP/port info, or if this is a problem with something else. ‚ÄúNo suitable driver‚Äù makes it sound like I‚Äôm missing a driver! Can you help?#2021-03-0821:22seancorfieldWhat is your testmap?#2021-03-0821:23seancorfieldThat error generally means you have not specified a valid :dbtype#2021-03-0821:26seancorfield@scotto You're using PostgreSQL? Hosted somewhere non-local?#2021-03-0821:27Scott StarkeyYeah, I want to host it at my hosting provider (bluehost). Eventually I would like it to be a web app.#2021-03-0821:29seancorfieldSo I would expect something like this in your testmap: {:dbtype "postgres" :dbname "..." :user "..." :password "..." :host "..."} (assuming a default port for PostgreSQL which is 5432)#2021-03-0821:29Scott StarkeyMy testmap is 
{:dbtype "postgres",
 :dbname "", ; redacted
 :user "", ; redacted
 :password "", ; redacted 
 :host "162.241.216.221", ; The ip number that Bluehost told me.
 :port 3306} ; The port number that Bluehost told me.
#2021-03-0821:30seancorfield3306 is normally MySQL, not PostgreSQL.#2021-03-0821:30Scott StarkeyAhhh‚Ä¶#2021-03-0821:30Scott StarkeyThey might have given me wrong info.#2021-03-0821:30seancorfieldIn your project setup, do you have the appropriate database driver added as a dependency?#2021-03-0821:31seancorfieldPer the Getting Started docs: "In addition, you will need to add dependencies for the JDBC drivers you wish to use for whatever databases you are using."#2021-03-0821:31Scott Starkey
:dependencies [[org.clojure/clojure "1.10.3"]
                 [seancorfield/next.jdbc "1.1.613"]]
I think so‚Ä¶ ^#2021-03-0821:31seancorfieldNo, you have no JDBC drivers there.#2021-03-0821:32seancorfieldThe docs link to this part of the next.jdbc project https://github.com/seancorfield/next-jdbc/blob/develop/deps.edn#L10-L27 which shows a list of JDBC driver dependencies.#2021-03-0821:32Scott StarkeyOh‚Ä¶ sorry. Newbie‚Ä¶#2021-03-0821:33seancorfieldAs you said ‚ÄúNo suitable driver‚Äù makes it sound like I‚Äôm missing a driver! Can you help? -- so you were correct that you are missing a driver.#2021-03-0821:33Scott StarkeyWhen this is fixed, I will buy you the beverage of your choice. üôÇ :thumbsup:#2021-03-0821:33seancorfieldPostgreSQL: org.postgresql/postgresql {:mvn/version "42.2.10"}#2021-03-0821:33seancorfieldMySQL: mysql/mysql-connector-java {:mvn/version "8.0.19"}#2021-03-0821:34seancorfieldThose aren't quite the latest versions but they should be recent enough for you.#2021-03-0821:35seancorfieldIf Bluehost is really offering you MySQL instead of PostgreSQL, you want :dbtype "mysql" instead of :dbtype "postgres" (and you can omit :port 3306 since that is the default)#2021-03-0821:35Scott StarkeyI‚Äôm using Leiningen, so I assume I need: [org.postgresql/postgresql "42.2.18.jre7"]#2021-03-0821:36seancorfieldAre you using Java 7 or a more recent JVM?#2021-03-0821:36Scott Starkeyjava version "1.8.0_201"#2021-03-0821:37seancorfieldLooks like this is the most recent for Java 8 and above: https://search.maven.org/artifact/org.postgresql/postgresql/42.2.19/jar#2021-03-0821:37seancorfieldScroll down and you'll see the Leiningen dep on the right hand side: [org.postgresql/postgresql "42.2.19"]#2021-03-0821:37Scott StarkeyAgain. Thank you so much!#2021-03-0821:37seancorfieldThe .jre7 and .jre6 versions are for older JVMs.#2021-03-0821:40seancorfieldIf you actually are connecting to MySQL, this is the latest version I recommend: https://search.maven.org/artifact/mysql/mysql-connector-java/8.0.22/jar (there's an 8.0.23 but it has a number of changes that can be a bit problematic, depending on your setup so I'd say stick to 8.0.22 for now).#2021-03-0421:34Scott StarkeyThank you, kindly!#2021-03-0717:58seancorfieldI plan to cut 2.0.0 Alpha 3 "soon", now that I've incorporated @camsaul‚Äôs "smarter" where/having and merge variants into the 2.x branch (and got all of his additional tests working -- although I still need to update the where/having docs to reflect that). Are there particular things in this list of open issues https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues that folks would like to see in Alpha 3 (vs a later milestone)? My goal is to hit Beta 1 in late March/early April which would be the signal that the API will no longer change in any breaking ways (and all subsequent changes would be purely accretive/fixative). Beta 1 will also signal that the documentation is "complete" insofar as every feature is documented and all public functions have docstrings. I anticipate the documentation continuing to improve well beyond the point of "completion". Feel free to add comments to issues you care strongly about so I can get a sense of what my priorities should be for Alpha 3. Oh, and Alpha 3 will be published as com.github.seancorfield/honeysql but not as seancorfield/honeysql.#2021-03-0719:59dharriganThre's a lot of good things in that issues list#2021-03-0719:59dharriganhard to choose üòâ#2021-03-0720:09dharriganIf I was to order them from a functional POV (rather than documentation or project POV), I suppose: #292, #284, #301, #297, #277, #306, #280, #303, #278.#2021-03-0720:09dharrigan(slight postgresql bias there üòâ )#2021-03-0720:20seancorfield@dharrigan Can you add comments to those indicating your priorities, so I have them on record?#2021-03-0720:21dharrigancomments?#2021-03-0720:21seancorfieldOr at least do a "thumbs up" on them.#2021-03-0720:21dharriganah, on github#2021-03-0720:21seancorfieldThen I'll tackle issues that seem to have the most "votes" etc.#2021-03-0720:21dharrigankk nae problemo!#2021-03-0720:25dharriganand done#2021-03-1018:46bartukaHi, I need an extra help with insert-into. I have a data like: 
(def my-data [{:value1 "1", :mymap {:map2 "42"}}])
this can potentially be several maps and I want to insert-many. 
(jdbc/execute! datasource (-> {:insert-into :Table :values my-data} (sql/format)))
but I got an error 
Execution error (PSQLException) at org.postgresql.core.v3.QueryExecutorImpl/receiveErrorResponse (QueryExecutorImpl.java:2553).
ERROR: syntax error at or near ")"
The sql query generate will be 
(-> {:insert-into :Table
     :values [{:value1 "1" :mymap {:map2 "42"}}]}
     (sql/format))
;; => ["INSERT INTO Table (value1, mymap) VALUES (?, ())" "1"]
#2021-03-1018:47bartukaI feel I am missing something here. Not sure if I need to add something specific into sql/format#2021-03-1019:15seancorfield@iagwanderson Which version of HoneySQL are you using? And what does it mean to have a column whose value is a hash map?#2021-03-1019:16bartukaversion "1.0.461", the hashmap is coerced to jsonb fields#2021-03-1019:17seancorfieldWith 2.0, you can do this: 
user=> (-> {:insert-into :Table
  #_=>      :values [{:value1 "1" :mymap [:lift {:map2 "42"}]}]}
  #_=>      (sql/format))
["INSERT INTO Table (value1, mymap) VALUES (?, ?)" "1" {:map2 "42"}]
I'm not sure what the solution is in 1.0, probably wrapping it in (sql/param ..)?#2021-03-1019:19seancorfieldNope, not sql/param#2021-03-1019:19bartukaI tried, sql/param too.#2021-03-1019:20seancorfieldI'm not sure if it's possible with 1.0.#2021-03-1019:20seancorfield(well, I'm sure it is possible but I don't know how, off the top of my head)#2021-03-1019:22bartukaI will investigate this further later on and fix my situation now using next.jdbc directly. Would be good idea to create an issue as enhancement to support this? At least for tracking and generate docs if current facilities allow#2021-03-1019:23seancorfieldIt works in 2.0 as shown above. If it isn't possible in 1.0, it won't get fixed at this point.#2021-03-1019:25seancorfieldIf you figure out how to do it in 1.0, I'd accept a PR for the docs for 1.0, but I'd encourage you you start upgrading to 2.0 at this point: you can depend on both versions at the same time -- different group IDs and different namespaces -- so you could use 2.0 for just that one insert if you wanted, and stay with 1.0 for everything else.#2021-03-1019:27bartuka> If you figure out how to do it in 1.0, I'd accept a PR for the docs for 1.0, but I'd encourage you you start upgrading to 2.0 at this point: you can depend on both versions at the same time -- different group IDs and different namespaces -- so you could use 2.0 for just that one insert if you wanted, and stay with 1.0 for everything else. nice, it makes sense. thank you!#2021-03-1114:49murtazaüëã We‚Äôve released a new version of honeysql-postgres with support for more PG clauses, minor improvements, and a revamped readme. ‚Ä¢ https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres/releases/tag/0.3.104 ‚Ä¢ https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres/releases/tag/0.4.112 ‚Ä¢ https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md #2021-03-1115:06murtazaWe've also added a note about the progress being made in Honeysql 2.0 for people who may be looking for pg support#2021-03-1117:17seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/310 üôÇ#2021-03-1117:18borkdudehow do I write this? 
(sql/format {:update :foo :set {:dismiss "dissmis + 1"}})
#2021-03-1117:20borkdudeI tend to just go with hugsql for queries like this#2021-03-1117:20borkdudebut there might be a good way to do it in honeysql?#2021-03-1117:21seancorfield[:+ dissmis 1] is the expression#2021-03-1117:22seancorfield
user=> (sql/format {:update :foo :set {:dismiss [:+ :dissmis 1]}})
["UPDATE foo SET dismiss = dissmis + ?" 1]
#2021-03-1117:23seancorfield@borkdude There's an example of that in the README: 
(-> (h/update :films)
    (set {:kind "dramatic"
           :watched [:+ :watched 1]})
    (where [:= :kind "drama"])
    (sql/format {:pretty true}))
=> ["
UPDATE films
SET kind = ?, watched = watched + ?
WHERE kind = ?
"
"dramatic"
1
"drama"]
;; or as pure data DSL:
(-> {:update :films,
     :set {:kind "dramatic", :watched [:+ :watched 1]},
     :where [:= :kind "drama"]}
    (sql/format {:pretty true}))
=> ["
UPDATE films
SET kind = ?, watched = watched + ?
WHERE kind = ?
"
"dramatic"
1
"drama"]
#2021-03-1117:23seancorfieldSee https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/tree/v2#updates#2021-03-1117:23borkdudeI am using v1 still at work.#2021-03-1117:23seancorfieldThere's an example in the v1 readme too!#2021-03-1117:24borkdudemy bad then, but thanks for answering :)#2021-03-1117:24seancorfieldYou have to use (sql/call :+ :watched 1) in V1 https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql#updates#2021-03-1117:24borkdudeI see yeah, hm. I did scan the unit tests for this#2021-03-1117:25seancorfield(I know the V1 readme only uses helpers -- you can always run the helper version in the REPL without sql/format to see what the equivalent data structure would be)#2021-03-1117:26borkdudethanks a lot, this helps#2021-03-1117:26borkdudeI still think the helpers are somewhat magic, but I guess not#2021-03-1117:27seancorfieldThey're a lot less "magic" in V2 since they're nearly all implemented with the same generic function üôÇ#2021-03-1200:34maxp@iagwanderson You can use named parameter in insert-into and after that pass param-map to sql/format.#2021-03-1200:37maxpsomething like 
(-> 
  (insert-into :table) 
  (values [{:map_field :?my-map}])
  (sql/format {:my-map {:a :b}}))
#2021-03-1200:51seancorfieldThanks @maxp ‚Äî I tend to forget about named parameters because I never use them.#2021-03-1219:46seancorfieldJust committed extended support for create/`drop` for tables, views, materialized views. Also refresh support for the latter. Docs to come but hopefully the tests explain enough of it for now.#2021-03-1219:46seancorfield^ @dharrigan üôÇ#2021-03-1307:46dharriganthank you! looks great!#2021-03-1323:59seancorfieldcom.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-alpha3"} is available on Clojars for testing ‚Äî lots of new stuff in this Alpha release: * Change coordinates to com.github.seancorfield/honeysql (although new versions will continue to be deployed to seancorfield/honeysql for a while -- see the [Clojars Verified Group Names policy](https://github.com/clojars/clojars-web/wiki/Verified-Group-Names)). * Support much richer range of syntax on CREATE/`DROP` statements in general, including columns, TABLESPACE, CASCADE, WITH [NO] DATA, etc. * Fix #306 by supporting CREATE TABLE .. AS ... * Fix #305 by supporting more complex join clauses. * Fix #303 by supporting MySQL‚Äôs ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE. * Fix #301 by adding support for CREATE/`DROP`/`REFRESH` on MATERIALIZED VIEW. * Add tests to confirm #299 does not affect v2. * Fix #297 by adding both SELECT .. INTO .. and SELECT .. BULK COLLECT INTO ... * Fix #295 by adding docstrings to all helper functions (and adding an assert to ensure it stays that way as more are added in future). * Confirm the whole of the [nilenso/honeysql-postgres](https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres) is implemented out-of-the-box (#293, but see #310 for recent additions not yet incorporated). * Fix #292 by adding support for SELECT TOP and OFFSET/`FETCH`. * Fix #284 by adding support for LATERAL (as special syntax, with a helper). * Reconcile where behavior with recent 1.0 changes (porting #283 to v2). * Fix #280 by adding :escape as special syntax for regular expression patterns. * Fix #277 by adding :join-by/`join-by` so that you can have multiple JOIN‚Äôs in a specific order.#2021-03-1400:04seancorfield(ugh, I cut the tag on the wrong branch‚Ä¶ let me fix that ‚Äî the JAR on Clojars is correct!)#2021-03-1400:09seancorfieldFixed! Updated docs https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha3/doc/readme#2021-03-1519:17dcjI am attempting to migrate to honeysql 2 from 1. Many things are working, but I'm having trouble with one very complex CTE: The docs for with state: 
The argument to :with (or :with-recursive) is a sequences of pairs, each of a result set name (or description) and a basic SQL statement
I'm having trouble parsing this, and the examples given use a different style than I am used to.... Previously I did something like: 
(with [:A "some sql thing"]
      [:B "another sql thing"]
      ...)
Is that still valid?#2021-03-1519:39seancorfieldI don‚Äôt think that, as written, has ever been valid with strings.#2021-03-1519:40seancorfield(with [:A ["some sql thing" its params]] [:B ["another sql thing" more params]]) is more like it.#2021-03-1519:42seancorfieldCan you share exactly what you had with v1 that worked (that no longer works the same in v2)?#2021-03-1519:43seancorfieldThe syntax should not have changed between v1 and v2 as far as I‚Äôm aware @dcj#2021-03-1519:45seancorfieldThere are two CTEs in the V1 tests: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/test/honeysql/core_test.cljc#L16-L62 and here‚Äôs the same tests for v2 https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/test/honey/sql/helpers_test.cljc#L22-L62#2021-03-1519:46seancorfieldThe difference there is that modifiers no longer exists in v2 (`:select-distinct` replaces :select and :modifiers as separate things).#2021-03-1520:10dcjSorry, I over simplified my example with and confused things. I don't use strings, your re-write is basically indeed what I did both before and now#2021-03-1520:12seancorfieldSounds like you‚Äôll need to share more of what code you actually have then and compare the V1 and V2 data structures produced and what the formatter does with each. That‚Äôs why V2 has different namespaces so you can try them side-by-side.#2021-03-1520:30bartukahi!! is it possible to perform select from values in honeysql? => SELECT * FROM (VALUES (1, 'one'), (2, 'two'), (3, 'three')) AS t (num,letter); ? I am still getting the hang of it.#2021-03-1521:28seancorfieldIn V2: 
user=> (-> (select :*) (from [(values [[1, "one"] [2, "two"] [3, "three"]]) :t]) (sql/format))
["SELECT * FROM (VALUES (?, ?), (?, ?), (?, ?)) AS t" 1 "one" 2 "two" 3 "three"]
#2021-03-1521:29seancorfieldNot sure about the (num,letter) piece at the end‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt even understand that SQL syntax‚Ä¶#2021-03-1523:26dcjHere is the raw SQL string I am attempting to model in honey2: 
(SELECT fid, pca_raw, dca, X.path[1] AS id, X.geom AS g, ST_M(geom) AS m FROM flts_close CROSS JOIN ST_DumpPoints(t_trajectory) AS X)
So: 
(println (sql/format (-> (select :fid :pca_raw :dca [[:raw "X.path[1]"] :id] [:X.geom :g] [[:ST_M :geom] :m])
                                (from :flts_close)
                                (sql.helpers/cross-join [[:ST_DumpPoints :t_trajectory] :X]))))

[SELECT fid, pca_raw, dca, X.path[1] AS id, X.geom AS g, ST_M(geom) AS m FROM flts_close CROSS JOIN ST_DUMPPOINTS(t_trajectory) X]
Is the part after the CROSS JOIN the same as AS X above?#2021-03-1523:37dcjApparently yes!#2021-03-1523:41seancorfieldIn cross join x as y, the x as y part is just an aliased pair (like other joins). I‚Äôll have a think about that array indexing syntax but I don‚Äôt realistically think there‚Äôs anything I can do that would make it easier/neater in HoneySQL than wrapping [:raw ..] around the expressions.#2021-03-1601:21dcjHere is the latest v2 "puzzle": The SQL I'm trying to generate is: 
LEAD(g) OVER (PARTITION BY fid ORDER BY m)
I've tried this: 
(sql.helpers/over [[:lead :g]
                   (-> (sql.helpers/partition-by :fid) (order-by :m))])
which generates: 
[[:over [[:lead :g] {:partition-by [:fid], :order-by [:m]}]]]
which sql/format chokes on#2021-03-1601:42seancorfieldCan you provide a bit more context? This works: 
user=> (sql/format (-> (select (over [[:lead :g] (-> (h/partition-by :fid) (order-by :m))]))))
["SELECT LEAD(g) OVER (PARTITION BY fid ORDER BY m ASC)"]
#2021-03-1601:45seancorfieldHere‚Äôs a more complex example from the docs: 
user=> (sql/format (-> (select :id
  #_=>                                (over [[:avg :salary] (-> (h/partition-by :department) (order-by :designation)) :Average]
  #_=>                                      [[:max :salary] :w :MaxSalary]))
  #_=>                        (from :employee)
  #_=>                        (window :w (h/partition-by :department))))
["SELECT id, AVG(salary) OVER (PARTITION BY department ORDER BY designation ASC) AS Average, MAX(salary) OVER w AS MaxSalary FROM employee WINDOW w AS (PARTITION BY department)"]
#2021-03-1602:27dcjI definitely looked at the docs that I could find in https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/doc/clause-reference.md The broader context is that the snipped above is part of a with CTE, here is the raw version of it (that works): 
[:E [:raw "(SELECT DISTINCT ON (fid) fid, id AS a, id + 1 AS b, ST_3DDistance(ST_MakeLine(g, LEAD(g) OVER (PARTITION BY fid ORDER BY m)), pca_raw) AS dist FROM D ORDER BY fid, 4)"]]
#2021-03-1602:32dcjHere is what I tried: 
[:E (-> (sql.helpers/select-distinct-on :fid
                                        :fid
                                        [:id :a]
                                        [[:raw "id + 1"] :b]
                                        [[:ST_3DDistance [:ST_MakeLine :g
                                                                        (sql.helpers/over [[:lead :g]
                                                                                          (-> (sql.helpers/partition-by :fid)
                                                                                              (order-by :m))])] :pca_raw] :dist])
        (from :D)
        (order-by [:fid 4]))]
#2021-03-1603:22seancorfield[I was wrong: HoneySQL treats #2021-03-1603:29seancorfieldOh, I see the issue @dcj :select-distinct-on expects the first argument to be a sequence of column names per the docs: "Similar to :select-distinct above but the first element in the sequence should be a sequence of columns for the DISTINCT ON clause"#2021-03-1603:32seancorfieldAlso, the order-by should have a direction (`:asc` or :desc) instead of 4 -- can you explain what you're trying to do there?#2021-03-1603:34seancorfieldMaybe this is what you're aiming for: 
dev=> (sql/format (-> (h/select-distinct-on [:fid]
 #_=>  #_=>                                         :fid
 #_=>  #_=>                                         [:id :a]
 #_=>  #_=>                                         [[:+ :id 1] :b]
 #_=>  #_=>                                         [[:ST_3DDistance [:ST_MakeLine :g
 #_=>  #_=>                                                                         (h/over [[:lead :g]
 #_=>  #_=>                                                                                  (-> (h/partition-by :fid)
 #_=>  #_=>                                                                                      (h/order-by :m))])] :pca_raw] :dist])
 #_=>  #_=>                 (h/from :D) (h/order-by :fid [[:inline 4]])))
["SELECT DISTINCT ON(fid) fid, id AS a, id + ? AS b, ST_3DDISTANCE(ST_MAKELINE(g, (LEAD(g) OVER (PARTITION BY fid ORDER BY m ASC))), pca_raw) AS dist FROM D ORDER BY fid ASC, 4 ASC" 1]
Not sure whether the id + 1 is better for you as an expression rather than raw like that?#2021-03-1616:16dcj1. Thank you for the syntax fix! 2. Clearly I need to read the docs more carefully 3. Is there some way I can run my proposed query DSL through Spec, to veriify it is correct? 4. Thank you for [[:+ :id 1] :b] that is way better #2021-03-1616:23dcj
Also, the¬†order-by¬†should have a direction (:asc¬† or¬†:desc) instead of¬†4¬†-- can you explain what you're trying to do there?
The short answer is that I can't explain this, the query I am working on was created by an extremely experienced PostGIS developer, and I don't understand how it works üòû That being said, I checked the Postgres docs on order-by: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.5/queries-order.html Note this: 
A sort_expression can also be the column label or number of an output column, as in:

    SELECT a, max(b) FROM table1 GROUP BY a ORDER BY 1;
So, at this point, here is what I have: 
(pprint tqe)

{:select-distinct-on
 [[:fid]
  :fid
  [:id :a]
  [[:raw "id + 1"] :b]
  [[:ST_3DDistance
    [:ST_MakeLine
     :g
     [[:over [[:lead :g] {:partition-by [:fid], :order-by [:m]}]]]]
    :pca_raw]
   :dist]],
 :from [:D],
 :order-by [[[:raw "fid, 4"]]]}

(println (sql/format tqe {:pretty true}))

[
SELECT DISTINCT ON(fid) fid, id AS a, id + 1 AS b, ST_3DDISTANCE(ST_MAKELINE(g, (LEAD(g) OVER (PARTITION BY fid ORDER BY m ASC))), pca_raw) AS dist
FROM D
ORDER BY fid, 4 ASC
]
I haven't tested this yet, need to head to a meeting, back in a couple hours#2021-03-1617:03seancorfieldI showed an order-by that would work for :fid, 4: (h/order-by :fid [[:inline 4]]) ‚Äî you don‚Äôt need :raw here.#2021-03-1619:39dcjYes, this is working, thank you! Now, pne last giant blob of :raw to convert....#2021-03-1617:05seancorfieldRe: #3 ‚Äî there‚Äôs an issue on GitHub for a Spec for the DSL but I‚Äôm not sure how tractable that really is since it would need to pretty much match the entire recursive descent ‚Äúformatter‚Äù: SQL is extremely complex as a language and Spec isn‚Äôt really suited to describing language grammars.#2021-03-1619:41dcjCould each helper fn check its args? Not saying this would enable checking everything.... I will try and give this some thought#2021-03-1620:21seancorfieldNot really: the helpers are nearly all generic ‚Äî they mostly just assoc/merge arguments into the underlying data structure (they‚Äôre nearly all just calls to generic under the hood).#2021-03-1620:22seancorfieldAnd the problem is that the syntax of SQL is recursive: SELECT expressions can contain SELECT expressions in all sorts of complex ways.#2021-03-1620:23seancorfieldAny Spec that I end up writing is only going to catch the most egregious mistakes.#2021-03-1620:24seancorfieldThere are a few clauses where the structure required is unique enough that Spec could catch some errors (`:select-distinct-on` is a particular case where it expects a sequence where the first element must be a sequence ‚Äî but you already got an error from that‚Ä¶ just not a very informative one).#2021-03-1620:25seancorfieldI can try to add more ‚Äúspecific error checking‚Äù in cases where, if you pass in bad data today you get a generic error (either an NPE or a CCE), but many of those would be hard to predict‚Ä¶#2021-03-1620:27seancorfieldThere are also two distinct classes of ‚Äúuser error‚Äù here: one that blows up the formatter and one that formats successfully but produces bogus SQL. The former I can probably do something about, at least in terms of narrowing down where the error occurred, but the latter is pretty much impossible to detect.#2021-03-1620:27seancorfieldThere are also two distinct classes of ‚Äúuser error‚Äù here: one that blows up the formatter and one that formats successfully but produces bogus SQL. The former I can probably do something about, at least in terms of narrowing down where the error occurred, but the latter is pretty much impossible to detect.#2021-03-1620:35dcjUnderstood! I'm thinking more about the "user error" case....#2021-03-1620:53dcjToday's v2 puzzle, trying to convert this from :raw 
FROM
    (SELECT fid, pca, dca FROM P) P
    INNER JOIN
    (SELECT fid, m, ST_3DDistance(g,pca) AS dist FROM D WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, a FROM E)) A ON P.fid = A.fid
    INNER JOIN
    (SELECT fid, m, ST_3DDistance(g,pca) AS dist FROM D WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM E)) B ON P.fid = B.fid
My approach to these tasks is to try and build "up" from an innermost. So in this case, I started trying to write: 
(SELECT fid, m, ST_3DDistance(g,pca) AS dist FROM D WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM E)) B
The part I can't figure out is WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM E), specifically the IN part...#2021-03-1620:58seancorfield
user=> (sql/format {:where [:in [:composite :fid :id] {:select [:fid :b] :from :e}]})
["WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM e)"]
#2021-03-1620:59seancorfield(assuming you want the data structure version, not the helper version)#2021-03-1620:59seancorfield
user=> (sql/format (where [:in (composite :fid :id) (-> (select :fid :b) (from :e))]))
["WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM e)"]
#2021-03-1621:00dcjNice! Thank you again!#2021-03-1621:01seancorfieldIt‚Äôs probably worth pointing out that this is one of those places where the V2 support for symbols instead of keywords makes for a more readable piece of code 
user=> (sql/format '{where [in [composite fid id] {select [fid b] from e}]})
["WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM e)"]
#2021-03-1621:01seancorfield(that was not possible in V1 although symbols were accepted in a few places)#2021-03-1621:02seancorfieldObviously you can‚Äôt use a quoted structure if you have Clojure variables in the structure but‚Ä¶#2021-03-1621:03seancorfield(although you could use named parameters for that)#2021-03-1621:04ennperfect use case for quasi-quote#2021-03-1622:46dcjRecall my "today's V2 puzzle" above... Here is what I've got now: 
(-> (select :fid :pca :dca)
    (from :P)
    (inner-join [(-> (select :fid :m [[:ST_3DDistance :g :pca] :dist])
                     (from :D)
                     (where [:in (composite :fid :id) (-> (select :fid :a) (from :E))]))
                 :A]
                [:= :P.fid :A.fid])
    (inner-join [(-> (select :fid :m [[:ST_3DDistance :g :pca] :dist])
                     (from :D)
                     (where [:in (composite :fid :id) (-> (select :fid :b) (from :E))]))
                 :B]
                [:= :P.fid :B.fid]))
Which results in this: 
[
SELECT fid, pca, dca
FROM P
INNER JOIN (SELECT fid, m, ST_3DDISTANCE(g, pca) AS dist FROM D WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, a FROM E)) AS A ON P.fid = A.fid INNER JOIN (SELECT fid, m, ST_3DDISTANCE(g, pca) AS dist FROM D WHERE (fid, id) IN (SELECT fid, b FROM E)) AS B ON P.fid = B.fid
]
This seems really close, but I can't figure out how to get the first SELECT to end with AS P It is supposed to be: 
(SELECT fid, pca, dca FROM P) P
#2021-03-1623:03seancorfieldYou don‚Äôt need it to be aliased tho‚Äô since the table name is already P, right?#2021-03-1623:06seancorfieldI‚Äôm not even sure how to get an alias on that without nesting it in a SELECT ‚Ä¶ SELECT * FROM (SELECT fid, pca, dca FROM P) AS P which would be (-> (select :*) (from [(-> (select :fid :pca :dca) (from :p)) :p]) ...) I think @dcj?#2021-03-1623:07seancorfield
user=> (sql/format (-> (select :*) (from [(-> (select :fid :pca :dca) (from :p)) :p])))
["SELECT * FROM (SELECT fid, pca, dca FROM p) AS p"]
#2021-03-1623:09seancorfield(SELECT .. FROM ..) AS alias INNER JOIN .. is certainly not legal SQL as far as MySQL is concerned.#2021-03-1623:12dcjAFAICT, it is supposed to be: 
(SELECT some-stuff FROM OTHER_P) P
INNER JOIN ...
INNER JOIN ...
AFAIK this is legal Postgres, my raw query above works fine#2021-03-1623:15dcjHad to edit the above 3 times to get it right#2021-03-1623:19seancorfieldThere‚Äôs no way to generate that with HoneySQL ‚Äî the closest you‚Äôll get is the nested select I showed above.#2021-03-1623:19seancorfieldI can‚Äôt even think how to write that syntax in the DSL.#2021-03-1623:20seancorfieldSELECT some-stuff FROM OTHER_P AS P would be ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù though, wouldn‚Äôt it?#2021-03-1623:20seancorfield(and that is expressible in the DSL)#2021-03-1623:20dcjThat makes me feel better since I spent the last couple hours trying and failing#2021-03-1623:22dcjI also think your point that "you already have P, so why alias it again" bears some thought, seems like I ought to be able to make my query work without that#2021-03-1623:27seancorfieldI can‚Äôt see how it‚Äôs legal based on the Postgres docs either but, hey, maybe PG accepts syntax that isn‚Äôt documented?#2021-03-1623:28dcjDon;t know if it matters, but all this ends up in a from#2021-03-1623:31seancorfieldThe FROM can alias the result ‚Äî but it would be the entire result, not just that select/`from` part.#2021-03-1623:35seancorfieldOh, I see what you mean. So it is (-> .. (from [ (-> (select :fid :pca :dca) (from :other_p)) :p ]) (inner-join .. ) )#2021-03-1623:37seancorfieldbecause overall your query is select stuff from (select fid, pca, dca from p) as p ... right?#2021-03-1623:38dcjyes the original P was part of a with/CTE above#2021-03-1623:43dcjbut the inner joins apply to the select/from within the larger from#2021-03-1623:58seancorfieldI‚Äôd have to see the whole raw query to be able to help further at this point.#2021-03-1700:29dcjInteresting, I finally tried to run the entire query with that last bit, and now I get this: 
ERROR: subquery in FROM must have an alias

  Position: 1092
#2021-03-1700:36dcjSo I need to figure out how to generate that alias for the select....#2021-03-1700:40seancorfieldI told you how to do that just above.#2021-03-1700:40seancorfield^ @dcj did you not see my suggestion?#2021-03-1700:41dcjyes, wrapping the entire thing in an outer select :*#2021-03-1700:41dcj?#2021-03-1700:45seancorfieldNo, the alias in the from clause.#2021-03-1700:45dcjtrying that now,#2021-03-1700:45seancorfield(from [ (some subquery) :alias ]) => FROM (some subquery) AS alias#2021-03-1700:46seancorfieldSo it‚Äôs just a matter of how much of your query needs to go into that (some subquery) piece.#2021-03-1700:46dcjSeem to recall issue with subsequent inner joins not being inside the enveloping FROM#2021-03-2006:14Vincent Cantin@seancorfield I have a small suggestion about honeysql 2.0.0-alpha3, it is to rename the namespaces to remove the ending s . ‚Ä¢ honey.sql.helpers -> honey.sql.helper ‚Ä¢ honey.specs -> honey.spec#2021-03-2014:59Vincent Cantinit is a very subjective suggestion, ignore it at will üôÇ#2021-03-2100:45seancorfield@U8MJBRSR5 Clojure has core.specs (`.alpha`) and I think a lot of libraries have followed that plural lead -- I did with next.jdbc and it seemed natural to do so for HoneySQL as well. As for helpers -- people are used to that from V1 so it's been plural for years.#2021-03-2613:43maxpis there an example how to use on-conflict do-update-set in HoneySQL 2.0 ?#2021-03-2613:48dharriganhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/24b87ebd69e756d910d38bece954f3e1d2de864d/test/honey/sql/postgres_test.cljc#L34#2021-03-2615:57seancorfield@maxp https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-alpha3/doc/getting-started/postgresql-support covers the HoneySQL equivalents from honeysql-postgres. If you want to format the query as a string with no parameters (e.g. to use the SQL statement in a SQL console), pass :inline true as an option to sql/format:

;; conn
(connection/->pool HikariDataSource (select-keys env [:jdbcUrl]))

(s/defn read-user-tab :- [TabDB]
  [{:user/keys [id]} :- {:user/id s/Uuid}]
  (log/info "Reading tabs for user id" id)
  (nj/with-transaction [tx db]
    (nj/execute! tx (-> (helpers/select :*)
                        (helpers/from :tab)
                        (helpers/where [:= :tab/user-id id])
                        (sql/format {:dialect :ansi})))))

Sean wouldn't do anything without a reason üôÇ#2021-04-0113:53dharriganit's probably because as you're using ansi, it won't make any assumptions about the identifiers#2021-04-0113:53dharriganit'll treat them "literally"#2021-04-0113:53dharriganrather than trying to undasherize them#2021-04-0113:54aratareI mean I can rename the table, but it‚Äôs hard trying to find anything more suitable than user#2021-04-0113:56aratareI have another problem it seems. The returned map still keeps it as user_id‚Ä¶#2021-04-0113:58aratareWell that‚Äôs tomorrow‚Äôs problem. Time for me to do something else üòÖ#2021-04-0114:02dharriganUser is the only convention I break (keeping tables singular) and I call it users#2021-04-0114:02dharriganmakes life simple üôÇ#2021-04-0116:34seancorfield@rextruong To clarify some stuff about the camel snake kebab stuff: that only affects next.jdbc and it only affects 1) names in ResultSet‚Äôs that the library converts to Clojure and 2) names in Clojure data structures that the library converts to SQL ‚Äî it does not (cannot) affect anything in the SQL string itself.#2021-04-0116:36seancorfieldHoneySQL V2 defaults to :ansi dialect so you don‚Äôt need to provide it as an option (it‚Äôs relatively harmless to do so). If you specify a dialect, you get quoting. You can also ask for :quoted true to get quoted with the current/default dialect.#2021-04-0116:37seancorfieldIf you ask HoneySQL to quote names, it does so without dealing with -/`_` ‚Äî in both V1 (which is the code @dharrigan linked to) and V2 here: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/src/honey/sql.cljc#L150-L169#2021-04-0116:39seancorfield
user=> (-> {:select :* :from :tab :where [:= :tab/user-id 42]} (sql/format))
["SELECT * FROM tab WHERE tab.user_id = ?" 42]
user=> (-> {:select :* :from :tab :where [:= :tab/user-id 42]} (sql/format {:quoted true}))
["SELECT * FROM \"tab\" WHERE \"tab\".\"user-id\" = ?" 42]
#2021-04-0116:40seancorfieldSee some of the important differences around V1/V2 handling of names here https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/doc/differences-from-1-x.md#option-changes#2021-04-0201:33aratareThanks for the explanation and the fix @seancorfield.              :name     "foo",
             :password ".Xp8",
             :user-id  (java.util.UUID/fromString "740cb441-ce5e-4f8f-b328-009dc44ebda6")}]
    (nj/with-transaction [tx db]
                         (nj/execute-one! tx (-> (helpers/insert-into :tab)
                                                 (helpers/values [tab])
                                                 (helpers/returning :*)
                                                 (sql/format)))))

      :name "",
      :password ".Xp8",

      :updated #object[java.time.OffsetDateTime 0x46632f55 "2021-04-02T01:30:20.962643Z"],
      :user_id #uuid"740cb441-ce5e-4f8f-b328-009dc44ebda6"}
Am I doing something wrong here? Thanks in advance.#2021-04-0201:35seancorfieldWhat is the column actually called in the DB @rextruong?#2021-04-0201:36aratareuser_id, hence the reason why I was asking about how HoneySQL handles conversion between the two cases.#2021-04-0201:37aratareYou mentioned ‚Äúit only affects 1) names in¬†ResultSet‚Äôs that the library converts to Clojure‚Äù so that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm expecting user-id instead#2021-04-0201:37seancorfieldSince you are using the default result set builder, you get <table>/<column>.#2021-04-0201:37seancorfieldIf you have Camel Snake Kebab on your classpath, that enables a couple of new result set builders that you can choose to use.#2021-04-0201:38seancorfieldIt doesn‚Äôt change the default behavior.#2021-04-0201:38aratareAh that makes sense#2021-04-0201:39seancorfieldnext.jdbc‚Äôs default is to leave names alone going in both directions (with the caveat that you get qualified names out).#2021-04-0201:39aratareI see. So I‚Äôd need to change the builder when I‚Äôm setting next.jdbc up.#2021-04-0201:40aratareWill have a go at it now. Thanks a lot üôÇ#2021-04-0201:41seancorfieldYou can specify :table-fn and :column-fn to affect how the ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù SQL functions deal with (Clojure data structure) input and you can specify :builder-fn to affect how almost all functions deal with (`ResultSet` to Clojure data structure) output.#2021-04-0201:43seancorfieldIf you want a particular set of behaviors to be your ‚Äúdefault‚Äù (for most calls), take a look at next.jdbc/with-options but also be aware of the caveats around that near the end of https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/next.jdbc/1.1.646/doc/getting-started#options--result-set-builders#2021-04-0201:43seancorfieldHoneySQL operates completely ‚Äúindependently‚Äù of next.jdbc insofar as all it does is turn Clojure data into SQL (plus parameters) so any translation of names there only corresponds to next.jdbc‚Äôs ‚Äúinput‚Äù via the ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù SQL functions.#2021-04-0201:44seancorfield(I definitely need to clarify that in HoneySQL‚Äôs docs!)#2021-04-0201:45aratareSo I was reading that link and I noticed that the examples are mostly just jdbc/get-datasource. I assume with-options also works with connection/->pool?#2021-04-0201:46seancorfieldYes, because it ‚Äúis-a‚Äù DataSource.#2021-04-0201:46aratareLovely. Thanks.#2021-04-0201:47seancorfieldwith-options: ‚ÄúGiven a connectable/transactable object and a set of (default) options that should be used on all operations on that object, return a new wrapper object that can be used in its place.‚Äù ‚Äî a connectable is anything you can get a Connection from.#2021-04-0201:47seancorfield(you just have to be careful that if you get a Connection from it, that‚Äôs a bare Java object with no ‚Äúoptions‚Äù attached)#2021-04-0910:22JoeHello, first time HoneySQL user here. I'm doing an insert statement on a PostGres DB, and having trouble with the SQL HoneySQL is spitting out...#2021-04-0910:22JoeThis is the clojure code: 
(-> (insert-into :records)
    (values sample-records)
    (sql/format))
#2021-04-0910:24Joewhich produces this (slightly sanitized) 
["INSERT INTO records (date, balance, account_number, amount, memo, payee, category) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, food), (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, food)"

["INSERT INTO records (date, balance, account_number, amount, memo, payee, category) VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?), (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)"
 "01/02/2021"

 "Deliveroo"

 123.45

 "Tesco"
 "food"]
it seems to work OK.#2021-04-0910:27Joe> can you show what your sample-records looks like Sure, it's 
{:date "01/02/2021"
   :balance 123.45
   :account-number "acc"
   :amount 123.45
   :memo "memo"
   :payee "Deliveroo"
   :category :food}
Now I look at it, it seem like it must be something to do with the keyword. Maybe I need stringify that before I pass it in#2021-04-0910:28JoeSo the SQL comes out (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, 'food') or something#2021-04-0910:29JoeYup, that did it, thanks for the prompt!#2021-04-0910:31dharriganyou're welcome üôÇ#2021-04-0916:14seancorfield@U0105JJK1L3 Keywords (and symbols) are treated as column names, universally, in HoneySQL ‚Äî and you would need to convert :food to a string even if you weren‚Äôt using HoneySQL because you can‚Äôt write a Clojure keyword into a SQL database.#2021-04-0916:38JoeThat make sense, thanks Sean#2021-04-1007:01seancorfieldcom.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-beta1"} ‚Äî HoneySQL V2 moves out of Alpha! At this point I consider the documentation ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù (it will continue to grow but I believe it now covers all V2 functionality) and the APIs are all stable. Only accretive/fixative changes will be made from this point on. See https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/releases/tag/v2.0.0-beta1 for details of this release. I consider this stable for production usage (we‚Äôre already using Alpha 3 at work).#2021-04-1007:01dharriganw00t!#2021-04-1007:02dharriganWill you let it bed in for a couple of weeks before promoting to release?#2021-04-1007:18seancorfieldAt least a couple of weeks, yes.#2021-04-1007:18seancorfieldI‚Äôm hoping for wider usage/testing now it‚Äôs ‚Äústable‚Äù (out of alpha) and therefore more feedback on the docs and some of the specific functionality.#2021-04-1007:20seancorfield(I‚Äôve already found and pushed a bunch of small doc fixes since Beta 1 hit http://cljdoc.org!)#2021-04-1007:22dharriganI'm writing a new backend service, using v2, nothing fancy, nothing pushing the boundaries, but will keep an eye on it üôÇ#2021-04-1007:23seancorfieldOf the open issues, I definitely want to get #308 and #310 done for an RC, maybe #315 as well. I still need to figure out what to do about #146 (Spec) and I need to come up with a suitable extension hook for Gungnir #276.#2021-04-1007:24seancorfieldBut those are all accretive at this point. The rest will slip to 2.1 or later.#2021-04-1007:25dharriganAll excellent news. It's a great library#2021-04-1008:44Ben SlessHi, something I've been wondering about regarding honeysql for a while is if there's any way to render a string in advance and pass it parameters as symbols. From what I've seen there's no way to avoid calling format every time, but I could have missed it. What I had in mind can best be illustrated by this little macro I wrote: 
(defn parametrize-form
  [form params]
  (clojure.walk/postwalk
   (fn [e]
     (if (and (symbol? e)
              (contains? params e))
       `(sql/param ~(keyword e))
       e))
   form))

(defn format
  [args query]
  (let [form (parametrize-form query (set args))]
    (sql/format (eval form) (zipmap (map keyword args) args))))

(defmacro defsql
  [name args query]
  `(defn ~name [
I wouldn't feel half as bad about it if it didn't use eval thoughts?#2021-04-1016:10seancorfield@ben.sless yeah, this is something I've thought about often but haven't yet come up with a good way to handle in the context of HoneySQL. It's definitely still on my radar.#2021-04-1016:31seancorfieldI‚Äôll create a GH issue for tracking. It definitely feels like something worth doing. It‚Äôs not easy though: there are some constructs that don‚Äôt lend themselves to it in all cases ‚Äî the two that spring to mind immediately are [:in :col some-vals] where the generated string depends on the number of elements in some-vals and even something as simple as [:= :col foo] because the generated string is different for foo being nil, vs foo being non-`nil`: col IS NULL vs col = ?.#2021-04-1017:56Ben SlessFigured it wasn't going to be this easy üôÇ#2021-04-1018:07Ben Sless> produce strings with special placeholders so that only those pieces of the overall string needed to be generated for a final format Wonder if it's possible to return a closure and delay the building Emit something like: 
(fn [foo]
  (let [rendered-foo (if (nil? foo) " IS NULL" " = ?")]
    (let [sb (StringBuilder.)]
      (.append sb "SELECT * WHERE col")
      (.append sb rendered-foo))))
#2021-04-1018:22seancorfieldRight now, the entire formatting system expects to use str to bash pieces together under the hood. I suspect I‚Äôd need to change every piece of code that does that to allow for a sequence of strings-or-thunks and then have just the top-level format actually bash everything together ‚Äî but that would break the public API functions format-expr and format-dsl, as well as making it much harder for anyone to extend HoneySQL for their own syntax.#2021-04-1018:23seancorfieldOne ‚Äúeasy‚Äù workaround is to build the sql+params once with dummy values and just reuse that sql string with different sets of values ‚Äî but that doesn‚Äôt account for IN or the NULL stuff.#2021-04-1018:26seancorfieldAnother option is to produce a Selmer-style template that could just be formatted with the final set of parameters ‚Äî but that‚Äôs still going to potentially do a bunch of string-bashing each time anyway.#2021-04-1018:28seancorfieldAs an example of the complexity of logic needed to ‚Äúdo the right thing‚Äù, look at how much conditional logic is in format-in to take into account empty collections and nil values: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/src/honey/sql.cljc#L923-L951#2021-04-1018:54Ben SlessThat's pretty complicated#2021-04-1019:02seancorfieldSQL is complicated, man üôÇ#2021-04-1019:10Ben SlessI think it was Rich in one of his talks who commented on how silly SQL was, instead of being a protocol/specification first it was a natural language first and doomed us forever to string-manipulation-purgatory#2021-04-1019:14seancorfieldYeah, it‚Äôs been eye-opening trying to implement a much large subset of SQL for V2 than V1 supported ‚Äî and the vendor-specific extensions are often completely arbitrary as far as syntax goes (in my opinion).#2021-04-1019:15seancorfieldEvery year I continue to work with relational databases is a year that I get ever closer to wanting something more like Datalog instead üôÇ#2021-04-1019:15seancorfieldThat said, HoneySQL has definitely made our lives easier at World Singles Networks, where we programmatically compose some very gnarly reporting queries full of conditionals‚Ä¶#2021-04-1019:21Ben SlessWorking with data is certainly better than working with strings, don't get me wrong, but at the bottom of the stack stands some poor soul who has to write a compiler for that mess#2021-04-1019:22seancorfieldAs someone who started their career in IT writing compilers, yes, I feel that pain üôÇ#2021-04-1019:24Ben SlessAnd speaking of bashing strings, I don't know if you'll find this useful, but I wrote a templating engine which bashes strings relatively fast because I needed one. Was somewhat inspired by Metosin's approach https://github.com/bsless/contextual#2021-04-1019:29seancorfieldInteresting.#2021-04-1019:33Ben SlessReturning types which implement the desired behavior at run/compile/render time can speed you up significantly over runtime interpretation. Another thing I did because I was already used to that technique was unroll loops where possible, which is why I have ugly macros emitting defrecord s with 20 arities#2021-04-1016:44seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/320#2021-04-1017:55Ben SlessCan you please tag my GH user, @bsless ?#2021-04-1017:58seancorfieldTagged!#2021-04-1017:58Ben Slessthank you üôÇ#2021-04-1017:59seancorfieldI have a tentative solution for https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/315 but I‚Äôd like some input: if you effectively say {:where [:in :id []]} what would you expect to get? Also {:where [:in :id [nil]]}?#2021-04-1018:01seancorfieldSince id IN () is not legal SQL and no IDs are in an empty set, I would lean toward producing WHERE FALSE for that case and WHERE id IS NULL for the second case.#2021-04-1018:02seancorfieldAnd, just as a sanity check, do folks think adding an explicit OR id IS NULL is the correct way to handle this in the first place?#2021-04-1100:00seancorfield(if folks want to actually experiment with #315, it has been pushed to the v2 branch, post Beta 1)#2021-04-1123:02seancorfieldFor folks who do a lot of PostgreSQL work -- and especially folks who are using nilenso/honeysql-postgres with HoneySQL 1.x -- I just added the new features from 0.4.112 (of the nilenso library) to HoneySQL 2.x as special syntax, as well as support for ORDER BY in expressions which I saw in the PG docs while researching FILTER and WITHIN GROUP. It'll be in the next 2.0.0 Beta but you can try it out via :git/url "" :sha "d734767877b718244d366a7680069eb99ab723b3" if you want.#2021-04-1123:02seancorfieldI'd also be interested to hear about any PG features that you use but are not yet implemented by either the nilenso library or by HoneySQL.#2021-04-1219:13seancorfieldThere‚Äôs some additional discussion on https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/315 that I‚Äôd like more input on. I‚Äôm inclined to roll that change back out at this point‚Ä¶?#2021-04-1219:46sandqvistAssuming a function such as 
(defn find-foos [ids]
  (-> (select :*)
      (from :foo)
      (where [:in :id ids])))
I would expect to pass either a subselect or a seq of primary keys as ids. Values such as nil, [nil] and [1 2 nil] would all be programming errors in my code and I'm happy to catch them early. Especially the last one (when actually desired) I would always write explicitly as two clauses so that the next person to see the code can see how NULL is handled.#2021-04-1219:48seancorfieldThanks, @sandqvist ! Good feedback. ‚Äúavoid magic, make programmer errors visible‚Äù#2021-04-1219:51seancorfieldSo I guess then a question would be: should HoneySQL throw an exception if the IN collection is empty and/or contains nil? The former seems reasonable since WHERE col IN () is going to blow up in JDBC-land anyway, but the latter is probably a grey area since it ‚Äúworks‚Äù in JDBC-land, it just doesn‚Äôt necessarily do what the developer might want/expect‚Ä¶?#2021-04-1220:16sandqvistThis is a tricky one. For the [] and nil cases an exception would be useful if it makes complex statements easier to debug and fix than looking at the database logs and reading the SQL statement which is what I currently do as I'm still on v1. An exception without a good HoneySQL data structure context might be tricky to figure out. What I mean is unless the IN clause has a helper fn, you can only throw in format, right?#2021-04-1220:19seancorfieldCorrect. But the error message could include the SQL fragment that would fail, e.g., col IN () so you would at least see the col (or expression).#2021-04-1220:25sandqvistI compose HoneySQL queries quite a bit. What I'm afraid of is an error like [:in :id nil] is not allowed when I've composed three or four subqueries for tables that all have a surrogate primary key column called id. In that case, just looking at the database log is simpler.#2021-04-1220:27sandqvistBut just a debugging option to ignore the check and let the DB complain would also be fine.#2021-04-1220:28seancorfieldOr perhaps leave the default behavior ‚Äúas-is‚Äù and add a :checking true opt-in feature that performs this check (and potential other checks in the future)?#2021-04-1220:34sandqvistI would prefer that, with the possibility of later adding helper fns for IN and other clauses. The stacktrace from those would be very helpful. Of course, anyone can make those.#2021-04-1309:34orestisGlad to see that honeysql v2 supports DDL statements.#2021-04-1316:26seancorfieldThanks! @orestis It supports a pretty wide range of things now. I started with what the honeysql-postgres library supported, then added a bunch of additional syntax I found in the PostgreSQL docs (and SQL Server and MySQL docs too) while trying to figure out the correct syntax for the nilenso stuff (instead of trying to read their implementation), then added quite a bit of stuff suggested by folks here, including (and especially) @dharrigan#2021-04-1316:27dharriganYou're most welcome!
