So far the only way I found to make it work was to use either [:inline "enumValue"] or (types/as-other "enumValue"), in both cases the downside is that it involves modifying the query arguments, and keywords can't be used without an extra step to turn them into strings#2021-04-1419:43dcjCould you write your own helper to handle the keyword conversion for you? e.g. 
(defn clj-pg-enum
  [kw]
  [:inline (name kw)])
#2021-04-1508:40yendayes that is what I have 
(defn enum [k]
  (types/as-other (name k)))
I wouldn't recommend the inline solution it's not the same, with as-other it's a ? in your prepared statement, with inline it's part of it#2021-04-1412:56orestisI've added casts in the enum definition: 
DO $$ BEGIN
  CREATE TYPE idea_state AS ENUM ('draft', 'publish');
  CREATE CAST (varchar AS idea_state) WITH INOUT AS ASSIGNMENT;
EXCEPTION
  WHEN duplicate_object THEN null;
END $$;
#2021-04-1412:56orestisBut I was recently told that postgres enums are dangerous because you cannot add new values without dropping the enum, which is difficult to do when you already have data that point to the enum.#2021-04-1417:48yendahttps://blog.yo1.dog/updating-enum-values-in-postgresql-the-safe-and-easy-way/ what you were told is not correct, adding is easy, updating is only since 9.6 and removing involves renaming / creating a new one / migrating#2021-04-2305:16seancorfieldFYI, progress on v2: 
* 2.0.next in progress
  * Fix #323 by supporting more than one SQL entity in `:on-conflict`.
  * Fix #321 by adding `:checking` mode. Currently only detects potential problems with `IN` clauses.
What will determine whether I go to Beta 3 or RC 1 is whether the maintainer of Gungnir gets back to me "soon" and what we decide to do about that potential integration.#2021-04-2305:18dharrigan:thumbsup:#2021-04-2623:18piyerIs there a way to install honeysql v2 beta from clojars to test?#2021-04-2623:29piyernvm, found it.#2021-04-2722:50azHi all, is there a way convert raw sql to honeysql compliant data? I have a bunch of sql I would like to convert.#2021-04-2723:35Noah BogartDepending on how much effort you want to put in, you could convert the sql to AST nodes and then convert that to honeysql style nodes#2021-04-2723:37seancorfieldThe grammar for SQL is extremely complicated and is also different for each database so this is a very hard problem to solve.#2021-04-2723:38seancorfieldIf you have ‚Äúsimple‚Äù SQL, you might be able to do at least some of it via regex-style parsing but it‚Äôs still going to be a lot of work @limix#2021-04-2723:39azThank you, makes sense#2021-04-2723:39seancorfield(it‚Äôs been requested a couple of times against HoneySQL and I‚Äôve rejected it each time as being effectively intractable)#2021-04-2801:27Noah BogartDoes honeysql have anything like a spec or BNF? #2021-04-2801:56seancorfield@nbtheduke No. See https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/146#2021-04-2801:57seancorfieldOr if you want the TL;DR jump straight to the end https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/146#issuecomment-817217955#2021-04-2802:28Noah BogartThanks for that link! I‚Äôll take a look#2021-04-2808:08tianshuHi, does honeysql v2 has the support for array types?#2021-04-2816:10seancorfield@doglooksgood Do you mean for PostgreSQL? Read the PostgresSQL section of the Tips &amp; Tricks page in the docs ‚Äî it has example code and explains how to work with arrays.#2021-04-2901:39tianshu@seancorfield thanks! I didn't notice there's a docs folder in project.#2021-04-2902:02seancorfieldIt‚Äôs a lot easier to read here: https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-beta2/doc/readme#2021-04-2902:03seancorfield(which is linked from the README BTW)#2021-04-2902:04seancorfieldOh, I just realized I thought you were asking about arrays at the JDBC level which is not those docs.#2021-04-2902:05seancorfieldThis is probably what you want: https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/next.jdbc/1.1.646/doc/getting-started/tips-tricks#2021-04-2902:05seancorfieldHoneySQL doesn‚Äôt interact with JDBC at all, so ‚Äúarrays‚Äù are irrelevant for HoneySQL. When you interact with the database, the handling of arrays will matter and that‚Äôs something you control via next.jdbc stuff.#2021-04-2902:06seancorfield@doglooksgood Perhaps you can elaborate on what you mean by ‚Äúsupport for array types‚Äù?#2021-05-0117:17snorremdHi! I'm struggling to combine the with and insert-into functions to build a query. Any help is appreciated. EDIT: Found the answer using the pure clojure map specification: 
{:with [[:workday {:insert-into :workdays
                   :values [{:work-date (t/today)
                             :work-interval (t/new-duration 7 :hours)
                             :account-id #uuid "5d90856c-5a48-46ae-8f6e-a06295ea0dfb"}]
                   :on-conflict [:work-date :account-id]
                   :do-update-set [:work-interval]
                   :returning [:id]}]]
 :insert-into [[:work-intervals [:workday-id :interval-start]]
               {:select [:workday.id (t/now)]
                :from :workday}]}
Where I want to end up: 
WITH workday_insert AS (INSERT INTO workdays (work_date, work_interval, account_id) VALUES (?, ?, ?) ON CONFLICT (work_date, account_id) DO UPDATE SET work_interval = EXCLUDED.work_interval RETURNING id)
INSERT INTO work_intervals (workday_id, interval_start) INSERT INTO work_intervals (workday_id, interval_start) SELECT id, ? FROM workday_insert
What I have so far: 
(-> (hsqlh/with [:workday-insert (-> (hsqlh/insert-into :workdays)
                                     (hsqlh/values [{:work-date (t/today)
                                                     :work-interval (t/new-duration 7 :hours)
                                                     :account-id #uuid "5d90856c-5a48-46ae-8f6e-a06295ea0dfb"}])
                                     (hsqlh/on-conflict :work-date :account-id)
                                     (hsqlh/do-update-set :work-interval)
                                     (hsqlh/returning :id))])
    (hsqlh/insert-into :work-intervals
                       [:workday-id :interval-start]
                       (-> (hsqlh/select :id (t/now))
                           (hsqlh/from :workday-insert))))
Producing: 
["WITH workday_insert AS (INSERT INTO workdays (work_date, work_interval, account_id) VALUES (?, ?, ?) ON CONFLICT (work_date, account_id) DO UPDATE SET work_interval = EXCLUDED.work_interval RETURNING id) INSERT INTO work_intervals (workday_id, interval_start)"
 #time/date "2021-05-01"
 #time/duration "PT7H"
 #uuid "5d90856c-5a48-46ae-8f6e-a06295ea0dfb"]
It seems the select and from portion of the insert-into is simply dropped from the query. Not sure why. When running the insert-into function on its own and formatting I get: 
INSERT INTO work_intervals (workday_id, interval_start) SELECT id, ? FROM workday_insert
For reference I'm using the latest code of the v2-branch. 
com.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:git/url ""
                                  :sha "20cba15da22946d60f53dd6913caba990f7cddb7"
#2021-05-0118:26seancorfield@snorremd Can you open an issue on GitHub and I'll take a look at this next week when I'm back at work?#2021-05-0118:27seancorfieldIn the meantime, have a look in the v2 tests for insert-into / :insert-into -- pretty sure there's an INSERT INTO .. SELECT .. example there somewhere.#2021-05-0118:40snorremdI'll try to make a smallest possible reproduction of the working and non-working code in a repo and file an issue as soon as possible. This should make it easier for you to verify/test the issue. The INSERT INTO .. SELECT .. standalone case works well both with utility functions and the clojure map syntax, so there might be something with the utility functions and combining the insert-into and with statements. Many thanks for the quick reply. üëç#2021-05-0119:28seancorfield@snorremd It's a bug in the insert-into helper.#2021-05-0119:30seancorfieldIt doesn't expect to have a statement to already merge into.#2021-05-0119:49seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/324#2021-05-0119:57snorremdAh, I see. Thanks for looking into that.#2021-05-0119:57seancorfield@snorremd The fix is on the v2 branch if you want to test it?#2021-05-0119:57snorremdYeah, definitely.#2021-05-0119:57seancorfieldNew sha 46b3c1773b57ad17efda63f5ceee4f24c221ad0a#2021-05-0119:59snorremdI can verify that it now works as expected.#2021-05-0120:00seancorfieldThanks for finding that bug! This is why we have Beta releases üôÇ#2021-05-0120:01snorremdYeah, no problem! In the future, would you prefer if I just open issues for problems like these? I was not 100% sure if it was a bug in honeysql or some problem with my code, so I used the slack channel.#2021-05-0120:03seancorfieldPosting the example here is good. Others may see it and have input, in case there are workarounds or it isn't a bug.#2021-05-0120:04seancorfieldAnd my exposure to more "exotic" SQL is somewhat limited so I'm not always sure whether a given syntax is legal, especially for PostgreSQL üôÇ#2021-05-0404:58AkizHi! I am using honeysql together with Babashka and I would like to produce a raw sql queries compatible with psql. Is this possible right now?#2021-05-0405:23seancorfieldIf you're using V2, there is an inline option that tries to put the values inline in the string instead of using ? And putting the parameters in a vector#2021-05-0409:10AkizThank you, this is exactly what I needed.#2021-05-0409:14AkizHi, version 1 has build fn, i use it for removing keys with missing values to build a valid sql map. Is there something simiƒ∫lar in v2? #2021-05-0416:10seancorfield@zikajk No, V2 does not have that function. Can you explain what you mean by ‚Äúremoving keys with missing values‚Äù?#2021-05-0416:20Akiz@U04V70XH6 In HoneySQL v1 I had got a function like this: (defn build-select [table-name where limit] (hsql/format (hsql/build :select :* :from table-name :where where :limit limit))) All this was valid thanks to the build fn: (build-select :public.table) (build-select :public.table [:= :table.field "string"]) (build-select :public.table [:= :table.field "string"] 10) Now I changed the logic in HoneySQL v2 to this - so I can supply map with/out :where or :limit as before. (defn build-select [table-opts] (hsql/format (merge {:select [:*] :from [(:table-name table-opts)]} (select-keys table-opts [:where :limit])))) The input got a little different of course: (build-select {:table-name :public.table}) (I am building custom sql queries from EDN files. I used to read list of [table-name where limit] now it is (:table-name string :where vector :limit int}#2021-05-0416:23seancorfieldWell, it‚Äôs ‚Äújust data‚Äù so you can use cond-> and assoc to conditionally add things, or use the helper functions to make sure you get the right structure.#2021-05-0505:45seancorfield@zikajk BTW, if you‚Äôre reading a vector of [table-name where limit] you can always turn that into a map programmatically with (zipmap [table-name where limit] [:table-name :where :limit]) or your build-select could take [[table-name where limit]] as before and do (hsql/format (cond-> {:select [:*] :from [table-name]} where (assoc :where where) limit (assoc :limit limit)))#2021-05-0505:45seancorfield(in case you wanted to preserve the calling format)#2021-05-0506:17Akiz@U04V70XH6 Thank you. I already changed my code to use maps, no problem here. It is just that build fn is one of the first thing mentioned in HoneySQL v1 tutorial so I have been looking for it (as I migrated to version2 because of {:inline true} which is a great option btw.)#2021-05-1017:46thumbnailI'm new to honey and so far loving it!. V2 has been really solid! I'm composing a sub query and noticed the params are not filled in correctly :thinking_face: . 
(sql/format
  {:left-join [[{:select [:c]
                 :from   :a
                 :where  [:= :id 123]}]
               :x]
   :where     [:= :a/id 123]})
=> ["LEFT JOIN (SELECT c FROM a WHERE id = ?) ON x WHERE a.id = ?" 123]
I can work around it by using :where [:= :id [:inline 123]] but it I might be doing something wrong#2021-05-1018:33seancorfield@jeroen.dejong Hmm, that may be a form of JOIN that just isn‚Äôt supported yet.#2021-05-1018:33seancorfieldWhat DB are you using?#2021-05-1018:34thumbnailpostgres#2021-05-1018:36seancorfieldOf course üôÇ OK, I‚Äôll open an issue to review it and see if I can find PG‚Äôs docs about that syntax ‚Äî I know your posted example is simplified but it doesn‚Äôt make sense to me as written, so I‚Äôll need to see what the full syntax can be from the docs‚Ä¶#2021-05-1018:40seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/326#2021-05-1018:40thumbnailhaha sure thing. I converted this from a snippet I found in another projects codebase üòÖ; so the exact wizardry is lost on me too to be honest. Thanks !#2021-05-1018:57seancorfieldI can see where the parameter(s) are getting dropped. There‚Äôs an assumption in the formatter for JOIN that parameters will only ‚Äúappear‚Äù for a JOIN .. USING .. statement, not a JOIN .. ON .. statement. That‚Äôs an easy bug to fix‚Ä¶ OK, v2 has an update that ‚Äúfixes‚Äù your example case, if you want to test via :git/url?#2021-05-1018:58seancorfieldI‚Äôm going to leave that open until I have tests in place and a better understanding of the implication of making that change‚Ä¶#2021-05-1019:01thumbnailThat's epic! I'll try it out soon and let you know#2021-05-1106:55thumbnailJust tried out 2.0.0-rc2; and it indeed fixes my issue. Epic üôÇ Thanks again#2021-05-1018:55Noah Bogartfull syntax for postgres select is here: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-select.html#2021-05-1018:56Noah Bogartfrom clause, select: > A sub-SELECT can appear in the FROM clause. This acts as though its output were created as a temporary table for the duration of this single SELECT command. Note that the sub-SELECT must be surrounded by parentheses, and an alias must be provided for it.#2021-05-1018:57Noah Bogartfrom clause, join type: > A JOIN clause combines two FROM items, which for convenience we will refer to as ‚Äútables‚Äù, though in reality they can be any type of FROM item. Use parentheses if necessary to determine the order of nesting. In the absence of parentheses, JOINs nest left-to-right. In any case JOIN binds more tightly than the commas separating FROM-list items.#2021-05-1018:59Noah Bogartthe requirement to alias the sub-select might be something worth noting, @seancorfield, from the current output it looks like that's not being generated#2021-05-1019:00seancorfieldThe code snippet above does not have the alias in the correct place.#2021-05-1019:00Noah Bogartcool#2021-05-1019:01seancorfieldBut that highlights a second bug in the join formatting, which is that ON is optional, which the current formatter does not support üòê#2021-05-1019:03Noah Bogartoops, but also glad i could help#2021-05-1019:05seancorfieldOK, fix for that pushed to v2 as well. Now: 
user=> (sql/format
  #_=>   {:left-join [[{:select [:c]
  #_=>                  :from   :a
  #_=>                  :where  [:= :id 123]}
  #_=>                :x]]
  #_=>    :where     [:= :a/id 124]})
["LEFT JOIN (SELECT c FROM a WHERE id = ?) AS x WHERE a.id = ?" 123 124]
#2021-05-1019:05seancorfieldNote the nesting on the alias @jeroen.dejong#2021-05-1019:06seancorfield(that bug was due to using partition instead of partition-by)#2021-05-1019:09thumbnailAwesome! Big thanks for quick response üôÇ#2021-05-1019:49seancorfieldThanks for finding bugs! üôÇ#2021-05-1105:56seancorfieldcom.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-rc2"} ‚Äî https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/releases/tag/v2.0.0-rc2 ‚Äî bug fixes for JOIN, % function syntax (thanks to @zugnush), more control over quoted entity rendering.#2021-05-1107:03thumbnailAnother question, I noticed :%coalesce.a/id.b/id.c/id will format correctly in 2.0.0-rc2; But because it's not a valid keyword, Cursive prevents me from sending the form to the repl. Is there an alternative without resorting to :raw :thinking_face:?#2021-05-1116:24seancorfieldYou can either a) (keyword "%coalesce.a/id.b/id.c/id") or b) '%coalesce.a/id.b/id.c/id -- since symbols work as well as keywords (but the latter may be illegal for Cursive too?).#2021-05-1116:52thumbnailThat works, Thanks. Cursive indeed triggers the same "syntax error" on the symbol.#2021-05-1116:47seancorfieldFWIW, that keyword is just plain old illegal in ClojureScript, so even in the test suite I have to construct it programmatically by calling keyword.#2021-05-1209:19snorremdHello. What's the story around using your own Records/types with honeysql V2 . In version 1 there seems to be a honeysql.format/ToSQL protocol to tell honeysql how to deal with Record parameters. In v2 this seems to be gone? When I pass in a record type as a parameter to honeysql v2's format function it incorrectly parses the record fields as sql clauses: 
:message "Unknown SQL clauses: :beginning, :end"
Any thoughts on how to solve this in v2 is much appreciated. The use case would be to pass the record as a parameter value that can then be handled by next.jdbc's settable parameter protocol which would dispatch on the Record type. Edit: Since breaking changes can be introduced with V2, perhaps this would be a good time to just not treat Records as SQL clauses maps? Edit 2: The expression in question where interval in the select statement is the record in question. 
{:with [[:workday (workday-upsert m)]]
 :insert-into [[:work-intervals [:workday-id :interval]]
               {:select [:workday.id interval]
                :from :workday}]
 :returning :*}
#2021-05-1214:00snorremdSo I think the problem is related to how the format-selectable-dsl function checks if something is a map, which records are. https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v2/src/honey/sql.cljc#L257 It seems the code should check that something is both a map and not a record, but I'm not sure if this is then something that would have to be done a lot of places. Edit: I've not had the chance to test this in practice, but could test this after work today if you'd be interested in a pull-request for this.#2021-05-1216:17seancorfield@snorremd I think you can wrap such things with [:lift ..]#2021-05-1216:18seancorfieldThat‚Äôs the ‚Äúescape‚Äù mechanism for passing sequential and map-like types through as parameter values, if I‚Äôm understanding what you‚Äôre trying to do‚Ä¶#2021-05-1216:46snorremdSo something like this? 
(-> {:insert-into [[:foo [:interval]]
                   {:select [[:lift (->Interval nil nil)]]
                    :from :test}]}
    hsql/format)
Produced an error: 
; Execution error (ExceptionInfo) at honey.sql/format-dsl (sql.cljc:891).
; Unknown SQL clauses: :beginning, :end
#2021-05-1216:57seancorfield:select expects a sequence of expressions, but those can be aliased, so a function call without an alias still needs to be written as if it did have one ‚Äî the docs have examples and talk about this.#2021-05-1216:57seancorfield{:select [[[:lift (->Interval nil nil)]]] .. should do it.#2021-05-1216:58snorremdAh, thanks. That worked. üôÇ#2021-05-1216:58seancorfield:select [:a [:b :c] [[:fun 42] :d]] => SELECT a, b AS c, FUN(42) AS d#2021-05-1216:32Micha√´l SalihiHi everybody! I begin to playing with honeysql and I wonder how I can do SELECT (first_name, last_name) as name#2021-05-1216:34seancorfield
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:composite :first_name :last_name] :name]]})
["SELECT (first_name, last_name) AS name"]
#2021-05-1217:02Micha√´l SalihiI tried and it gives me this error: 
Assert failed: Alias should have two parts[:composite :first_name :last_name]
(= 2 (count x))
#2021-05-1217:09Micha√´l SalihiIt works with the helpers function call: 
(h/format {:select [[(composite :first_name :last_name) :name]]})
#2021-05-1217:10Micha√´l SalihiI prefer the first syntax. Any idea?#2021-05-1217:53seancorfieldYou have missed a level of nesting. Funnily enough I was just explaining this to someone else‚Ä¶#2021-05-1217:54seancorfield:select [:a :b :c] => SELECT a, b, c#2021-05-1217:54seancorfield:select [:a [:b :c]] => SELECT a, b AS c#2021-05-1217:54seancorfield:select [:a [[:foo :bar] :c]] => SELECT a, FOO(bar) AS c#2021-05-1217:55seancorfieldAnd as I showed above: 
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:composite :first_name :last_name] :name]]})
["SELECT (first_name, last_name) AS name"]
Note the nesting level.#2021-05-1217:56seancorfieldIf I add spaces it might be easier to see: 
user=> (sql/format {:select [    [  [:composite :first_name :last_name] :name  ]    ]})
["SELECT (first_name, last_name) AS name"]
#2021-05-1218:56Micha√´l SalihiNo success, always same error with a simple copy paste: 
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:composite :first_name :last_name] :name]]})
Execution error (AssertionError) at honeysql.format/seq->sql (format.cljc:385).
Assert failed: Alias should have two parts[:composite :first_name :last_name]
(= 2 (count x))

On V1, you‚Äôd have to use the helper I think or sql/call.#2021-05-1220:14Micha√´l SalihiI supposed sqlite is not well supported. With particulary syntax like: 
SELECT first_name || " " || last_name as name FROM users;
#2021-05-1220:26seancorfield[:|| :first_name " " :last_name] should work.#2021-05-1220:26seancorfield:select [ [ [:|| ...] :name ] ]#2021-05-1220:27seancorfield
user=> (sql/format {:select [ [ [:|| :first_name " " :last_name] :name ] ]})
["SELECT first_name || ? || last_name AS name" " "]
Several DBs have || as a string concatenation operator.#2021-05-1220:28seancorfieldSee https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-rc2/doc/getting-started/sql-operator-reference#2021-05-1220:38Micha√´l SalihiGreat, very relevant. Thanks a lot.#2021-05-1216:35seancorfield[:composite :first_name :last_name] is a function call/operator syntax#2021-05-1216:35seancorfield[[:composite :first_name :last_name] :name] is an aliased expression#2021-05-1216:35seancorfieldand :select takes a sequence of expressions#2021-05-1216:36Micha√´l SalihiOh I had missed :composite#2021-05-1216:36Micha√´l SalihiPerfect, thanks!#2021-05-1216:38seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/tree/v2#composite-types (README) ‚Äî although the usage shown is with insert rather than select#2021-05-1216:41Micha√´l SalihiLast thing, is there an equivalent of "%pattern%" for a where clause?#2021-05-1216:43seancorfieldNot sure what you mean.#2021-05-1216:43seancorfield[:like :first_name "%foo%"] ?#2021-05-1216:43Micha√´l SalihiYes#2021-05-1216:44seancorfieldBTW, it can be really inefficient to query with a leading % in a regex ‚Äî it will do a full table scan in all cases.#2021-05-1216:44seancorfieldTrailing % is OK, because SQL can use the stem value (the portion before the %) to narrow down the index range, assuming you have an index on the column üôÇ#2021-05-1216:47Micha√´l SalihiOh thanks, very useful information.#2021-05-1216:50Micha√´l SalihiSo with your snippet, if I want pass a var so I'll do [:like :first_name (str "%" foo "%")]#2021-05-1216:52Micha√´l Salihior is a cleaner way to do it?#2021-05-1216:55seancorfieldIf you have just a string and you want it to be a SQL regex and match anywhere in the column value, you have to add the % yourself.#2021-05-1216:56seancorfieldI think :like will be case sensitive in most cases (depends on the DB and how it is setup) so there‚Äôs also :ilike for a case-insensitive comparison#2021-05-1216:56Micha√´l SalihiGreat, thanks. üëç#2021-05-1409:45Lennart BuitCan you express nested functions in honeysql, say sum(coalesce(a, b))?#2021-05-1415:47dcjWould [:sum [:coalesce a b]] work?#2021-05-1416:23seancorfield
dev=> (sql/format-expr [:sum [:coalesce :a :b]])
["SUM(COALESCE(a, b))"]
dev=> (sql/format {:select [ [[:sum [:coalesce :a :b]] :c] ]})
["SELECT SUM(COALESCE(a, b)) AS c"]
dev=>
#2021-05-1716:36borkdudeAny tips on how to express: 
SELECT ARRAY[1,2] && foo;
in honeysql (still on v1 in our production app)? The left array is from values from input, the other array foo is from a table#2021-05-1716:38borkdudeI guess I can use (h/format (honeysql.types/array [1 2 3]))#2021-05-1716:41borkdudeand now the [:&& included-uuids :tzdb.tag_uuids] part: can I generate the && as an operator instead of a function?#2021-05-1716:42borkdude(sorry, this is probblay in the docs somewhere, but I have trouble finding it üòí )#2021-05-1716:49borkdudeIs there some hook to register a thing as an infix thing?#2021-05-1716:52borkdudeI did this: 
(defmethod hf/fn-handler "&&" [op & args]
  (let [args (map hf/to-sql args)]
    (hf/paren-wrap (str/join (str " " op " ") args))))
#2021-05-1717:04seancorfieldSounds like you‚Äôve solved the problem? Which DB is that for? || is a variadic infix operator in V2 for string concatenation so I‚Äôm a bit surprised to see && ‚Äî what does it mean?#2021-05-1717:31borkdude@seancorfield this is an array operator in postgresql.#2021-05-1717:31borkdude
array[1,2,3] && array[1,2,3,4]
means all the left elements must occur in the right elements#2021-05-1717:32borkdudeperhaps allowing people to say: "this is an infix operator" would be easier#2021-05-1717:36seancorfieldThat‚Äôs easy in HoneySQL v2 but I think fn-handler is the right approach in v1.#2021-05-1717:38seancorfieldIn v2 it‚Äôs (sql/register-op! :&& :variadic true) and you‚Äôre off to the races. But I‚Äôll go ahead and add && as a built-in for the next v2 version anyway.#2021-05-1717:43borkdudeExcellent! I'll try to migrate this one namespace to v2 now#2021-05-1717:43borkdudeWe can use them side by side anyway#2021-05-1717:44seancorfieldYup. develop has that change. It‚Äôll be in RC 3 or ‚Äúgold‚Äù, whichever comes next.#2021-05-1718:46borkdudeif I have an array like ARRAY["..."] but I want to generate ARRAY["..."]::uuid[], what's the best option?#2021-05-1718:49borkdude
[:cast included-uuids :uuid[]]
doesn't work obviously :)#2021-05-1718:53borkdudehacky and ugly, but it works: 
[:&& [:cast included-uuids [:lift (symbol "uuid[]")]]  :tzdb.tag_uuids]
open to improvements :)#2021-05-1718:55borkdudethis seems to work: [:&& [:cast included-uuids [:raw "uuid[]"]] :tzdb.tag_uuids]#2021-05-1718:59borkdudeThe :inline feature is great for debugging#2021-05-1719:54seancorfieldI‚Äôd probably go with :cast / :raw for a situation like that. Open to suggestions on making that easier ‚Äî but we‚Äôre sort of at the mercy of Clojure‚Äôs reader for that one.#2021-05-1720:13borkdudecast / raw works for me, it just wasn't what I usually write with hugsql#2021-05-1812:12borkdude@seancorfield any idea about this one? 
(sql/format {:select [:tzdb.source :tzdb.uri [:cast :tzdb.tag_uuids [:raw "text[]"]]]})
;;=>
["SELECT tzdb.source, tzdb.uri, cast AS tzdb.tag_uuids"]
I want something like cast(tzdb.tag_uuids as text[])#2021-05-1812:16borkdudeThis also doesn't work for me: (sql/format {:select [:tzdb.source :tzdb.uri [:raw "tzdb.tag_uuids::text[]"]]})#2021-05-1812:22borkdudeAgain, this works: (sql/format {:select ['foo 'bar (symbol "tzdb.tag_uuids::text[]")]}) but it's pretty ugly :)#2021-05-1812:23borkdudeperhaps instead of (symbol "tzdb.tag_uuids::text[]") honeysql could support a raw function, since [:raw ...] doesn't seem to work everywhere.#2021-05-1815:27seancorfieldFor functions in a select you need an extra level of brackets - otherwise it's an aliased column. The docs explain that but could clearly do a better job:grin:#2021-05-1817:28borkdude@seancorfield üôè 
:select [:tzdb.source :tzdb.uri [[:raw "tzdb.tag_uuids::text[]"]]]
there's nothing that can't be fixed using an extra pair of brackets#2021-05-1817:55seancorfieldWell, :select [[:a :b]] means SELECT a AS b so :select [[[:foo :a] :b]] means SELECT FOO(a) AS b#2021-05-1820:11borkdudeof course, once you see it you can't unsee it#2021-05-2000:57seancorfieldFYI: in preparation for 2.0 ‚Äúgold‚Äù hopefully dropping fairly soon, I have created a v1 branch from develop (in case I need to cut security fixes) and I have merged the v2 branch down onto develop. I will probably delete the v2 branch once I cut a ‚Äúgold‚Äù release from develop. I will also most likely drop double-publishing to Clojars at that point (so 2.0 ‚Äúgold‚Äù will not appear under the old seancorfield group ID).#2021-05-2001:14seancorfieldI‚Äôve expanded the SQL Expressions section in Getting Started to better explain how to SELECT function expressions https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/doc/getting-started.md#sql-expressions /cc @borkdude and everyone else who has run into that and asked questions here and on Zulip üôÇ#2021-06-0213:22Teemu KaukorantaHow do you cast strings to enums with honeysql? In case someone finds this message later, here's the approach I used https://www.bevuta.com/en/blog/using-postgresql-enums-in-clojure/#2021-06-0215:50seancorfieldYeah, if you‚Äôre using clojure.java.jdbc, you need to extend ISQLValue. That‚Äôs one of the nice things about next.jdbc: you can use any of the built-in JDBC types as ‚Äúhints‚Äù, via the next.jdbc.types namespace: https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/next.jdbc/1.2.659/api/next.jdbc.types#2021-06-0811:07orestisI've finally taken honeysql2 out for a spin. What an improvement @seancorfield, many thanks for taking the time. Funnily enough, it's the helpers documentation and clause reference that it's most useful so far. I like the new call convention, when reading examples I was worried about too many square brackets (obviously could use quoted parentheses there if I want to, right?)#2021-06-0815:25seancorfieldThank you, and I‚Äôm glad the new documentation is helping ‚Äî as I was rebuilding HoneySQL, I began to realize just how many features were not documented at all or only appeared in an example with no explanation! And, yes, the ‚Äúquoted list‚Äù format and being able to use symbols in place of keywords can make complex forms a lot more readable ‚Äî thanks to whoever it was that asked for ‚Äúquoted forms, like datalog etc‚Äù üôÇ#2021-06-0815:26seancorfieldThanks for the issues. Will take a look during my next ‚ÄúOSS window‚Äù this week.#2021-06-0908:04orestisOne suggestion that perhaps merit some discussion is re-introducing the call helper? It would help our migration quite a bit and the implementation could just be 
(defn call [f & args]
  (apply vector f args))
#2021-06-0912:13seancorfieldOpen a Github issue and I'll think about it.#2021-06-1504:36pinealanAre there examples out there for writing CTE in honeysql? I‚Äôm basically trying to write insert queries with https://dba.stackexchange.com/questions/46410/how-do-i-insert-a-row-which-contains-a-foreign-key so it involves quite a few types of clauses in one go where the interactions are not described in the docs#2021-06-1504:58seancorfield@achan961117 You mean like this? https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-rc2/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#with-with-recursive#2021-06-1505:00seancorfieldAnd if you're still using 1.x, the first test here has an example: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v1/test/honeysql/core_test.cljc#L16#2021-06-1505:10pinealanthanks for the pointer!#2021-06-1505:12pinealanya I‚Äôm still on 1.x, I‚Äôve only just read the 1.x -> 2 differences doc and still digesting the changes#2021-06-1609:30orestisIs there a way to order by NULLS FIRST/LAST in honeysql 2?#2021-06-1609:33orestisOh I see, just pass in a keyword: :desc-nulls-last which sql-kw would convert to DESC NULLS LAST#2021-06-1612:44orestisI see that honeysql v1 qualify was removed. It was quite handy for us, I've come up with a quick replacement: 
(defn- qualify
  "Replace honeysql v1 qualify function, that takes a table and column
  and joins them together."
  [table column]
  (keyword (hsql/format-entity (keyword (name table) (name column)))))
I was just wondering if there was something wrong with the original? I could copy that code.#2021-06-1614:07jaihindhreddyEncouraging pervasive use of namespaced keywords is the reason perhaps?#2021-06-1614:49seancorfieldWhat purpose do qualified names serve in SQL?#2021-06-1617:23orestisSo we use a lot of WITH statements that we later join to. Sometimes more than once with different table names. So the table name is dynamic. If you want to refer to a specific column you need to write it as table.column which is what the qualify function would give us #2021-06-1617:23orestisPerhaps there‚Äôs a more direct way to do this?#2021-06-1617:47seancorfieldSo you‚Äôre round-tripping through qualified keywords for that? I guess I‚Äôm having a hard time imagining what the code looks like for this to be needed‚Ä¶ Can you show a (simplified) example?#2021-06-1618:48orestisI‚Äôm on the phone but imagine that I have a base query map that I keep adding where clauses to (users adding filters etc) Some of the where clauses need additional with and left-join clauses. The with, left-join and where clauses must share the same table name. The table name is dynamic as a filter might be repeated. So all the column references need to be qualified at runtime with the dynamic table name. #2021-06-1618:50orestisNote, I don‚Äôt care about namespaced Clojure keywords at all. All I want is a honeysql function that given a table and a column will construct the correct keyword (to be later escaped properly) for an ‚Äúabsolute‚Äù column reference. #2021-06-1618:51orestisMy sample code took advantage that format-entity uses namespaced keywords to generate the escaped column reference. #2021-06-1619:19seancorfield:some_alias.some_col when you have [:table :some_alias] to alias table to some_alias?#2021-06-1619:19seancorfieldAnd :some_alias is the dynamic part here (not really the table name)?#2021-06-1619:21seancorfieldSo I think you just want (keyword (name the-alias) (name column)) and then HoneySQL will take care of formatting that? (you don‚Äôt need to call format-entity and convert back to a keyword) What am I missing?#2021-06-1707:16orestisRight, so there is a convention that I‚Äôm missing. In all of our hand written columns we use dot as a separator - alias.some_column - but you‚Äôre saying that namespaced keywords also would be equivalent; alias/some_column as far as honeysql is concerned? #2021-06-1716:18seancorfieldIn v1, you needed to specify :namespace-as-table? true as an option ‚Äî that has become the default in v2: 
dev=> (sql/format {:select [:foo/bar] :from [:foo] :where [[:= :foo/id 42]]})
["SELECT foo.bar FROM foo WHERE (foo.id = ?)" 42]
dev=>
#2021-06-1705:00pinealanIs it possible to create VALUES in FROM for postgresql in honeysql 1.x (or 2)?#2021-06-1705:04pinealanah nevermind scratch that, I realised it‚Äôs an issue with values in from requiring an alias, got what I wanted with 
(sql/format {:select [[:column1 :num]]
             :from [[{:values [[1] [2] [3]]} :vraw]]})
#2021-06-1715:08orestisMigrating our codebase to honeysql v2. An easy transition but I‚Äôm glad that we have end-to-end tests. If we had a bigger codebase I‚Äôd investigate an automated approach with rewrite-clj#2021-06-1715:09orestisThank you @seancorfield for taking the time to do this work. I particularly like some error messages that I saw!#2021-06-1716:24seancorfieldWe‚Äôre migrating one query at a time at work ‚Äî since we can have both v1 and v2 required into the same namespace.#2021-06-1716:46borkdudeI using both (versions of honeysql) at the moment. I just rewrote a query using honeysql which was previously in hugsql... it's way more fun (and easier to debug).#2021-06-1717:16orestisA lot of our queries are interconnected so they have to be changed as a unit. But otherwise we have hugsql, honeysql 1 and honeysql 2 :) We have committed to standardize on honeysql 2 though. #2021-06-1717:48borkdudeWhere can I get a t-shirt#2021-06-1717:49seancorfieldIf only HoneySQL had a project logo‚Ä¶#2021-06-1717:50borkdudeIf you like Calva's and clojure-lsp's logo, you could ask @jayzawrotny#2021-06-1717:52borkdudeNikitonsky designed clj-kondo and babashka's logo, but he's quite busy I think#2021-06-1717:53borkdude@lee also made a few logo's (jet and sci). So there, a few ideas#2021-06-1718:15lreadI also did rewrite-clj's current logo. It was not terribly imaginative, but I also came up with the clj-kondo icon clj-kondo. I would consider myself an amateur, but if you seriously want a logo, and none more talented makes an offer, I could take a stab at it sometime.#2021-06-1718:17borkdudeThe icon is iconic, thanks again @lee#2021-06-1718:19lreadFor you? Anytime!#2021-06-1813:39orestisShould there be support for CROSS JOIN LATERAL? I tried the [:lateral ...] wrapper but didn't get what I expected...#2021-06-1813:44orestis
{:select [:foo.id [ :x.id :x_id] :x.value ]
 :cross-join [[[:jsonb_to_recordset :foo.json_value]
                 [[:raw "x(id text, value jsonb)"]]]]
   :from [:foo]}
vs 
{:select [:foo.id [ :x.id :x_id] :x.value ]
   :cross-join [:lateral
                [[[:jsonb_to_recordset :foo.json_value]
                  [[:raw "x(id text, value jsonb)"]]]]]
   :from [:foo]}
The latter returns: 
SELECT foo.id, x.id AS x_id, x.value
FROM foo
CROSS JOIN lateral, (JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value), (x(id text, value jsonb)))
instead of 
SELECT foo.id, x.id AS x_id, x.value
FROM foo
CROSS JOIN LATERAL JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value) x(id text, value jsonb)
#2021-06-1813:45orestisPerhaps there should be a :cross-join-lateral keyword? Can I add this on my own?#2021-06-1817:13seancorfield@orestis Is this what you‚Äôre after? 
dev=> (sql/format {:select [:foo.id [ :x.id :x_id] :x.value ]
 #_=>    :cross-join [[[:lateral
 #_=>                 [[:jsonb_to_recordset :foo.json_value]
 #_=>                   [:raw "x(id text, value jsonb)"]]]]]
 #_=>    :from [:foo]})
["SELECT foo.id, x.id AS x_id, x.value FROM foo CROSS JOIN LATERAL (JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value), x(id text, value jsonb))"]
:cross-join takes a sequence of SQL entities; each can be a simple name or a pair of expression/alias ‚Äî like :select ‚Äî so when you want a ‚Äúfunction call‚Äù there, you need :cross-join [ [ [:fn-call :arg1 :arg2] ] ] just like in a SELECT.#2021-06-1817:15seancorfieldLooking at your desired result more carefully, I think you want this: 
dev=> (sql/format {:select [:foo.id [ :x.id :x_id] :x.value ]
 #_=>    :cross-join [[[:lateral
 #_=>                   [:jsonb_to_recordset :foo.json_value]]]
 #_=>                 [[:raw "x(id text, value jsonb)"]]]
 #_=>    :from [:foo]})
["SELECT foo.id, x.id AS x_id, x.value FROM foo CROSS JOIN LATERAL JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value), x(id text, value jsonb)"]
Again, the :raw part needs to be treated as a function call in the sequence of CROSS JOIN expressions.#2021-06-1817:17seancorfieldSo we have [:lateral [:jsonb..]] as one function call, wrapped as an alias (with the actual alias omitted): [ [:lateral [:jsonb..]] ] and then the same for [ [:raw ..] ]#2021-06-1817:19seancorfieldI notice you don‚Äôt have a , in your desired expression: CROSS JOIN LATERAL JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value) x(id text, value jsonb) ‚Äî is that intentional? I‚Äôm not quite sure what to make of that syntax‚Ä¶#2021-06-1817:25orestisThanks for answering @seancorfield - first of all, putting the lateral as in your example works. I was putting it surrounding the entire expression but I was confused üôÇ#2021-06-1817:26orestisRegarding the raw placement: my example is actually what I'm after. In this case, the x(id text, value jsonb) is a cast expression. jsonb_to_recordset takes a postgres jsonb array and creates a "set" (or table, or relation) out of it. But since SQL is statically typed you need to provide the columns and their types as a cast expression.#2021-06-1817:27orestisI discovered that technically for postgres the LATERAL is not needed in a table-returning-function (it can refer to other tables already in the FROM clause).#2021-06-1817:28seancorfieldSo you‚Äôre aiming for JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value) AS x(id text, value jsonb) essentially?#2021-06-1817:29seancorfield(i.e., x is the name you are trying to give to the record set?)#2021-06-1817:29orestisIf you're interested, given a column containing this JSONB data (using EDN for type laziness): [{:id "foo" :value "bar"}, [{:id "qoo" :value "cux"}]it would return 2 rows with the columns id, value.#2021-06-1817:29orestisYes, x is the name of the recordset that you can use in the SELECT clause.#2021-06-1817:30orestisAS is optional as in many other places. SQL is soooo weird üôÇ#2021-06-1817:30orestisSo, no worries from my end: honeysql provides what I want, and turns out I didn't need it anyway üôÇ Thanks for taking the time.#2021-06-1817:31orestisBetween honeysql queries-as-data and PostgreSQL's power I can create pivot tables quite easily. Dynamically generate column definitions etc üôÇ#2021-06-1817:31seancorfieldOK, here it is: 
dev=> (sql/format {:select [:foo.id [ :x.id :x_id] :x.value ]
 #_=>    :cross-join [[[:lateral
 #_=>                   [:jsonb_to_recordset :foo.json_value]]
 #_=>                   [[:raw "x(id text, value jsonb)"]]]]
 #_=>    :from [:foo]})
["SELECT foo.id, x.id AS x_id, x.value FROM foo CROSS JOIN LATERAL JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value) x(id text, value jsonb)"]
#2021-06-1817:33seancorfield:cross-join now has a single expression: an alias pair. The first part of that alias pair is [:lateral ..] and the second part is the nested ‚Äúfunction call‚Äù of [[:raw ..]].#2021-06-1817:34seancorfield:cross-join [ [expr [AS] alias] ] where [AS] is just intended to show how the aliased expression gets created.#2021-06-1817:35orestisGotcha, I ended up with the same result. I was looking for "lateral" in the docs and found a couple of hits but I I was tired üôÇ#2021-06-1817:35orestisBTW, honeysql is CLJC, right? Would be a nice project to put together a webpage that takes a honeysql query on the left and gives you SQL on the right.#2021-06-1817:36orestisI think malli has something similar with also some persistence that makes it for a nice playground and easier for creating issues and so on...#2021-06-1817:36seancorfieldThe ‚Äúproblem‚Äù is that pretty much any combination of expressions with [..`]` is ‚Äúvalid‚Äù as far as the DSL is concerned and most of them produce valid SQL with various meanings, but not all of the possible SQL outputs are going to be valid üôÇ#2021-06-1817:36orestis(hoping someone likes the idea and takes it up, I don't have time myself üòÑ)#2021-06-1817:37seancorfieldI don‚Äôt do cljs/frontend at all so it won‚Äôt be me either!#2021-06-1817:37orestisI think that's a valid tradeoff. SQL is infinitely complicated and getting a DSL able to express all of it correctly while still being data will be impossible.#2021-06-1817:38orestisYou do end up using the REPL quite a lot during query development, and for the more complex stuff you do have to run the query against a live DB anyway -- but that's what we do in Clojure anyway üôÇ#2021-06-1817:40seancorfieldYeah, I tend to build my more complex queries up in RCFs with dummy data values, to ensure I‚Äôm getting what I want. But I also use MySQL so life is a lot simpler üôÇ#2021-06-1817:43orestisRCF?#2021-06-1817:44seancorfieldRich Comment Form.#2021-06-1817:44orestisHehe most of our queries are pretty simple too. But we're migrating a MongoDB database with an actual valid use case of using schema-less in some areas. And these areas we have to dig into Postgres JSON support which is great but also weird üôÇ#2021-06-1817:44orestisAh yes. Same here üôÇ#2021-06-1817:45seancorfieldA name coined by Stu Halloway for (comment ..) forms used while developing/exploring problem solutions ‚Äî because Rich Hickey does it that way (you can see some such forms at the bottom of some namespaces in Clojure).#2021-06-1817:45seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/332#2021-06-1817:52orestisI knew the term but not the acronym üôÇ#2021-06-1902:32john-shaffer@orestis https://www.john-shaffer.com/honeysql/#2021-06-1902:33john-shafferVery primitive, but works & maybe I'll have time later to spruce it up#2021-06-1902:37john-shafferKnow any good syntax/highlighting libs for sql/edn?#2021-06-1903:28seancorfield@jshaffer2112 That is awesome! üôÇ#2021-06-1909:39borkdude@jshaffer2112 you could try to integrate nextjournal/clojure-mode: https://nextjournal.github.io/clojure-mode/ also sci for clojure(script) evaluation if you need it.#2021-06-1909:40borkdudefor only highlighting, perhaps highlight.js has sql support#2021-06-2115:17john-shafferThanks, those look great. I'm getting married Saturday, but I'll try those out once things settle down#2021-06-2115:18borkdudeCongrats!#2021-06-2114:00borkdudeHow do I express x is not null in honeysql?#2021-06-2114:01borkdude
[:raw "username is not null"]
:)#2021-06-2114:18john-shaffer
[:not= nil :username]
#2021-06-2114:28seancorfield
dev=> (sql/format {:where [:is-not nil :x]})
["WHERE x IS NOT NULL"]
dev=> (sql/format {:where [:<> nil :x]})
["WHERE x IS NOT NULL"]
dev=> (sql/format {:where [:not= nil :x]})
["WHERE x IS NOT NULL"]
#2021-06-2116:27borkdudethe possibilities are endless!#2021-06-2220:31Eric CasteleijnIs there a way to express array_agg(distinct table.field) in honeysql, specifically the distinct there, or do I have to fall back to raw in that case?#2021-06-2220:39seancorfield@thisfred If you‚Äôre using 2.0.0 RC 3, you can do it like this: 
dev=> (sql/format-expr [:array_agg [:distinct :table/field]])
["ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT table.field)"]
#2021-06-2220:39Eric CasteleijnThank you so much!#2021-06-2220:40seancorfieldOr like this in a select: 
dev=> (sql/format {:select [ [ [:array_agg [:distinct :table/field]] :agg ] ] :from :table})
["SELECT ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT table.field) AS agg FROM table"]
#2021-06-2220:40Eric CasteleijnI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre on that yet, but I‚Äôll make a note to replace the raw with that as soon as we upgrade#2021-06-2307:28orestisHere's a touch one: Can we use operators that are not valid clojure keywords? Postgresql has some array operators that contain @ , particularly @> and <@#2021-06-2312:12thumbnailYou could use (keyword "<@") at the very least#2021-06-2315:42seancorfield
dev=> (def at> (keyword "@>"))
#'dev/at>
dev=> (def <at (keyword "<@"))
#'dev/<at
dev=> (sql/register-op! at>)
nil
dev=> (sql/register-op! <at)
nil
dev=> (sql/format {:select :* :from :foo :where [:and [at> :a :b] [<at :c :d]]})
["SELECT * FROM foo WHERE (a @> b) AND (c <@ d)"]
#2021-06-2317:25orestisAh nice. I forgot that you can make keywords which are valid but "unreadable".#2021-06-2317:31john-shafferI do exactly this, but are the warnings on https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/keyword still valid? 
;; keyword does not validate input strings for ns and name, and may
;; return improper keywords with undefined behavior for non-conformant
;; ns and name.
;; Warning - the following generated keywords are non-conformant and may wreak
;; serious havoc in the near/far future when least expected...
iirc undefined === "behavior can change at any time"#2021-06-2317:33john-shafferI don't think it's a big deal here, but I see a lot of places where people e.g. take arbitrary JSON as input and decode with keyword keys, and it seems pretty scary if the result is undefined#2021-06-2317:35john-shafferShould I be a stickler about using string keys, or are keywords actually fine?#2021-06-2317:45seancorfieldThe core team did at one point try to tighten up what keywords the reader accepted but it broke quite a bit of code out there ‚Äî so they reverted that change. I think at this point you are ‚Äúsafe‚Äù creating unreadable keywords via keyword as long as you don‚Äôt actually try to .#2021-06-2317:46seancorfield(and, in particular, http://clojuredocs.org is not official documentation so examples and commentary are what random community members think üôÇ )#2021-06-2517:20rlanderHey folks! How do I call a PG stored procedure in HoneySQL v1.0?#2021-06-2517:22rlanderIn plain SQL it¬¥d be CALL stored_procedure_name(argument_list)#2021-06-2618:04seancorfieldAt the suggestion of @borkdude I have enabled Discussions on GitHub https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/discussions (and I now plan to do this for most of my projects).#2021-06-2707:46Ilan UzanI am trying to use :param inside :raw because I have an unsupported SQL clause postgres: 
(sql/format {:select [:*]
             :from [:blah]
             :where [:raw ["x >>= " [:param :x]]]})
I don't get where to place the param value - this throws: 
missing parameter value for :x
and what worked in honeysql-1: 
(sql/format {:select [:*]
             :from [:blah]
             :where [:raw ["x >>= " [:param :x]]] :params {:x 3}})
Execution error (ExceptionInfo) at honey.sql/format-dsl (sql.cljc:904).
These SQL clauses are unknown or have nil values: :params
does not work in honeysql-2...#2021-06-2716:13Ilan Uzannevermind, it works - my code wasn't doing what I thought it was doing.#2021-06-2717:44seancorfieldJust to follow-up on @ilan800‚Äôs post -- this works: 
dev=> (sql/format {:select [:*]
 #_=>              :from [:blah]
 #_=>              :where [:raw ["x >>= " [:param :x]]]}
 #_=>             {:params {:x 3}})
["SELECT * FROM blah WHERE x >>= ?" 3]
but it's easy enough to just register >>= as a new binary operator and use it directly: 
dev=> (sql/register-op! '>>=)
nil
dev=> (sql/format {:select [:*]
 #_=>              :from [:blah]
 #_=>              :where [:>>= :x [:param :x]]}
 #_=>             {:params {:x 3}})
["SELECT * FROM blah WHERE x >>= ?" 3]
#2021-06-2807:28Ilan Uzaneven better! thanks:)#2021-06-2905:46Krishan VHey everyone, I am trying to insert 3 new records into two tables at the same time. The first record that goes into Table A looks somewhat like {:id "" :name ""} while the second and third record that goes into Table B looks like {:a_id "" :country_id ""} where a_id is a foreign key constraint. How do I go about creating records through association with honeysql? Is there a reading or somewhere in the docs where I can try to self-serve from?#2021-06-2906:02seancorfield@krishanvj I'm afraid I don't understand what you're trying to do... HoneySQL is just a DSL to create SQL from Clojure data structures so if you don't know what the SQL should be, we're not going to be able to help you figure out what the DSL should be.#2021-06-2908:49Krishan VI see, I'll have to shake off my ORM habits. I've decided to go with separate insert statements and have resolved this issue. Thanks anyways!#2021-06-2919:08seancorfieldhttps://blog.codinghorror.com/object-relational-mapping-is-the-vietnam-of-computer-science/ üôÇ#2021-07-0209:27Krishan VWhat would the DSL look like if my raw SQL were to look like this? 
INSERT INTO profiles_to_countries (profile_id, country_id)
SELECT '04d6b414-2163-476d-8d20-91f918f63045', c.id 
FROM countries c 
WHERE c.region = 'Africa'
My select statement returns a list of values which are them inserted in a join table. My incomplete statement is somewhat like this. I am unsure how the c.id bit would translate to the DSL 
(->
  (sqlh/insert-into :profiles_to_countries)
  (sqlh/select [(:profiles_id m) ()])
  (sql/format))
#2021-07-0215:26seancorfield@krishanvj There are examples of this in the docs https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-rc3/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#insert-into#2021-07-0504:12Krishan VThanks! @U04V70XH6. Is it possible to interpolate variables directly into the SQL statement rather than using bindings with HoneySQL? e.g: INSERT INTO profile (name, age) VALUES ("John Doe", "30") instead of INSERT INTO profile (name, age) VALUES (?, ?) My intention is to generate an SQL file which I can use for an up.sql migration script.#2021-07-0504:19Krishan VNevermind, I just found out about the :inline true option in format Loving this library, thank you so much for making this possible! @U04V70XH6#2021-07-0819:53mjosefsHi there! I‚Äôm wondering if there‚Äôs any way to access a composite type (as in https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/rowtypes.html#ROWTYPES-ACCESSING ) with honeysql? Re the linked example: as I‚Äôm not able to use :(item).name, is there any alternative way to express (item).name? (I could only find how to compose a composite type in the docs; any way to decompose it would be useful.)#2021-07-0821:54seancorfieldI suspect (keyword "(item)" "name") would work (but that's pretty ugly). I'd probably define :. as special syntax: 
dev=> (sql/register-fn! :. (fn [_ [x y]] [(str "(" (sql/format-entity x) ")." (sql/format-entity y))]))
...
dev=> (sql/format-expr [:. :item :name])
["(item).name"]
Maybe (sql/format-expr x) if that can be an expression -- but that returns [sql & params] so you'd need a more complex formatted...#2021-07-0821:55seancorfield@marcus.josefsson ‚òùÔ∏è:skin-tone-2: Does that help?#2021-07-0909:14mjosefsIt does - many thanks for the help!#2021-07-0902:24pinealanI‚Äôm trying to use honeysql to format an insert Prepared Statement with next.jdbc/execute-batch!, how that seems not possible since honey.sql needs all the values up front to format the sql string appropriately, and I‚Äôm stuck using next.jdbc/execute!. Are there idioms that I‚Äôm missing which would make things easier? Should I even be concerned with using execute-batch!?#2021-07-0902:43seancorfieldexecute-batch! exists for a very specific purpose, namely "repeating" the same statement -- typically an insert -- with lots (and often LOTS) of groups of parameters.#2021-07-0902:44seancorfieldHoneySQL is designed to help you programmatically create single SQL statements with a (single) group of parameters.#2021-07-0902:45seancorfield@achan961117 Does that help?#2021-07-0906:05pinealanthanks ya I think I can stick with honeysql and use partition with doseq and achieve a similar factor of optimisation#2021-07-1213:00zackteoHello, may I know if there is a good way to changed the namespaced keywords (based on the table) to normal keywords in honeysql? Am thinking it is removing the namespace part is better when I pass the resulting sql result to my frontend. I know I can do something like ... 
(zipmap (map (comp keyword name)
               (keys sql-result)) (vals sql-result))
do i just do that?#2021-07-1215:29thumbnailThere might be a better way; but aliases don‚Äôt get a namespace. So if you {:select [[[:user/id] :my_id]]}; it returns :user/id as :my_id#2021-07-1218:26seancorfield@UUSQHP535 I don't understand the context of this question. What perceived problem are you trying to solve? I've never needed to do anything like this.#2021-07-1403:00zackteo@U04V70XH6 I was thinking of renaming/removing the namespace from the keywords. So that my frontend doesn't need to know in which database table the column of data comes from#2021-07-1403:03seancorfieldI'm not sure what that has to do with HoneySQL? You use HoneySQL to generate SQL that you then pass to a JDBC library (by which point namespaced keywords have been processed/removed).#2021-07-1403:03seancorfieldThe JDBC library might give you back namespace-qualified keywords but that has nothing to do with HoneySQL.#2021-07-1403:05seancorfieldYou can tell the JDBC library to not qualify column names -- but my recommendation would be to allow that and to have a transformation at the boundary where you pass data back to the frontend: I would argue that in general the over-the-wire data you send from the backend to the frontend should be a specific API (that suits the client) and should not just be an exact copy of the data model used inside your backend.#2021-07-1403:08seancorfieldIn my handler function, which returns data to the API, I would probably either destructure the data to extract just the fields the API needs (and give them appropriate "API" names) or use a combination of select-keys and clojure.set/rename-keys to produce an appropriately named data structure for the client.#2021-07-1403:09seancorfieldThis isolates your frontend code from any changes in your data model -- and also allows for your frontend/API to change independently of your data model.#2021-07-1403:10seancorfieldThe data structures going back and forth between your API and your client are a good candidate for validation with Spec (using :req-un/`:opt-un` keys).#2021-07-1404:50zackteooops, yeah you are right, this is a next.JDBC. Was getting things mixed up because was concurrently thinking if i should be renaming it with :as in sql#2021-07-1404:51zackteoThanks for your advice! Let me try to implement what you explained#2021-07-1218:11borkdudedoes honeysql support this syntax in do-update-set? 
;; do update set (docdata_user_id, docdata_client_id, profile, last_login, _updated, login_count) =
;; (:docdata_user_id, :docdata_client_id, excluded.profile, now()::timestamp, now()::timestamp, users.login_count + 1)
#2021-07-1218:11borkdudeso set (x,y,z) = (foo,bar,baz)?#2021-07-1218:11borkdudeI'm trying to convert a hugsql query#2021-07-1218:32seancorfield@borkdude I don't think you can do a composite set like that, but you can specify a hash map of columns/values that it will set: :do-update-set {:docdata_user_id :docdata_user_id, :docdata_client_id :docdata_client_id, :profile :excluded.profile, :last_login ..., :_updated ..., :login_count [:+ :users.login_count 1]}#2021-07-1218:32borkdudeoh that's equally good#2021-07-1218:33seancorfield(I'm not quite sure what the best way to write the cast syntax is [:cast [:now] :timestamp] would probably work)#2021-07-1218:33borkdudeI don't care about the SQL it generates, as long as it's the thing that's semantically the same#2021-07-1218:33borkdudeyeah, I can always do a :raw for that as well#2021-07-1218:33borkdudethanks!#2021-07-1218:36seancorfieldThe docs have an example of :do-update-set with a hash map BTW#2021-07-1218:36seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-rc3/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#on-conflict-on-constraint-do-nothing-do-update-set#2021-07-1719:33Daniel Hughüëã Hi, I am using honeysql version 2.0.0-rc3 and seem to have encountered a couple bugs with the :fetch clause. 1. 
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
(require '[honey.sql :as sql])
nil
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
(sql/format {:select [:id :name]
             :from [:table]
             :offset 20 :fetch 10})
["SELECT id, name FROM table OFFSET ? FETCH ?" 20 10]
According to the second example in https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/doc/clause-reference.md#limit-offset-fetch we are missing the ONLY term 
;; expected return
["SELECT id, name FROM table OFFSET ? FETCH ? ONLY" 20 10]
2. 
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
(require '[honey.sql.helpers :as h])
nil
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
(h/fetch 10)
{:offset 10}
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
Should the map returned contain the :fetch key instead of the :offset key?#2021-07-1719:48seancorfield@daniel_hugh Is it actually syntactically illegal for the JDBC driver you're using?#2021-07-1721:59Daniel HughYes it appears to be illegal. I am using a JDBC driver for Microsoft SQL Server and it looks like it requires the ONLY term according to the syntax docs https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/queries/select-order-by-clause-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15 EDIT: Actually in my case, FETCH ? ONLY isn't enough üòû I would need something like FETCH NEXT 20 ROWS ONLY with terms like NEXT and ROWS like described in this old issue https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/58 So it looks like I will need to create a custom clause.#2021-07-1723:59seancorfieldDarn, I thought bits were optional. Sigh. I suspect OFFSET also needs ROW or ROWS for SQL Server? I'll have to do that based on dialect because MySQL can't have ROWS there. PostgreSQL can have OFFSET n or OFFSET n ROWS (of course it can!). And it can either have LIMIT n (like MySQL) or FETCH FIRST n ROWS ONLY (FIRST/NEXT are synonyms, ROW/ROWS are synonyms).#2021-07-1800:04Daniel HughYep seems like that is the case for OFFSET in SQL Server. What an interesting standard we have for SQL haha#2021-07-1800:53seancorfieldAre you specifying :sqlserver as your dialect, BTW?#2021-07-1800:55seancorfieldI'm going to set it up so if there's :offset and :fetch it will use this verbose style, if there's :offset and :limit it will use the abbreviated style, and if there's :offset on its own, it will only use the verbose style for the :sqlserver dialect -- which I think is the only way to not introduce breaking behavior.#2021-07-1800:56Daniel HughNo i am not currently using the dialect option#2021-07-1801:00Daniel HughI think that will work for my use case. The query I have uses both :offset and :fetch#2021-07-1801:03seancorfield@daniel_hugh OK, 2.0.0-rc5 is available on Clojars. Can you try it out and let me know if it works for you?#2021-07-1801:04seancorfieldOnce I get the all-clear from you, I'll go ahead and actually announce that RC üôÇ#2021-07-1801:06Daniel HughSure thing. Let me get on a computer#2021-07-1801:17Daniel HughGreat! That works for me üôÇ Thanks for implementing this so quickly üòÑ#2021-07-1801:21seancorfieldThank you for catching this before I got to "gold"!#2021-07-1801:35Daniel HughOh yeah, I suppose the original example that started this all would need to be updated as well with the verbose style. https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/doc/clause-reference.md#limit-offset-fetch 
(sql/format {:select [:id :name]
             :from [:table]
             :offset 20 :fetch 10})

["SELECT id, name FROM table OFFSET ? ROWS FETCH NEXT ? ROWS ONLY" 20 10]

(require '[honey.sql.helpers :as h])
nil
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
(h/fetch 10)
{:offset 10}
cljÍûâuserÍûâ>¬†
Should the map returned contain the¬†`:fetch`¬†key instead of the¬†`:offset`¬†key?#2021-07-1723:50seancorfieldI did not see that, no, sorry.#2021-07-1723:52seancorfieldOK, that's fixed on develop.#2021-07-1801:35seancorfieldOK, com.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.0.0-rc5"} -- https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/releases/tag/v2.0.0-rc5 -- fixes :fetch/`:offset` for SQL Server (and ANSI/PostgreSQL too), fixes the fetch helper and the with-columns helper, improve error reporting when an entity is required but something else if provided, improves the :cross-join documentation. This should be the last RC and 2.0.<commits> will be the "gold" version arriving at the end of the month!#2021-07-1915:05john-shafferWhy 2.0.<commits>?#2021-07-1915:29seancorfield@jshaffer2112 All my projects follow MAJOR.MINOR.COMMITS these days -- same as many of the Clojure tools. I think it's a better model than SemVer.#2021-07-1915:30seancorfieldPer the HoneySQL README: > Once the prerelease testing is complete, this project will follow the version scheme MAJOR.MINOR.COMMITS where MAJOR and MINOR provide some relative indication of the size of the change, but do not follow semantic versioning. In general, all changes endeavor to be non-breaking (by moving to new names rather than by breaking existing names). COMMITS is an ever-increasing counter of commits since the beginning of this repository.#2021-07-1915:42john-shafferWhy the commits counter though, as opposed to incrementing by one? It seems like a very considered choice, but I haven't found any explanation of the reasoning behind it#2021-07-1916:58seancorfieldThe commit counter is easy to base a version on programmatically -- tools.build has a built-in function for that -- and it gives a sense of how much change has occurred between two releases. It also makes it clear you're not using SemVer (which just incrementing the patch slot would look like).#2021-07-1916:59seancorfieldThe Clojure CLI, tools.deps.alpha, and several other libraries have all adopted this so I think it's a good model to follow.#2021-07-1917:51seancorfield@jshaffer2112 Alex told me "commits is a meaningful, monotonically-increasing, quantitative description of version over time. major.minor is a subjective, human oriented description of version. Combined, you get both."#2021-07-1917:51seancorfield(and I agree üôÇ )#2021-07-1917:56john-shafferThanks! That makes sense#2021-07-2018:48orestisTIL about the commits rationale. Thanks @seancorfield#2021-07-2618:46v3gaWhat would be a good way to go about deleting a record by ID with honeysq≈Ç? I've updated honeysql and depstar like that.#2021-07-2906:15seancorfield(and expectations.clojure.test!)#2021-07-2906:17seancorfieldI hope you will also continue to provide feedback like this -- it is super helpful (even if I seem dense about understanding the feedback sometimes!)#2021-07-3111:26AdieHey all, I am using https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres#upsert for upserting this data in my postgres database. The table has this schema: 
CREATE TABLE my_table (
                      key varchar(150) NOT NULL,
                      value jsonb,
                      PRIMARY KEY (key)
);
My clojure code looks like this: 
(defn upsert!
  [table record constraint-name where-clause]
  (-> (insert-into table)
      (values [record])
      (where* where-clause)
      (psqlh/upsert (-> (psqlh/on-conflict-constraint constraint-name)
                        (psqlh/do-update-set :key
                                             :value)
                        ))
      sql/format)
But I am getting this error on calling the upsert function on the same key twice : 
2021-07-30 19:42:30.656 UTC [2376] ERROR:  duplicate key value violates unique constraint "my_table_pkey"
2021-07-30 19:42:30.656 UTC [2376] DETAIL:  Key (key)=(8343847329) already exists.
2021-07-30 19:42:30.656 UTC [2376] STATEMENT:  INSERT INTO my_table (driver_id, tags) VALUES ($1, $2)
As per the doc the query in postgres should look like below : 
["INSERT INTO distributors (did, dname) VALUES (?, ?), (?, ?) ON CONFLICT (did) DO UPDATE SET dname = EXCLUDED.dname RETURNING *"
    5 "Gizmo Transglobal" 6 "Associated Computing, Inc"]
#2021-07-3111:31AdieThe following query works fine when executed directly in the psql shell. 
INSERT INTO my_table (key, value) VALUES ('8343847329', '{"val-a": "hello", "val-b": ["ABC" "XYZ" "PQR"], "val-c": "MNO", "val-d": ["RST"]}') ON CONFLICT (key) DO UPDATE SET value = EXCLUDED.value RETURNING *;
I feel my clojure code is unable to create the appropriate DML for the expected psql query.#2021-07-3112:53indyYou can start debugging by comparing the output of the upsert query returned by your function with the one you intend to run. What is the output of the upsert query that you generated using honesql-postgres?#2021-07-3112:54indyFrom the log that you posted, doesn't seem like the on conflict bit has been included#2021-07-3113:09Adiecan you please share some doc how to log querys generated from honeysql#2021-07-3113:11indyYou just have to call the function that generates the query from the REPL, in your case the upsert! function. It'll give you the output. sql/format will return something like ["SELECT * FROM some_table"].#2021-07-3113:25indyFrom your past messages in other channels, it seems you've misunderstood honeysql. To clarify things, honeysql and it's postgres fork by nilenso are only query builders, they will only help you build queries using Clojure's datastructures and don't interact with the database at all. It is the JDBC driver that will interact with the DB, this is done using next.jdbc and the postgres driver in your case. So the flow is something like this, 1. You build SQL queries using honeysql that take clojure data structures as input. 2. You pass this query to next.jdbc's functions like next.jdbc/execute , next.jdbc.sql/query and others. 3. next.jdbc will interact with the DB using the chosen driver, postgres in your case and return you the results if any.#2021-07-3114:41AdieThose are old messages when I had barely used honeysql#2021-07-3115:17AdieI ran the exact same example on my repl as shown here https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres#upsert but my query is coming as different#2021-07-3115:18AdieThe exact same is happening for my table as well.#2021-07-3115:26indyAre you using honeysql 2? It seems honeysql 2 doesn't work with honeysql-postgres https://github.com/nilenso/honeysql-postgres/issues/62#2021-07-3115:28indyNot sure if the situation has changed since the comments are dated#2021-07-3115:30indyBut honeysql 2 has direct support for upsert https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-rc5/doc/getting-started/postgresql-support#2021-08-0116:11p-himikIs there a common approach towards approaching aliases/CTE names generation in reusable subquery-generating functions? I have a lot of functions that generate small clauses, some of which require aliases due to nesting or names for some CTEs. Hard-coding them can't work because the same function can be used multiple times for the same query. Passing them can't work because the overall internal API is rather generic - the caller just cares about the changes it should make to the sqlmap, it doesn't care about which tiny function requires which aliases/names. I'm about to implement a mechanism similar to (gensym) with just a plain atom and ID increment + rollover (paranoid, I know). But maybe there's a known solution, maybe even a function somewhere for that, that I just can't find?#2021-08-0116:33deletedI was reading that and thinking "wow, sounds like gensym" and sure enough üòÇ#2021-08-0116:35p-himikgensym can't alleviate my paranoia - it doesn't have roll-over. :)#2021-08-0116:44p-himikA single swap! with if should be simpler though. I should've been more clear - the crux of the issue is not getting a unique identifier itself but rather having it work automagically. I've glanced at the source and there doesn't seem to be such a thing, but I could be blind.#2021-08-0116:48p-himikBut why can't I just use the counter itself? Just like gensym does. So an alias would be something like :G_234975 .#2021-08-0116:51p-himikNah, given my overflow paranoia it makes sense. Although that would have to be one large query to fit repeating IDs.#2021-08-0116:57p-himikJava doesn't have built-in unsigned number types though. And overflowing a long leads to an exception. And better be explicit about it anyway: 
(def -last-id (atom 1))

(defn get-alias
  ([]
   (get-alias :alias))
  ([k]
   (keyword (str (name k) "_" (swap! -last-id (fn [id]
                                                (if (= Long/MAX_VALUE)
                                                  1
                                                  (inc id))))))))
#2021-08-0117:10p-himikMakes sense! Especially given that it shouldn't happen at all in a realistic scenario.#2021-08-0518:56greglookI feel like I‚Äôm missing something obvious; how would I format an = clause inside of a function call? The approach I expected to work doesn‚Äôt do the right thing: 
=> (sql/format (sql/call :nullif [:= :id "dsr-000"] false))
["nullif((=, id, ?), FALSE)" "dsr-000"]
#2021-08-0518:57seancorfield@greg316 HoneySQL v1 or v2?#2021-08-0518:58greglookgood question, looks like [honeysql "1.0.461"]#2021-08-0518:58seancorfieldOn v2: 
dev=> (sql/format-expr (sql/call :nullif [:= :id "dsr-000"] false))
["NULLIF(id = ?, FALSE)" "dsr-000"]
(sorry, didn't paste the right thing)#2021-08-0518:59seancorfield(I'm not sure if you can format expressions in v1 -- you can't in v2, you must use format-expr -- but if you format a statement that includes your expression you should do better)#2021-08-0519:00greglookhas the same effect in a full expression: 
=> (sql/format (sql/build :update :foos :set {:is_default (sql/call :nullif [:= :id "dsr-000"] false)}))
["UPDATE foos SET is_default = nullif((=, id, ?), FALSE)" "dsr-000"]
#2021-08-0519:01seancorfieldv1 had some strange behavior in some places with embedded expressions...#2021-08-0519:01greglookhoping I don‚Äôt have to fall back to making it a raw string üòÖ#2021-08-0519:02seancorfieldv2: (there's no build function because it really didn't do much) 
dev=> (sql/format {:update :foos :set {:is_default (sql/call :nullif [:= :id "dsr-000"] false)}})
["UPDATE foos SET is_default = NULLIF(id = ?, FALSE)" "dsr-000"]
#2021-08-0519:03greglookunfortunately I don‚Äôt think upgrading the whole app to v2 is tractable right now, but I‚Äôll put it on our backlog - does look like a nicer API#2021-08-0519:05seancorfieldYou can run v1 and v2 side-by-side and migrate on a query-by-query basis.#2021-08-0519:05seancorfieldDifferent library names and different namespaces.#2021-08-0519:05seancorfieldWe're running both at work and slowly migrating from v1 to v2.#2021-08-0602:22john-shafferAdded clojure-mode, syntax highlighting, and permalinks to https://www.john-shaffer.com/honeysql/#2021-08-0602:27john-shaffere.g., https://www.john-shaffer.com/honeysql/?q=%7B%3Aupdate%20%3Afoos%0A%20%3Aset%20%7B%3Ais-default%20%5B%3Anullif%20%5B%3A%3D%20%3Aid%20%22dsr-000%22%5D%20false%5D%7D%7D&amp;opt=%7B%3Apretty%20true%7D#2021-08-0602:30john-shafferI'd like to add multiple versions in a dropdown (once it's relevant), so the permalinks will stay perma#2021-08-0603:59seancorfield@jshaffer2112 Is this something you're planning to keep online and maintain now?
