I wanted to say thank you @seancorfield for making this possible with the good decisions of honeysql v2. Much appreciated!#2022-07-2909:26seancorfieldIs the migration from 1.x to 2.x something you might write up as a blog post or something?#2022-07-2910:40orestisIt was rather boring to be honest! The best kind of migration. #2022-07-2910:42orestisWe introduced the new library, decreed that no more new v1 code, and no changes to v1 code (if you want to change, rewrite to v2 first). #2022-07-2910:43orestisThe new namespace was critical to be able to do it. If it was an in-place update, we wouldn't do it. #2022-07-2915:59seancorfieldThat sounds like how we're doing our migration too üôÇ#2022-07-2923:08seancorfieldI thinking about https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/413 and wondered how many people are using the :checking option already? I'm considering adding checks to :delete, :delete-from, and :update to throw an exception if there is no :where clause present or the :where conditions are empty -- if :checking :strict (or perhaps :checking :basic). Are there valid scenarios for these three statements that do not delete/update all rows but also do not have WHERE clauses?#2022-07-3002:44seancorfieldAlthough most of this is documentation updates, the key new feature is the ability to register your own dialects. Thank you to everyone who contributed code and uncovered bugs and helped improve the documentation!#2022-07-3002:56seancorfieldFor folks who create their own dialects, register their own functions and clauses to go with those dialects -- create issues on the repo with details; send PRs. I'd love to expand the dialects and databases that HoneySQL supports out of the box!#2022-08-0204:16quan xingI want to generate dynamic sql where conditions with honeysql . Here is my code that has achieved the result I want. Is there a better or easy way to write it? 
(defn select-audit-list
  [conn {revitId :revitId
         type :type 
         pro :pro
         username :username}]
  (let [con (data.common/with-logging conn)]
    (let [
          wheresql (cond-> [:and [:= revitId :RevitID]]
                     (not (empty? type)) (conj [:in :Type type])
                     (not (empty? pro)) (conj [:in :Pro pro])
                     (not (empty? username)) (conj [:in :username username]))
          sqlmap {:select :*
                  :from :audit
                  :where wheresql}]
      sqlmap
      (sql/format sqlmap {:inline true}))))
  
(def args {
             :revitId "123"
             :type [1 2 3]
             :pro ["p1" "p2" "p3"]
             :username ["user1"]
  })
  
(select-audit-list nil args)
==> ["SELECT * FROM audit WHERE ('123' = RevitID) AND (Type IN (1, 2, 3)) AND (Pro IN ('p1', 'p2', 'p3')) AND (username IN ('user1'))"]

(select-audit-list2 nil (assoc args :username []))
==> ["SELECT * FROM audit WHERE ('123' = RevitID) AND (Type IN (1, 2, 3)) AND (Pro IN ('p1', 'p2', 'p3'))"]
#2022-08-0204:31seancorfieldUsing the where helper would make this easier since it takes care of the connectives: 
(require [honey.sql.helpers :refer [where]])
...
(cond-> (where := :revitId :RevitID)
  (seq type) (where :in :Type type)
  (seq pro) (where :in :Pro pro)
  (seq username) (where :in :username username))
Assuming you're using HoneySQL 2.x#2022-08-0204:38seancorfieldAs an example: 
user=> (let [username "test" type [1 2 3] revitId 42]                                                                                                          #_=>   (cond-> (where := revitId :RevitID)
  #_=>     (seq type) (where :in :Type type)
  #_=>     (seq username) (where := username :username)
  #_=>     :and (select :*)                                                                                                                                    #_=>     :then (from :table)
  #_=>     :format (sql/format)))
["SELECT * FROM table WHERE (? = RevitID) AND (Type IN (?, ?, ?)) AND (? = username)" 42 1 2 3 "test"]
user=>
(I know that's not quite the data you have but it should give you an idea of what I'm suggesting)#2022-08-0204:39seancorfieldNote, in particular, that (seq foo) is more idiomatic than (not (empty? foo)) per the empty? docstring: 
clojure.core/empty?
([coll])
  Returns true if coll has no items - same as (not (seq coll)).
  Please use the idiom (seq x) rather than (not (empty? x))
#2022-08-0206:09quan xingThank you very much @U04V70XH6#2022-08-0206:06slipsetFYI. We‚Äôve built some fns on top of honey to make stuff a bit more fluent and saves us from runtime errors: 
(def none [:= true false])

(def all [:= true true])

(defn in
  [column-name values]
  (if (seq values)
    [:in column-name (set values)]
    none))

(defn and [& clauses]
  (into [:and] (seq clauses)))

(defn or [& clauses]
  (into [:or] (seq clauses)))

(defn lift [x]
  [:lift x])
#2022-08-0206:13Cora (she/her)now that's interesting#2022-08-0206:14Cora (she/her)the in bit especially#2022-08-0206:17Cora (she/her)filtering of nil clauses would be useful, so you could go (and (when (seq type) (in :Type type)) (when (seq pro) (in :Pro pro)))#2022-08-0206:22Cora (she/her)
(defmacro in-when
  [condition column-name values]
  `(when ~condition
     [:in ~column-name ~values]))
#2022-08-0206:26Cora (she/her)
(defn and [& clauses]
  (let [c (remove nil? clauses)]
    (when (seq c)
      (if (second c)
        (into [:and] (seq c))
        (first c)))))
#2022-08-0206:26Cora (she/her)you could do the same with or#2022-08-0206:32slipsetThe and and or are nice in so far that you can write (pq/and foo bar baz) but, it‚Äôs a bit sucky in this situation (apply pq/and (map lol xs))#2022-08-0206:33slipsetThe reason for lift is so that you can (update foo :myjsonprop lift)#2022-08-0213:24ts1503Hello guys. How can I use :drop-table clause with table names such as user (reserved names) I‚Äôm trying these things (sql/format {:drop-table "foo"}) => ["DROP TABLE FOO"] (sql/format {:drop-table :foo}) => ["DROP TABLE foo"] and it doesn‚Äôt work#2022-08-0215:10seancorfieldCheck the docs for the :quoted option. You can also select the :dialect to get the quoting store you want for your database.#2022-08-0220:48ts1503that helps. thanks a lot#2022-08-0213:25ts1503(sql/format {:create-table "foo"}) does work indeed => ["CREATE TABLE \"foo\""]#2022-08-0215:02Cora (she/her)wanted to run some functions by you to see if you're interested in something like this in honeysql. putting it in this thread#2022-08-0215:03Cora (she/her)#2022-08-0216:31Cora (she/her)they're rather a lot but if you have multiple queries and need to merge their concerns this gets you there. I'm not a huge fan but it ended up being something we needed. it perhaps could be written better#2022-08-0316:25seancorfieldLooks interesting but I have a couple of concerns: a) it assumes there is a helper for every clause -- which isn't true out of the box b) it won't work for any clauses registered by users c) does ns-publics and resolve work in ClojureScript?#2022-08-0316:26Cora (she/her)ahhh ok good call. never mind!#2022-08-0316:36Cora (she/her)I'm sure there would be a way to handle this well, but maybe it's not a good call overall#2022-08-0316:37seancorfieldI recommend always using the helpers to builder queries and just keep threading stuff together instead of building separate pieces and trying to merge them after the fact.#2022-08-0316:37Cora (she/her)that ship has sailed a bit, for a number of reasons, but mostly my colleagues don't like to use the helpers ¬Ø\(„ÉÑ)/¬Ø#2022-08-0316:39seancorfieldHmm, maybe there's a lesson to be had in that then? üòâ#2022-08-0316:43Cora (she/her)well, sure, I agree#2022-08-0315:18raymcdermottI would like to use honeysql to connect to Postgres using nbb, so via ClojureScript - has anyone done this yet?#2022-08-0315:19borkdudehoneysql is only for producing SQL queries, it does not make connections#2022-08-0315:20borkdudeI have an example here for honeysql + sqlite: https://github.com/babashka/nbb/blob/main/examples/sqlite/honeysql.cljs#2022-08-0315:20borkdudeIt should be similar for postgres#2022-08-0315:21borkdudehttps://node-postgres.com/#2022-08-0315:23raymcdermottI know but come on man, I just want to cut n paste :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:#2022-08-0315:23raymcdermottI'll work it out#2022-08-0315:25borkdudeI notice the syntax expected by this pg lib is $1 instead of ? what honeysql uses.#2022-08-0315:25raymcdermottsearching around GH I see that this lib has done it before#2022-08-0315:26raymcdermotthttps://github.com/talented0312/jobsite/blob/3bf03eda55b40c016e613ad184b415d2623216f2/src/district/server/async_db.cljs#2022-08-0315:26raymcdermottso I'll take it from there#2022-08-0316:09seancorfieldYeah, the Node PG lib doesn't support regular ? placeholders -- and HoneySQL does not produce the numbered parameters. There's a ticket in the backlog for HoneySQL but it turns out to be extremely tricky with the current machinery -- although I have some ideas about making it work. HoneySQL v1 used to support the numbered parameters but almost no one was using it and since it was really handled "under the hood" it didn't matter much.#2022-08-0316:10borkdudeI wonder how that async_db.cljs example works then#2022-08-0316:29seancorfieldIt uses HoneySQL v1 not v2. And it uses the PG extensions library for HoneySQL v1.#2022-08-0316:29borkdudeoh right#2022-08-0316:29borkdudePerhaps it's not difficult to hack around this: replace each ? with a $ + an incremental number#2022-08-0316:33seancorfieldIn SQL ?? is the escaped version of a ? when you don't want a placeholder and PG has (at least) ~three~ four operators that include a ?#2022-08-0316:34seancorfieldSo you can "hack around" it for simple cases if you know what your SQL is going to contain üôÇ#2022-08-0316:34borkdudehehe yeah...#2022-08-0316:36seancorfieldHave I said lately just how much I dislike SQL? And how much I particularly like PostgreSQL's extensions to SQL? üòÜ#2022-08-0316:36borkdudeI heard your podcast :)#2022-08-0316:37seancorfieldI should go listen to myself rant... maybe...#2022-08-0319:56raymcdermottare you suggesting that it's not recommended @U04V70XH6?#2022-08-0319:56raymcdermottmy uses cases are pretty simple tbh#2022-08-0319:56raymcdermottso strings are likely good enough#2022-08-0320:28borkdude@U04V5V0V4 Perhaps this also works: 
{:select :$1 :from :$2}
#2022-08-0320:28borkdude
{:select :$1 :from :$2 :where [[:= :x :$3]]}
#2022-08-0320:29borkdudeand then you're own your own for passing those arguments in the right order#2022-08-0320:32seancorfieldMaybe I'll try to set aside a day or two to add support for it üòû I sort of know how to go about it (the complication is that you can't guarantee formatting actually happens strictly left-to-right -- so the actual parameters potentially need to be reordered at the end to match the order the $n were actually embedded in the final string).#2022-08-0320:33borkdudeSo is this $n syntax coming from the library or is it actually a postgres syntax?#2022-08-0320:34seancorfieldPostgreSQL supports both ? in SQL strings and $n -- presumably at the JDBC driver level.#2022-08-0320:35seancorfield"all" JDBC drivers support ?. But not all PG drivers across all platforms support ?.#2022-08-0320:35borkdudeso JDBC does the ? => $n translation?#2022-08-0320:36seancorfieldI'm not sure what you mean by "translation" there.#2022-08-0320:36seancorfieldFor JDBC, generally you provide a SQL string, with a ? placeholder in the string for each parameter for the statement, in the same matching order.#2022-08-0320:37borkdudeif postgres expects $n syntax, but JDBC supports writing ?, does JDBC driver translate this before passing it to PG? Or do drivers convert the string + arguments into something else at the driver level?#2022-08-0320:37seancorfieldPG's driver supports ? for JDBC.#2022-08-0320:38seancorfieldI don't know that drivers parse the SQL string (I find that extremely unlikely but, hey, databases and drivers are weird). The generic JDBC docs talk about using ?.#2022-08-0320:39seancorfieldUnder the hood, how each JDBC driver talks to its specific database tends to be proprietary. So "anything" could be happening there.#2022-08-0320:39borkdudeAfter skimming a little bit, my assumption now is that PG only supports the $n syntax natively and JDBC drivers do the ? to $n translation to offer a uniform interface#2022-08-0320:40seancorfieldSo it's entirely possible that PG's underlying ... yeah, I was just about to say that and that's probably why the PG node driver doesn't bother and just forces users to put $n in their SQL strings.#2022-08-0320:41seancorfieldHoneySQL currently "assumes" JDBC even tho' it is technically a clj/s library.#2022-08-0405:41raymcdermottDoes JavaScript have JDBC? ü•¥#2022-08-0521:38alpoxLooks like the go-to querybuilder of the node-universe (KnexJS) does in its postgres adapter a simple regex replace: https://github.com/knex/knex/blob/master/lib/dialects/postgres/index.js#L140#2022-08-0522:01seancorfieldAnd what of SQL like this? "SELECT ' ? ' AS answer" To be fair, Apache Derby and HSQLDB both throw exceptions trying to parse this but all the other DBs/drivers I test next.jdbc against are happy with this SQL.#2022-08-0522:04borkdudealso the sqlite go library seemed to accept the ? output from honeysql#2022-08-0707:53namenuI'm using honeysql with mysql. every now and then I get fatal runtime errors caused by misused 'where in' form. the arguments passed into in must not empty, but in reality, this check easily be omitted. Whenever this happens, I terribly miss the non-empty type. I wonder how others handle this case?#2022-08-0708:04namenuidea: what if we replace where-in with logical false when the argument is empty?#2022-08-0718:28seancorfieldSince it's impossible to know whether this is a programming error or intended to be either a logical false or a logical true, there's :checking so you can get an exception from HoneySQL itself.#2022-08-0802:18namenubut logically A ‚äÇ ‚àÖ is always ‚àÖ , so isn't that irrelevant to the programmer's intent?#2022-08-0803:14seancorfieldI can construct a SQL statement with a join over an IN condition that will likely give you an "unexpected" result if IN () produced false -- so you're much safer getting an exception.#2022-08-0912:42sheluchinIs there any way to convert raw SQL to HoneySQL expressions?#2022-08-0918:48seancorfieldSomeone would have to write a full SQL parser. That's a lot of work (and very hard).#2022-08-0918:58sheluchinFair enough. Thought I'd ask just in case. Some changes are just so easy to make in DB GUI - it would make to a nice workflow to be able to copy stuff from the transaction log and into your clj project as HoneySQL. Thanks @U04V70XH6.#2022-08-0918:59seancorfieldIt's been asked several times over the years -- but no one is willing to put in the time and effort to write such a thing üôÇ#2022-08-0919:00sheluchinAnd that's understandable, but it would sure be cool üôÇ#2022-08-1017:35krydosThere is https://github.com/camsaul/sqlhoney by @U42REFCKA It‚Äôs unable to parse complex queries but it‚Äôs a good base for that special someone who‚Äôs willing to spend time on this. It also has the best name for such kind of tool indeed#2022-08-1017:36sheluchin@U03G0UUUD8E thanks for the link. That name is a home run, for sure.#2022-08-1017:37Cam SaulIt's definitely not ready for prime time, more of a proof of concept than anything else. I do plan on fleshing it out at some point in the next year or so. SQL parsing is something we want to add to Metabase so if anything I'll need to do it as part of my day job #2022-08-1017:38Cam SaulIn the meantime tho you should be able to build on it to do what you need #2022-08-1601:17quan xinghow can I generate replace into table valeus use honeysql#2022-08-1602:07seancorfieldThere's currently no support for that. I hadn't even heard of it. Can you provide a link to some docs for what the actual syntax should be?#2022-08-1703:44quan xinghttps://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/replace.html the old row is deleted before the new row is inserted#2022-08-1704:10seancorfieldCreate an issue on GitHub with that link and I'll take a look. Maybe there's similar equivalent things in other databases.#2022-08-1804:18seancorfieldThanks for the issue @U025AG2H55F - I'll try to take a look this weekend.#2022-08-2318:34steven kentHi, in honeysql 1.0.461, does :except get converted to minus in an Oracle 18 context? Thank you#2022-08-2319:15seancorfieldHoneySQL 1.x knows nothing about dialects so if it supports :except at all it would always produce EXCEPT -- but I don't think it supports that?#2022-08-2319:17seancorfieldAh, yeah, looks like :except support was added in 0.9.10 back in March 2020. And it's a pretty simple formatter: 
(defmethod format-clause :except [[_ maps] _]
  (binding [*subquery?* false]
    (string/join " EXCEPT " (map to-sql maps))))
#2022-08-2319:34steven kentThanks @U04V70XH6#2022-08-2319:34seancorfieldAre you getting some strange behavior?#2022-08-2320:04steven kentNo sir, this was just a question that came up. I looked at this line, trying to answer it https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/v1/src/honeysql/helpers.cljc#L381 but apparently that isn't the same place you pointed out#2022-08-2322:58seancorfieldAh, yes, the build-clause stuff is how the helpers were handled in v1, and they build a data structure -- nothing more -- which is then turned into SQL via format-clause which is what I linked to.#2022-08-2408:54olyOn the of chance anyone has some ideas, I was curious if honey would work with klipse for interactive snippets, I can import the library but running a simple example fails with this.

  (sqlh/from :company)
  (sqlh/where [:= :id 1]))

[:pre.cm-s-rdark.bg-near-black.silver.pa2.hljs.roboto.overflow-auto.klipse
                                               {:data-external-libs ""} content]
So basically you add the data-external-libs as an attribute to include it then you just require honey as usual so a block like this in side the pre tag above. 
(ns core.demo
  (:require
   [honey.sql :as sql]
   [honey.sql.helpers :as sqlh]))

(-> (sqlh/select :*)
    (sqlh/from :company)
    (sqlh/where [:= :id 1]))
Docs mention data external libs below. https://github.com/viebel/klipse/blob/master/README.md#clojure-only-1#2022-08-2604:12seancorfieldI see you asked in the #klipse channel in early July and didn't get an answer to that? HoneySQL definitely works in regular ClojureScript environments so I suspect this is something to do with Klipse perhaps getting confused by the :refer-clojure :exclude stuff? You'll have to push harder there for an answer I think. Perhaps you can create a tiny repro using a fresh GH repro and a ns that excludes a core function and then redefines it and see what Klipse does?#2022-08-2613:19oliver marksyeah I thought that could be the, case one of those things I looked into and got around to taking another stab, but like to ask around in case any oe has tried previously before spending to much time on the issue.#2022-08-2408:56olyI noticed in the code honey seems to have it's own into function so I wonder if its related to that#2022-08-3012:50sheluchinIs it possible to generate PG's lateral joins? I'm trying to translate this to honeysql helper calls: 
SELECT *
FROM tags t
JOIN LATERAL (
  SELECT m.*
  FROM movies m
  WHERE m.tag_id = t.id
  ORDER BY m.created_at DESC
  FETCH FIRST 2 ROWS ONLY
) e1 ON true
#2022-08-3012:52sheluchinClosest I got is: 
(-> (hh/select :*)
      (hh/from [:tags :t])
      (hh/join
        (hh/lateral (-> (hh/select :m.*)
                        (hh/from [:movies :m])
                        (hh/where [:= :m.tag-id :t.id])
                        (hh/order-by [:m.created-at :desc])
                        (hh/fetch 10)))
       true)))
select
	*
from
	tags as t
inner join lateral as (
	select
		m.*
	from
		movies as m
	where
		m.tag_id = t.id
	order by
		m.created_at desc 
    fetch first 10 rows only)
on true
#2022-08-3015:25seancorfieldI suspect you need [ .. ] around the hh/lateral call.#2022-08-3015:25seancorfield(because of what the arguments to hh/join expect)#2022-08-3015:28seancorfield
user=> (-> (hh/select :*)
  #_=>       (hh/from [:tags :t])
  #_=>       (hh/join
  #_=>         [(hh/lateral (-> (hh/select :m.*)
  #_=>                         (hh/from [:movies :m])
  #_=>                         (hh/where [:= :m.tag-id :t.id])
  #_=>                         (hh/order-by [:m.created-at :desc])
  #_=>                         (hh/fetch 10)))]
  #_=>        true)
  #_=>     (sql/format))
["SELECT * FROM tags AS t INNER JOIN LATERAL (SELECT m.* FROM movies AS m WHERE m.tag_id = t.id ORDER BY m.created_at DESC FETCH FIRST ? ROWS ONLY) ON TRUE" 10]
#2022-08-3015:30sheluchinAh, I was close üôÇ Thanks @U04V70XH6. Now to translate this simplified example to my real query.#2022-08-3015:30seancorfieldThe example in the reference docs shows the raw data structure needed: 
user=> (sql/format {:select [:foo.id [:x.id :x_id] :x.value]
                    :cross-join [[[:lateral
                                   [:jsonb_to_recordset :foo.json_value]]
                                  [[:raw "x(id text, value jsonb)"]]]]
                    :from [:foo]})
["SELECT foo.id, x.id AS x_id, x.value FROM foo CROSS JOIN LATERAL JSONB_TO_RECORDSET(foo.json_value) x(id text, value jsonb)"]
Note the nested [ .. ] since :lateral is essentially a function call#2022-08-3015:31sheluchinYes, I was looking at that and the unit tests but made an error in the translation.#2022-08-3015:32sheluchinBTW, is there some way to get format to return the SQL string with linebreaks/formatting? Not a huge trouble to paste it to the GUI and format it there, but it would be convenient to skip that step.#2022-08-3015:33seancorfieldThere's a pretty print option -- see the docs.#2022-08-3015:34sheluchinGot it. Thank you.#2022-09-0417:44seancorfieldA potentially important security update (#422), quite a few language extensions, improved extensibility (for inlining values), improved checking for "unusual" expressions.#2022-09-0715:41MaxIs there a way to set the honeysql checking mode globally you can for the dialect and quoting options?#2022-09-0717:59seancorfieldNot currently. Feel free to create a GH issue about it!#2022-09-0718:06MaxFiled! https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/427#2022-09-0719:19fabraohello all, how do I convert this to helper? 
{:with [[:ce {:insert-into  ...}
to:
(sqlh/with 
       (sqlh/insert-into ...)) ?
#2022-09-0719:37seancorfieldAre you looking for this result? 
user=> (-> (with [:ce (insert-into :table)]) (sql/format))
["WITH ce AS (INSERT INTO table)"]
user=>
#2022-09-0719:38fabraothank you Sean, I'll try that#2022-09-0719:38fabraowhat is that [:ce stuff?#2022-09-0720:37seancorfieldI copied it from your code @U0YJJPFRA 
{:with [[:ce {:insert-into  ...}
The :with clause takes a sequence of pairs as a value. The helper takes any number of pairs. That's typically how all helpers work.#2022-09-0720:39fabraooh ok. It's information for with and not an operator, I got it, thank you again#2022-09-0720:41seancorfieldIt's like this: 
user=> (-> (select :a [:b :c] [[:+ :d :e] :f]) (from :table) (sql/format))
["SELECT a, b AS c, d + e AS f FROM table"]
user=>
#2022-09-0720:41seancorfieldCompare with the raw data structure: 
user=> (-> (select :a [:b :c] [[:+ :d :e] :f]) (from :table))
{:select [:a [:b :c] [[:+ :d :e] :f]], :from [:table]}
user=>
#2022-09-0720:42fabraoyes, undertood#2022-09-1421:53mattlydoes anyone know if there‚Äôs been much prior art for helpers on the frame clause of a postgresql window function? I‚Äôm talking about the part such as ROWS BETWEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND 1 FOLLOWING EXCLUDING CURRENT ROW#2022-09-1422:16seancorfieldI don't know of anything. I don't know how much folks are using HoneySQL for window stuff at all right now...#2022-09-1422:16mattlythanks;#2022-09-1422:18mattlyI‚Äôve been using honeysql a lot as part of prototyping out a larger query engine, it‚Äôs been great for that#2022-09-1422:18mattlyI may have to blaze this trail#2022-09-1422:19seancorfieldI'm happy to add support into the core if you create a GH issue with details of the syntax in context and a link to the PG docs for it.#2022-09-1908:24ts1503Hello guys! Is it possible to use lower case table names when constructing create-table query? For example I have a table in my Postgres - "user" quoted, so in all my queries I should use a lover case name And I‚Äôm trying to do something like this 
(sql/format {:create-table :table
             :with-columns [[:user :uuid [:references :user]]]}
            {:quoted true})
which gives me ["CREATE TABLE \"table\" (\"user\" \"UUID\" REFERENCES \"USER\")"] string with upper case "USER" as a table name. But Postgres doesn‚Äôt recognize it as an existing table user. and I see that HoneySQL is calling upper-case function for all columns here.#2022-09-1922:34seancorfieldThere's no real good solution right now but it's something I'm looking at because the logic around DDL creation and casing is... a bit of a hack. If you're on a recent version of HoneySQL, you could try [:references :'user] which should treat user as something literal but will probably not quote the name.#2022-09-1922:36seancorfieldAs I suspected, using the "literal name" escape hatch also (deliberately) avoids quoting: 
user=> (sql/format {:create-table :table
             :with-columns [[:user :uuid [:references :'user]]]}
            {:quoted true})
["CREATE TABLE \"table\" (\"user\" \"UUID\" REFERENCES user)"]
user=>
#2022-09-2010:24ts1503Thanks, but I think Postgres wouldn‚Äôt accept that as user is a reserved keyword and have to be quoted#2022-09-2010:25ts1503I ended up with some custom clause for now 
(defn format-raw-update [_ x]
  [(str "UPDATE " (first (sql/format-expr [:inline x])))])


(sql/register-clause! :update-raw format-raw-update :update)
#2022-09-2010:28ts1503seems a little bit hacky but it works. Will wait for a proper solution. :thumbsup:#2022-09-1908:24ts1503Is there a way to tell HoneySQL to leave the column name in lower case?#2022-09-2218:05vonadzAm I missing something about how to use the ->> json operator for postgresql? ["SELECT col1, col2 AS alias, report_summary ->> clicks FROM table"]
user=>

should be 
[[:->> :report_summary "clicks"]]

(honey.sql/register-clause! :create-temp-table (fn [_ args]
                                                 [(str "CREATE TEMP TABLE " (name args) " AS")])
                            :select)
#2022-09-3011:30slipsetNext question: I want to duplicate some rows in a table while changing one column. I don‚Äôt want to enumerate all the columns, so I‚Äôve come up with this: 
CREATE TEMP TABLE tmp AS (select * from foo where lol = 42);
UPDATE tmp SET lol = 43;
INSERT INTO foo (SELECT * from tmp);
DROP TABLE tmp;
(I‚Äôd be happy to get recommendations for better solutions) So these seem to be four separate sql statements, which means I need to call honey/format on a vector containing these, as my honey atm looks like: 
(let [tmp-table (gensym)]
    [(-> {:create-temp-table (keyword tmp-table)}
         (hh/select :*)
         (hh/from (keyword "foo")
         (hh/where [:= :lol 42))
     (-> (hh/update (keyword tmp-table))
         (hh/set {:lol 43}))
     (-> (hh/insert-into [(keyword "foo")
                          (-> (hh/select :*)
                              (hh/from (keyword tmp-table)))]))
     (hh/drop-table tmp-table)]))
And then, somewhere else, I‚Äôd need: (map honey/format xs) Is this the approach or am I missing somehting?#2022-09-3012:42slipsetOh, my colleague was smarter than me: (hh/create-table-as :temp (keyword tmp-table)) gives me a temp table üôÇ#2022-09-3017:47seancorfieldYeah, I should probably call that out in the docs that all the :create* operations accept one or more keywords and just make SQL out of them üôÇ#2022-09-3017:48seancorfield
user=> (sql/format (-> (create-table-as :fee :fie :foe :fum) (select :*) (from :bar)))
["CREATE FEE FIE FOE TABLE fum AS SELECT * FROM bar"]
user=>

    (hh/with-columns
      [[:did :uuid [:default [:gen_random_uuid]]]
       [:foo-id :varchar [:not nil]]
       [[:primary-key :did :foo-id]]
       [[:foreign-key :foo-id]
        [:references :foo]
        [:on-delete :cascade]]]))

CREATE TABLE order_items (
    product_no integer REFERENCES products ON DELETE RESTRICT,
    order_id integer REFERENCES orders ON DELETE CASCADE,
    quantity integer,
    PRIMARY KEY (product_no, order_id)
);
#2022-10-1116:31seancorfieldCan you create a GH issue with that example so I can think about it? DDL is horribly non-regular so trying to figure out DSL syntax for it is tricky at times. I'm not sure right now what the best solution for this case is -- I'll have to look at how various databases handle this.#2022-10-1116:36sheluchinThanks, @U04V70XH6. I'll have that issue up sometime soon. I was asking in here just in case I missed it. Grepping through the project I saw there was some mention of added support for CREATE TABLE / CASCADE a while ago, but couldn't find supporting examples to match my target: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/dda3aa017e62b54863d302252c574fabf687543c/CHANGELOG.md?plain=1#L139-L141#2022-10-1116:39seancorfieldDROP .. CASCADE is supported, as I recall, but that change entry refers to the top-level DSL clauses, not columns within CREATE TABLE.#2022-10-1512:09sheluchinhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/437 Just leaving the link to the issue here for reference.#2022-10-2414:50hifumi123Recently I had to deal with DDLs as well. In particular clauses like ON DELETE SET NULL ON UPDATE CASCADE. I wasn't able to get this outputted with e.g. [:on-delete :set nil], but as a temporary workaround you can use individual keywords. That is, you can use :on :delete :set nil :on :update :cascade for the time being. This is what I plan to do until HoneySQL improves support for this kind of syntax#2022-10-1721:19MaxIs there a way to do DELETE FROM ? CASCADE in honeysql?#2022-10-1723:42seancorfieldNo. Feel free to open a GH issue for it, with links to the database documentation for the syntax that shows what is possible (and then I have to determine whether this portable across multiple databases etc).#2022-10-1723:54MaxFiled: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/438#2022-10-1723:57seancorfieldNot delete from? üôÇ#2022-10-1723:57Maxfacepalm typo, delete doesn‚Äôt support cascade. Just truncate#2022-10-1723:58MaxThat should teach me to ask questions at 5pm#2022-10-2106:22–î–µ–Ω–∏—Å –ù–∏–±–∞–µ–≤Hello. Is there any way to add filter to windos function? Something like:

                {:partition-by [:p]

#2022-10-2118:41seancorfieldCreate a GH issue and I'll take a look at adding support for that.#2022-10-2113:21ivanaHello! format returns ["FROM heron.heron_file hf WHERE hf.external_file_id = ?" 33] May I get just raw string, i.e. "FROM heron.heron_file hf WHERE hf.external_file_id = 33" somehow, with already substituted all the ? by param values?#2022-10-2114:03Pragyan TripathiYou need to pass options parameter :inline true#2022-10-2114:03ivanaThanks alot!#2022-10-2118:43seancorfieldJust be aware of security issues here -- only use :inline true when you are guaranteed that all parameters are under your control and are validated! If you want to inline just one known-safe value, wrap it in [:inline 33] (and then you don't need :inline true as an option). The docs have warnings about security and :inline.#2022-10-2121:15ivanaThanks, didn't know. Anyway I tried to solve some problems with version 1 and tried to write my own helpers & wrappers for it. But finally I found, yhat version 2 works also with some bugs, but much better than 1 and may be extended in a custom way without inlining parameters.#2022-10-2121:57seancorfield@U0A6H3MFT The docs are also substantially better for v2 üôÇ#2022-10-2405:35hifumi123~How would one express ~ EDIT: Never mind, it works as intended.
