I can I use column = ANY <array expression> with Honey? https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/functions-comparisons.html#id-1.5.8.30.16. Do I need to fall back on :raw ? [:= column-name [:ANY (into-array String values)]] seems to work#2022-10-2610:35Pragyan TripathiHow can I create honeysql equivalent for: 
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "Blog" (
    "id" SERIAL NOT NULL,
    "title" TEXT NOT NULL,
    "comments" TEXT[] DEFAULT ARRAY['hello', 'world']::TEXT[],

    CONSTRAINT "blog_pkey" PRIMARY KEY ("id")
);
I am using following: 
{:create-table [:blog :if-not-exists],
 :with-columns
 [[:id :uuid [:not nil]]
  [:comments
   [:raw "text[]"]
   [:default [:raw "ARRAY[hello, world]::text[]"]]]
  [[:constraint :blog_pkey] [:primary-key :id]]]}
But this results in 
["CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS blog (id UUID NOT NULL, comments TEXT[] DEFAULT ARRAY[HELLO, WORLD]::TEXT[], CONSTRAINT blog_pkey PRIMARY KEY(ID))"]
Cases in the default values are incorrect. Is there a way I can do it without using :raw operator.#2022-10-2619:47seancorfieldThere's a GH issue open that mentions this https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/386 -- DDL support is very tricky to get right since it is so vendor-specific and the heuristic for upper-casing parts of the declaration is too zealous at the moment. So the TL;DR: is "No, you can't do this right now" but I plan to fix it at some point.#2022-10-2703:51Pragyan TripathiGot it. Thanks. Are there ideas about how you are planning to solve it? I can try to implement it for my use case.#2022-10-2704:16seancorfieldI don't know yet. DDL is horribly inconsistent and doesn't follow the "normal" rules of SQL syntax.#2022-10-2704:17seancorfieldThere are good reasons why HoneySQL v1 pretty much didn't touch DDL at all üôÇ#2022-10-2713:42ts1503Hey @U02JRAM6CBA I ended up with custom clause like this one#2022-10-2713:43ts1503last screenshot didn‚Äôt capture all code#2022-10-2800:48Pragyan TripathiThis is great. WIll give adding custom-clause a try.#2022-10-2723:08Jungwoo KimHello! Does honeysql support *&lt;<https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/comparison-operators.html#operator_equal-to%7C&lt;=&gt;&gt;*(null-safe> operator) in mysql? I‚Äôve checked out <https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/doc/operator-reference.md|here>. Is there any workaround instead of `:raw`?#2022-10-2723:30seancorfieldIt's not built-in but that example is specifically given in both the README https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.3.928/doc/readme#extensibility and Extending HoneySQL https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.3.928/doc/extending-honeysql#registering-a-new-operator#2022-10-2723:30seancorfieldFeel free to create a GH issue so it gets registered by default when the :mysql dialect is selected.#2022-10-2723:31seancorfield(I've used MySQL for over a decade and I've never encountered that operator!)#2022-10-2723:31seancorfieldMaybe it's new in 8.0? (we're still on 5.7 for... reasons...)#2022-10-2723:31hifumi123Aha, I was about to mention that it should be possible to patch into HoneySQL by using 
register-op!
I also can't say I've used <=> before, but I mostly use PostgreSQL, which probably lacks it#2022-10-2723:36Jungwoo KimThanks you all. I would try to use register op first.#2022-11-0114:35markaddlemanI‚Äôm writing a custom function to support BigQuery‚Äôs SAFE_OFFSET syntax. Normally, the function will produce a vector result like ["ARRAY[SAFE_OFFSET(?)]" idx] but when sql/format is called with :inline true, I‚Äôd like my function to return a result with arguments inlined. My stumbling block is honey.sql/*inline* is private. I don‚Äôt see another method of determining if the client wants an inline result.#2022-11-0118:49seancorfieldIf you call format-expr on the argument to safe_offset, that will take care of the inlining for you.#2022-11-0118:52markaddlemandoh - of course. Thanks#2022-11-0310:26quan xinghow can I covert string vector to honeysql like this: 
(defn sql-vec ["or",
                ["and", ["=","col_a","a"],["=","col_b",1]]
                ,
                ["and", ["=","col_d","a"],["=","col_e",1]]])

(what-fn sql-vec)
output :
 [:or
     [:and [:= :col_a "a"],[:= :col_b 1]
     [:and [:= :col_c "a"],[:= :col_d 1]]]
Is there a function that already exists#2022-11-0315:39seancorfieldHow would you tell the difference between a column or function name and an actual string value? How/why are you using strings in the first place? HoneySQL accepts symbols as well as keywords, if that's any help and lets you use lists instead of vectors in most places: '(or (and (= col_a "a") (= col_b 1)) (and (= col_d "a") (= col_e 1)))#2022-11-0316:26quan xingthank you. but I want to use a json string to define sql where condition, frontend post json where to backend. I wrote it for a long time, and it basically worked. but it felt ugly. the recursive processing of the data confused me. 
(defn first-second->key
    [[f1 f2 f3]]
    [(keyword f1) (keyword f2) f3])

  (defn reslove-exp-v
    [v]
    (if (vector? v)
      (if (every? #(not (vector? %)) v)
        (first-second->key v)
        (mapv reslove-exp-v v))
      (keyword v)))

  (defn reslove-exp
    [exp]
    (if (every? #(not (vector? %)) exp)
      (first-second->key exp)
      (mapv reslove-exp-v exp)))

  
  (reslove-exp ["=" "id" "1234"])
  ;; => [:= :id "1234"]

  (reslove-exp ["or",
                ["and", ["=","col_a","a"],["=","dff",1]]
                ,
                ["and", ["=","col_b","bb"],["=","abc",1]]])
  ;; => [:or [:and [:= :col_a "a"] [:= :dff 1]] [:and [:= :col_b "bb"] [:= :abc 1]]]
#2022-11-0316:38seancorfieldBear in mind that [:= "a" :col_x] is a perfectly valid condition too...#2022-11-0400:37quan xingok, thank you!#2022-11-1018:04orestisHaving seen systems that send ‚Äúwhere‚Äù queries to the backend, I would strongly suggest you find a different approach. Eg find your own mini-language or data structure to encode this information. #2022-11-1018:05orestisYour approach and your function can easily be circumvented to bypass all your where clauses. #2022-11-0503:42hifumi123Is there some dialect available for H2 database when building HoneySQL statements? I'm asking because I currently have to employ a workaround when referencing tables in DDLs. e.g. [[:constraint :some-constraint] [:references :table/column]] will produce CONSTRAINT some_constraint REFERENCES table.column, but H2 requires the reference to be schema.table(column), even if you are in the same schema as the table you're referencing, leading me to using workarounds like [[:constraint :some-constraint] [:references [:public.table :column]]]#2022-11-0503:44seancorfieldI'm not sure why you consider that to be a workaround?#2022-11-0503:45hifumi123hm... I guess I consider it a workaround because HoneySQL documentation seems to suggest :table/column is the "natural" way to reference table.column , rather than doing what I am currently doing. As long as this seems OK in your eyes then I'm willing to accept it üôÇ#2022-11-0503:46seancorfieldIf you need to specify the schema where would HoneySQL get that from, unless you tell it somehow? [:schema.table :column] seems like a good notation for that.#2022-11-0503:47seancorfield(and, as I keep saying over and over, DDL is so horribly DB-specific and non-regular that supporting it "fully" is... a pipe dream at best)#2022-11-0503:48hifumi123Makes sense. Thanks for the quick response btw. I was just making sure I'm using HoneySQL as intended, and I'm fine with things as they currently are#2022-11-0503:49seancorfield"as intended" implies HoneySQL is opinionated üôÇ I think, when it comes to DDL, whatever works is acceptable.#2022-11-0600:56seancorfieldIf you're a heavy user of HoneySQL for generating DDL statements, this release may impact you (but hopefully will just make your life easier!).#2022-11-0707:59slipsetIt seems to me from the examples bit of the https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-truncate.html that postgres accepts multiple tables to truncate, whereas honey does not? 
=# create table t1 (id int);
CREATE TABLE
=# create table t2 (id int);
CREATE TABLE
=# insert into t1 values (1);
INSERT 0 1
=# insert into t2 values (2);
INSERT 0 1
=# select * from t1;
 id
----
  1
(1 row)

=# select * from t2;
 id
----
  2
(1 row)

=# truncate t1, t2;
TRUNCATE TABLE
=# select * from t1;
 id
----
(0 rows)

=# select * from t2;
 id
----
(0 rows)

=#
Is this worth reporting as an issue?#2022-11-0708:23seancorfieldSure, open an issue. I was looking at this just the other day as I extended truncate to support cascade etc. Not sure what the syntax would have to be now, since a sequence argument already means "table + options", but I'll give it some thought.#2022-11-0715:26valeraukodoes honeysql (2) have some hidden state that persists across calls?#2022-11-0715:29valeraukoI'm observing super weird behavior: 
user=> (honey.sql/format
  {:replace-into :accounts
   :values [{:public-key 1 :private-key 2}]
   :returning [:*]})
ExceptionInfo These SQL clauses are unknown or have nil values: :replace-into {:replace-into :accounts}
user=> (honey.sql/format
  {:replace-into :accounts
   :values [{:public-key 1 :private-key 2}]
   :returning [:*]}
  {:dialect :mysql
   :quoted-kebab true})
ExceptionInfo These SQL clauses are unknown or have nil values: :replace-into {:replace-into :accounts}
And then suddenly... 
user=> (honey.sql/format
  {:replace-into :accounts
   :values [{:public-key 1 :private-key 2}]
   :returning [:*]}
  {:dialect :mysql
   :quoted-kebab true})
["REPLACE INTO `accounts` (`public-key`, `private-key`) VALUES (?, ?) RETURNING *" 1 2]
user=> (honey.sql/format
  {:replace-into :accounts
   :values [{:public-key 1 :private-key 2}]
   :returning [:*]})
["REPLACE INTO accounts (public_key, private_key) VALUES (?, ?) RETURNING *" 1 2]
I thought format was "just" a function but then how come it's not consistent? Does it have some state outside the function for the options?#2022-11-0715:36valeraukoOh okay digging in the source I figured it out. The first time the :mysql dialect is used it adds the clauses globally which means later calls (even if the :dialect passed to format is not :mysql) have access to it. https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/23be700b7eb74ff75096bc5c8324634a8e2b9e84/src/honey/sql.cljc#L109#2022-11-0718:11seancorfieldYeah, my feeling with that was that if you use a dialect, it's "harmless" to have any additions it makes stay in play -- if two dialects conflict, selecting back and forth between them should "correct" the formatting anyway. If you are only using one dialect, you probably should set-dialect! at startup. Specifying :dialect in a format call also turns on quoting for that call (unless you also say :quoted false).#2022-11-0801:32valeraukoYeah I can understand that. I think the element that really bugged me was that the first call with :dialect :mysql would fail#2022-11-0801:39seancorfieldWith? Or without?#2022-11-0801:40valeraukoIn the example above, it'd fail the first call with :dialect#2022-11-0801:41seancorfieldOh, that's definitely a bug - can you open an issue? I'm on my phone.#2022-11-0801:41valeraukoWill do#2022-11-0801:46valeraukohttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/441#2022-11-1515:24emccueDoes anyone remember how to get around postgres parameter limits with :in ? My brain is going "PGArray" but im only 30% confident about that (and trying it at the repl yields no success)#2022-11-1607:25orestisHm, we have a utility function 
(defn cast-ids [ids]
  [:cast [:lift (mapv str ids)]
   [:raw "mongo_id[]"]])
Where the interesting thing is the :lift that passes in the whole CLJ vector as a single parameter, which somewhere down the stack is converted in a PG array#2022-11-1615:33emccueWhat does :lift do?#2022-11-1615:34emccueand q. specific to your example - what is a mongo_id[]? do you have a custom type in postgres?#2022-11-1616:18orestisRe mongo_id, yes, it‚Äôs a custom type - so we cast to an array of those. #2022-11-1616:20orestis:lift will, IIRC, instruct honey sql to treat the argument as a single value and to not infer anything from the values type - it‚Äôs a honey sql2 thing. #2022-11-1616:51orestishttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/doc/special-syntax.md#2022-11-1616:51orestisI think that array would better than lift #2022-11-1617:49emccuei might be on honeysql 1...#2022-11-1620:01orestisAh, the docs say that honeysql has ‚Äúvalue‚Äù for something equivalent - we upgraded all of our code to honeysql2 a couple of months back. #2022-11-1607:25orestisAnother instance: 
{:select [:*]
   :from [:statuses]
   :where [[:= :title [:any [:lift (into-array status-titles)]]]]}
#2022-11-1607:26orestisWe don't really use :in in many places @emccue#2022-11-1715:17Ben LiebermanFirst time using HoneySQL this morning and this error is a bit confusing to me: 
Execution error (ExceptionInfo) at honey.sql/format-values (sql.cljc:794).
; :values expects sequences or maps
I worked around it by calling (into []) , but I would like to understand what I'm doing wrong. 
(-> (h/insert-into :posts) 
                    (h/values
                     (->Post 1 "testing a new post" (LocalDateTime/now) 1)) 
                    sql/format)
What is my Post record instance here if not a map?#2022-11-1715:45seancorfieldYou are trying to pass a single hash map. :values expects a sequence of hash maps (or a sequence of column values -- a sequence of sequences).#2022-11-1715:51seancorfieldLooking at it, I can see how many folks would expect to be able to pass one or more hash maps to the values helper and for it to "do the right thing"... so I'll create a ticket for that.#2022-11-1715:53Ben LiebermanThanks, Sean. I think the "or" is what put me off the scent there.#2022-11-1715:53seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/442#2022-11-1715:55seancorfieldThe problem is that :values sees [(map-entry ..) (map-entry ..) (map-entry ..)] and says "Hey, I'm expecting sequences or maps but I got a MapEntry!"#2022-11-1715:55seancorfieldI can make the error message better as well üôÇ#2022-11-1715:56seancorfieldI'm changing it to 
:values expects a sequence of rows (maps) or column values (sequences)
#2022-11-1716:11seancorfieldFWIW, the docstring of values says: 
Accepts a single argument: a collection of row values.
  Each row value can be either a sequence of column values
  or a hash map of column name/column value pairs.
I can fairly easily make it take one or more hash maps or two or more "sequence of column values" but determining whether a single argument of [[..] ..] or [{..} ..] is a single row with compound data values or a sequence of row values is much tougher, so I'll have to give that some thought so I don't break any existing code...#2022-11-1716:22Ben LiebermanDuly noted re: values docstring. Given my incomplete understanding of seqs, I am curious why calling values on a single hashmap/record like I am doing here works? The exception only happens when I pass it to format.#2022-11-1716:23Ben LiebermanI suppose that I expect the exception to be thrown in values and not in format#2022-11-1716:24Ben LiebermanOn the other hand, my use case is so trivial I can see why this behavior would never be encountered by anyone else.#2022-11-1716:25seancorfieldvalues only constructs data. format turns data into SQL. format is where all the checks are.#2022-11-1716:31seancorfieldIt looks like this is going to be harder to fix than I thought (without breaking backward compatibility). I'll have to give it some thought.#2022-11-1716:32Ben LiebermanNot a problem. Now that I know how this works as-is, I think I'll be alright. Thanks as always.#2022-11-1716:32seancorfield(because all the helpers are variadic and can optionally take a DSL hash map as their first argument)#2022-11-1716:35seancorfieldso (values {:insert-into :posts} {:foo 42}) could reasonably mean either "add :values [{:foo 42}] to the DSL" or "build an initial DSL with two rows for :values" üôÇ Even tho' the column value is funky there (but a string would be legal as a table name!).#2022-11-1716:40Ben LiebermanHuh, I'll have to give that some thought myself as DSLs are relatively new to me in general. I'm wondering whether I'm maybe trying to do too little with HoneySQL anyway :thinking_face: my queries are so simple I might be better off just passing them as strings to postgres if that's possible.#2022-11-1717:13seancorfieldString-bashing is never nice, so HoneySQL helps even in fairly simple cases. The data DSL behind HoneySQL is mostly fairly straightforward but the helpers introduce both convenience and some confusion -- some people love them, some people hate them. I tend to use a mixture of helpers and raw data (but mostly helpers). The key with the helpers is that you can thread them in any order so 
(-> (h/insert-info :posts) (h/values [(->Post ..)]) ..)
and 
(-> (h/values [(->Post ..)]) (h/insert-info :posts) ..)
generate identical data (or at least should generate identical data!), which is what allows users to build the SQL statement up across multiple functions and via conditional logic. But that does tend to make the helper functions a little odd/complex at times because the data DSL is a hash map and all helpers have essentially two arities: one with the DSL as the first argument (to allow threading) and one without the DSL as the first argument -- which means that (some-helper my-hash-map another-hash-map) is ambiguous if some-helper could also be called as (some-helper the-dsl my-hash-map another-hash-map) And given that some users build up that data DSL using regular Clojure code without helpers, it can be hard to tell the difference üôÇ#2022-11-1719:40ozymandias33I found an interesting unexpected behavior where honeysql is passing invalid column names when the table name is wrapped in a vector. It took a non-trivial amount of time to debug. Did I miss something in the docs? Does anyone know if there is an open issue on this? 
; DEPENDENCY => [com.github.seancorfield/honeysql "2.4.947"]

;; VALID
(-> (honey.sql.helpers/insert-into :my_pg_table)
    (honey.sql.helpers/values [{:foo "Always look..." :bar "on the bright side of life"}])
    (honey.sql/format))
;=> ["INSERT INTO my_pg_table (foo, bar) VALUES (?, ?)" "Always look..." "on the bright side of life"]

;; ERROR => note the declaration "MY_PG_TABLE() (foo, bar)" in the output block
(-> (honey.sql.helpers/insert-into [:my_pg_table])  ;; Vector Wrapper
    (honey.sql.helpers/values [{:foo "Always look..." :bar "on the bright side of life"}])
    (honey.sql/format))
;=> ["INSERT INTO MY_PG_TABLE() (foo, bar) VALUES (?, ?)" "Always look..." "on the bright side of life"]
#2022-11-1719:42ozymandias33Or maybe just missing the best practice on using positional params vs vectors in the DSL functions?#2022-11-1719:43valtteriA keyword inside a vector gets treated as a function https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql#functions#2022-11-1719:44ozymandias33Ah. Thank you so much üôè#2022-11-1719:45valtteriNo problem. üôÇ I think honeysql is working correctly because ~at least theoretically table name~ from clause could be resolved by a function#2022-11-1719:47ozymandias33I agree with that given the docs. No need to open an issue#2022-11-1719:49seancorfieldSpecifically, this is legal: 
user=> (sql/format {:insert-into [:table :alternative] :columns [:foo :bar] :values [[1 2]]})
["INSERT INTO table AS alternative (foo, bar) VALUES (?, ?)" 1 2]
user=>
#2022-11-1719:49seancorfieldSo HoneySQL accepts generalized expressions there to make life easier.#2022-11-1719:51seancorfield(I think it reuses part of the formatter from :select so that aliasing works the same way -- and the [:table] ;=> TABLE() is just an artifact of that)#2022-11-1721:17ozymandias33Of course it was a gap in understanding the meaning of the vector structure. Need to spend some time with the DSL to understand the particulars. I really like the expressiveness though. Someday we‚Äôll play Conway‚Äôs Game of [Honey]SQL üòÅ#2022-11-1721:17ozymandias33Or I suppose it will be Corfield‚Äôs Game of HoneySQL#2022-11-1721:21seancorfieldSQL is just so... gnarly...#2022-11-1722:14ozymandias33Yeah. It‚Äôs the 21st century. Let‚Äôs start modeling relational databases on general data structures and algebraic data types. I‚Äôll bash out shell scripts like the rest of us, but at some point a string-driven interface becomes too much overhead. Same goes for SQL#2022-11-1920:47kotlenikHi guys! I have had and issue writing simple query to fetch records based on primary keys given in vector to get something like this SELECT * FROM s_lab_results WHERE key IN (23, 456, 890)#2022-11-1920:47kotlenikI have started with query building function as: 
(defn records-for-keys-alt
  [table-name primary-key-column records-keys]
  (let [table-name-for-hsql (keyword table-name)
        primary-key-hsql (keyword primary-key-column)]
    (first (hsql/format {:select [:*]
                         :from   [table-name-for-hsql]
                         :where  [:in primary-key-hsql :?values]}
                        {:params {:values records-keys}
                         :pretty true
                         :inline true}))))
#2022-11-1920:48kotlenikbut it has resulted with : "\nSELECT *\nFROM s_lab_results\nWHERE key IN [23, 456, 890]\n" which is not correct due to usage of [] brackets.#2022-11-1920:49kotlenikWhat was working after colleague had helped me was: 
(defn records-for-keys
  [table-name primary-key-column records-keys]
  (let [table-name-for-hsql (keyword table-name)
        primary-key-hsql (keyword primary-key-column)
        records-keys-inline (mapv #(vector :inline %) records-keys)]
    (first (hsql/format {:select [:*]
                         :from   [table-name-for-hsql]
                         :where  [:in primary-key-hsql records-keys-inline]}
                        {:pretty true}))))
which gives: "\nSELECT *\nFROM s_lab_results\nWHERE key IN (23, 456, 890)\n" but I am not sure where I have made error in initial function. What do you think?#2022-11-1921:00seancorfieldThe documentation explains why you can't do that (named parameter vector with :in). And that second example isn't safe either. Why are you inlining values? That's not safe in general (SQL injection risks)#2022-11-1921:02kotlenikUnderstood, thanks! Values are collection of integers. Actual call may be like (q/records-for-keys-alt "s_lab_results" "key" [23 456 890]) #2022-11-1921:04kotlenikIntegers are always checked, since they are results of diff between source and destination database in data integration mechanism.#2022-11-2221:34marciolHey folks, I have a query that selects a column of enum type. I would now if there is a way to make it return a keyword instead of a string as it is doing right now.#2022-11-2222:12seancorfieldAs an FYI, how data is returned from JDBC is not related to HoneySQL -- it's about the JDBC wrapper you're using (so this Q belongs in #C1Q164V29). Depending on the wrapper, you could probably arrange for such columns to be auto-coerced but it would require runtime reflection on the metadata of the columns in the ResultSet but I think I would avoid that generic approach and explicitly post-process certain known columns directly.#2022-11-2222:13marciolYes, it's what I'm gonna do. @U3Y18N0UC told me that this is the approach he uses.#2022-11-2222:13marciolThanks @U04V70XH6#2022-11-2221:54marciolI think that I gonna use malli to coerce each row. thx#2022-11-2600:25fabraoHello all, I have a situation that I want to select the update operation with case. How can I do this in honeysql? 
:update :table :set {:source [:case [:> source destination] (sql/call :+ :sort-order 1) :else (sql/call :+ :sort-order 1)]} :where ...
how can I use the case in this case?#2022-11-2600:54seancorfieldSorry, I don't understand your question. Is it producing SQL you didn't expect?#2022-11-2600:57fabraoHello Sean, I expect the case be converted to 
CASE WHEN (source > destination) THEN sort_order + 1 ELSE sort_order - 1 END
#2022-11-2600:57fabraoI don't how to write it to have the output#2022-11-2601:03seancorfieldI still don't understand. What does it produce? And why is what it produces not correct for you?#2022-11-2601:08fabraoSorry to not be clear. How can I use the :case to produce a case for set sort = ?#2022-11-2601:10fabraoI have the query in string format, and I'm trying to convert it to honeysql#2022-11-2601:10seancorfieldWhat did you try and what did it produce?#2022-11-2601:10seancorfield
user=> (sql/format {:update :table :set {:source [:case [:> :source :destination] (sql/call :+ :sort-order 1) :else (sql/call :+ :sort-order 1)]}})
["UPDATE table SET source = CASE WHEN source > destination THEN sort_order + ? ELSE sort_order + ? END" 1 1]
user=>
#2022-11-2601:11seancorfieldThat's with HoneySQL v2 -- although it could be written without sql/call now: 
user=> (sql/format {:update :table :set {:source [:case [:> :source :destination] [:+ :sort-order 1] :else [:+ :sort-order 1]]}})
["UPDATE table SET source = CASE WHEN source > destination THEN sort_order + ? ELSE sort_order + ? END" 1 1]
user=>
#2022-11-2601:29seancorfieldI basically typed what you wrote into a REPL @U0YJJPFRA#2022-11-2602:26fabraothank you#2022-12-0113:22orestisAre there facilities to, er, query a HoneySQLv2 query map? For example, I want to check if a table is already left-joined. The function is trivial to write myself, but I was wondering if people tend to do this kind of thing.#2022-12-0113:22orestisI've had to also add facilities to join/filter/select using "dynamic" table names so that you would be able to do it more than once.#2022-12-0113:56markaddlemanThere are SQLisms that make this a difficult prospect in general - particularly aliases. But, if you ignore that, I have had good experience using #CFFTD7R6Z to parse through Honey data structures#2022-12-0114:32orestisI think that given honeysql has a somewhat well defined grammar, the SQLisms are not such big of a deal. #2022-12-0114:32orestisEg a table name is either a keyword or a vector #2022-12-0114:34markaddlemanGrammar isn‚Äôt the issue but semantics are. For example: 
{:with [[:cte {:select [:a] :from [:t]}]] :select [:a] :from [:s] :join [:cte]}
(edited to fix the syntax)#2022-12-0114:34markaddlemanIs :t in the join?#2022-12-0114:36orestisAh true. I‚Äôm not concerned with that though. I‚Äôm more interested in not writing functions to get the table names in the join clause. #2022-12-0114:37markaddlemanAh, ok. Then, I‚Äôve had good experience using meander to parse and recursively descend into honey data structures. Meander makes it very straightforward.#2022-12-0114:39orestisI do love how honeysql makes this even possible. We‚Äôve written some terrible looking code that ‚Äúprunes‚Äù an SQL query based on what the API request is. Impossible with string based sql#2022-12-0114:39markaddlemanAgreed!#2022-12-0118:23seancorfield@U7PBP4UVA That would be "trivial" if HoneySQL used sets for :join clauses I think? The only problem would be that JOIN order can be significant (which is why HoneySQL has a specific construct for ordering multiple JOIN clauses as well). Or I guess the join-merging logic could always apply distinct to the sequence of JOINs?#2022-12-0118:23seancorfieldFeel free to create a GH issue if you think there's anything HoneySQL could do better in this area to help support your use case.#2022-12-0119:06orestis(->> query :left-join (partition-all 2) (into #{} (map first)))#2022-12-0119:07orestisThis works nicely but I think doesn't handle aliasing the joined table as something else. It handles the specific query it was written for though (which assumes uniqueness, hence the cast to the set at the end)#2022-12-0119:08orestisI wouldn't change HoneySQL at all - this is a very much secondary problem that is definitely solvable in user land. I was more wondering if there are other people that are actually querying maps to find information, then some helpers might be in order.#2022-12-0201:07eccentric JI'm using HoneySQL with node's pg library. Was going smoothly until this road bump: ‚Ä¢ honeysql formats the queries like ["SELECT * FROM table WHERE field = ?", "value"] ‚Ä¢ pg expects [ "SELECT * FROM table where field = $1", ["value"] ] Is there an existing honeysql option to use a format that matches what pg expects? Or would it be better to just use the :inline true option with honeysql?#2022-12-0201:16seancorfieldThere's an open issue for that.#2022-12-0201:17seancorfieldI have an idea of how to make it work but there's some edge cases that are a bit gnarly.#2022-12-0201:19eccentric JJust read through the issue. What are the kinds of edge cases that would mess it up?#2022-12-0201:24seancorfieldI'm at the chiropractor right now so I can't look up my notes on it.#2022-12-0201:26eccentric JNo rush, not likely to have a solution, but just curious what kind of edge cases come up with a tool like this#2022-12-0201:26seancorfieldI think there were some corner cases around expansion of in and array since those are special cases today.#2022-12-0201:28seancorfieldBut it's kind of nasty since you can't guarantee everything is generated left to right, especially if folks write their own formatters. So you have to sit out so two passes.#2022-12-0201:29eccentric JI see. Are there any node libraries known to be compatible with honeysql? It's a green project so can switch to another library#2022-12-0201:35seancorfieldNo idea. I don't do any JS.#2022-12-0202:17eccentric JLooked at a few on npmjs, seems they exclusively use that numbered format. I think given that I just have to demo a small project tomorrow I‚Äôll just use the inline option and fix it later.#2022-12-0210:14FiVoHey, I am trying to figure out how to create a composite primary key. 
(def table {:create-table :hello
            :with-columns
            [[:a :int]
             [:b :int]]})

(sql/format table)
;; => ["CREATE TABLE hello (a INT, b INT)"]

(sql/format-expr [:primary-key :a :b])
;; => ["PRIMARY KEY(a, b)"]
How do I combine the two without doing awkward string manipulation?#2022-12-0210:18FiVoPostgres style btw https://kb.objectrocket.com/postgresql/postgresql-composite-primary-keys-629#2022-12-0216:50seancorfieldNot sure what you mean by "combine"? The primary key declaration should be part of the columns for the table, yes?#2022-12-0509:07FiVoI would like to add a composite primary key, I only know how to add a "standard" primary keys. 
(def table {:create-table :hello
              :with-columns
              [[:a :int [:primary-key]]
               [:b :int [:primary-key]]]})

  (-> (sql/format table) first)
  ;; => "CREATE TABLE hello (a INT PRIMARY KEY, b INT PRIMARY KEY)"

  ;; what I would like to have 
  "CREATE TABLE hello (
       a INT,
       b INT,
       PRIMARY KEY(a,b))"
#2022-12-0517:59seancorfield@UL638RXE2 
user=> (-> {:create-table :foo :with-columns [[:a :int] [:b :int] [[:primary-key :a :b]]]} (sql/format))
["CREATE TABLE foo (a INT, b INT, PRIMARY KEY(a, b))"]
user=>
See https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.947/doc/getting-started/sql-special-syntax-#column-descriptors#2022-12-0518:00seancorfieldI'll create a ticket to add an example in :create-table and :with-columns showing how to do this, and probably duplicate that example into that linked section.#2022-12-0518:09seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/445#2022-12-0608:38FiVoThank you üôè . I saw the special syntax section, but didn't make the connection. Haven't used SQL in Clojure. I think I even tried something similar to the above, but didn't nest [:primary-key :a :b] once more.#2022-12-0214:27Noah BogartMy team is trying to move us from v1 to v2. We have a fmt-and-query function that we use everywhere as the primary way to write a query and then execute it with jdbc: 
(defn fmt-and-query
  [db-spec query]
  (try (jdbc/query db-spec (sql/format query :quoting :ansi :allow-dashed-names? true))
       (catch Exception exc (handle-exception exc))))
Because we rely on this so much, it's been challenging to switch us to v2, due to the tight coupling of "make a sql query map" and "format and use the query map". How do y'all go about decomplecting your honeysql stuff from your jdbc stuff? What patterns have you come up with to help ease the transition?#2022-12-0216:54seancorfieldIt would never have occurred to me to combine formatting and querying into a single function like that üëÄ Why did you couple those operations in the first place?#2022-12-0216:56seancorfieldWe use a mix of clojure.java.jdbc and next.jdbc and a mix of HoneySQL v1 and v2. Your combined function ties you to just one of each - that's a lot of coupling.#2022-12-0217:01Noah Bogarthaha I didn't do this, the original dev of the project did it in early 2019. Looking at git history, seems they were coupled to not have to repeat the :allow-dashed-names? formatting flags. Glad to know you are doing it the way I've proposed internally. I think set-dialect! will help us out a lot in the transition.#2022-12-0218:01seancorfieldEven having two separate wrappers -- one to do the formatting with those options and one to call query with error handling -- would be better, but complecting two separate concerns like that was a poor decision however you slice and dice it üòû#2022-12-0218:02seancorfieldFWIW, one of our original devs did something similar for one piece of our codebase but we didn't let it spread to other parts üôÇ#2022-12-0220:53Noah BogartYeah, it's a pain in the butt now, that's for sure. Thanks for the input, will be helpful as we make this transition ourselves#2022-12-1412:10AbhinavHI, is there a way to write this in honeysql? I couldn‚Äôt find any mention of the epoch from ‚Ä¶ syntax. thanks 
SELECT EXTRACT(EPOCH FROM (timestamp_B - timestamp_A))
FROM TableA
#2022-12-1413:33slipset
[:extract
     [:epoch-from
      [:-
       [:raw "current_timestamp"]
       :lastUpdated]]]
#2022-12-1413:33slipsetIs a piece of code from our codebase. I‚Äôm sure you can adapt that?#2022-12-1503:47Abhinavoh yes, that works. thanks#2022-12-1708:07seancorfieldIf anyone wants to try the first cut of numbered parameters (using $1, $2 etc instead of ?), take a look at https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/405 and you can use a git dep with a SHA of c62f5da3f8d4a7f3978fa70ecec85c117b280e73#2022-12-1800:27seancorfieldNumbered placeholder support is now available in a full release. There are tests and also examples in the docs which are automatically tested but it's possible there are edge-case bugs in this functionality since it is brand new. If you use Node.js and PostgreSQL (which requires numbered placeholders), I would really appreciate you testing this and reporting any bugs with repro cases as GH issues. Thank you!#2022-12-1801:37seancorfieldThis first version of numbered placeholders does not attempt to reuse duplicate values but that's something I might add in future, if folks think it's worth it?#2022-12-1911:26orestisInteresting edge-case: 
(h/where {:where [:= 1 1]} false)
;=> {:where [:and [:= 1 1] false]}
but 
(h/where {} false)
;=> {}
#2022-12-1911:29orestisI worked around this by doing instead 
(h/where query [:= [:inline false] [:inline true]])
#2022-12-1917:47seancorfieldIs that using the latest version? There was a bug in where around that which was addressed recently.#2022-12-1918:40orestisAh perhaps I am running some versions behind. We need to really automate updating our clj dependencies.#2022-12-1918:41seancorfieldThis sounds like issue #431 which was fixed in 2.4.947 -- 2022-11-05#2022-12-1918:45orestisStill on 2.2.868 üò≥#2022-12-1918:52seancorfieldThat's only a few releases behind üôÇ#2022-12-2617:32markaddlemanIs there honeysql syntax for array subscripts? ie, https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/reference/standard-sql/operators#array_subscript_operator#2022-12-2617:45markaddlemanAsked and answered before https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C66EM8D5H/p1667313314499199 (lay off the eggnog, @me)#2022-12-2914:40fabraoHello all, how do I transform this query where WHERE payload ->> 'template_id' = '4de1b0da-78b8-4fdd-b376-2b7548ea49d3' to honeysql hashmap structure?#2022-12-2916:55orestis
(sql/register-op! :-> :variadic true)
(sql/register-op! :->> :variadic true)
#2022-12-2916:57orestisYou can then use :->> as an operator: 
[:where 
 [:=
   "4de1b0da-78b8-4fdd-b376-2b7548ea49d3"
   [:->> :payload [:inline "template_id"]]]]
#2022-12-2916:57orestisThe :inline isn't strictly needed but for static paths it saves you one JDBC parameter in the resulting query.#2022-12-2916:57fabraooh, I'll test here, thank you#2022-12-2916:58orestisSince :->> is variadic you can keep adding path elements... [:->> payload "foo" "bar" "baz"]#2022-12-2916:58fabraoI used :where [:= "payload->>'template_id'" id] and worked too#2022-12-2917:14orestisThat looks like it would work, yes!#2022-12-2920:24seancorfieldThese are built-in for HoneySQL -- no need to register new ops -- but you do need to require the pg-ops namespace. See https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.962/api/honey.sql.pg-ops#2022-12-2920:25seancorfieldAlso see https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.962/doc/getting-started/postgresql-support#operators-with---and- for notes on some PG ops that cannot be represented as Clojure keywords/symbols.#2023-01-0518:18marrsAre there any libs based on Honeysql for manipulating DB schemas?#2023-01-0518:45marrsI should have mentioned, I already know about the helpers provided#2023-01-0608:50ts1503I‚Äôm working on a such library but it‚Äôs not ready yet. it works only for postgres right now https://github.com/parencat/fx/blob/master/src/fx/migrate.clj the idea here that it will read a malli schemas and will produce a ddl statements for postgres#2023-01-0816:15marrs@U19BK6W0L thanks, I'm working with PG so that works for me. I'm trying to come up with a way to migrate table definitions declaritively instead of manually defining roll-forward/back procedures for every change. The idea is that you can compare 2 schemas defined in different commits and generate the necessary ddl to migrate between them automatically#2023-01-1013:26marrs@U19BK6W0L It looks like your approach is similar but works to the definition installed on the database instead. Did I get that right? How far along is this project? What can you do with it so far?#2023-01-1013:42ts1503Hi @UVDD67FFX Sorry for long response. I can show some examples later today. Just need to finish my work #2023-01-0613:55David YangAre there any patterns/libraries that normalize the results of queries with left joins? For example if I do something like select * from blog_posts left join comments I want to get a list of blog_post maps that have comments being a list of comment maps?#2023-01-0613:56orestisLooking how popular ORMs do this (outside of Clojure), it seems they will do two queries. One for blog_posts, then one for comments.#2023-01-0613:57orestisClojure could easily let you group-by blog_posts.id#2023-01-0614:01David YangThanks @U7PBP4UVA - ideally I‚Äôd like to get it into a format that I could pump into pyramid so then I could run pull queries#2023-01-0614:02David YangI was thinking if that‚Äôs too hard then I could just do something like (-> :blog_post/id distinct) and then iterate over that#2023-01-0614:03orestis
(group-by (fn [row] (select-keys row [:blog_post/id :blog_post/title ,,,]) rows)
#2023-01-0614:04orestisThis should give you a map with the keys being the blog posts, and for each blog post the sql rows (you would need to map another select-keys there to get only the comment columns)...#2023-01-0614:07David YangI see - that makes sense - that would give me a map with blog-post maps as keys right?#2023-01-0614:07orestisyes#2023-01-0614:07David Yangbut not necessarily preserve order#2023-01-0614:08orestisNo, order will be lost since you get a map. Another think you could consider is using aggregate functions - if you use PostgreSQL you can get one row per blog post with the comments as a PG array or a JSONB array.#2023-01-0614:08David Yangcool - alright thanks for the help!#2023-01-0614:09orestisThe issues with SQL aggregates is data type loss: jsonb for example is only JSON, so if you have dates and such they will be converted to strings.#2023-01-0614:10David YangI don‚Äôt want to get too in bed with SQL in my queries, I feel like that complicates the queries and also require mentally understanding nuances of pg aggregates#2023-01-0614:10orestisYep that's the tradeoff üôÇ#2023-01-0614:11David YangI basically want something like Datomic‚Äôs pull syntax for SQL - the closest thing I‚Äôve found is https://walkable.gitlab.io/ but looking to do it over honeysql üôÇ#2023-01-0614:12orestisThere's also https://pathom3.wsscode.com#2023-01-0614:12orestisI haven't used any of those though.#2023-01-1500:06seancorfield#2023-01-3022:02nigelI want to convert boolean values to bit values for DBs that don't have BOOLEAN values (sqlserver, oracle) in a consistent way (say, convert INT), while also keeping TRUE/FALSE values for dbs with native boolean support. a) Is this supported with HoneySQL? It doesn't appear to be. b) would registering a new dialect be a good approach, or should this be handled in application code?#2023-01-3022:06seancorfieldI'm not even sure what you're asking in terms of HoneySQL -- bit/boolean conversion happens at the JDBC level.#2023-01-3022:15nigelThanks. I guess my question was really "where should this happen"#2023-01-3022:23seancorfieldMySQL does not have a BOOLEAN data type, but its JDBC driver converts to/from Boolean just fine for a BIT(1) field. It's not even done in next.jdbc.#2023-01-3022:24seancorfieldFor a JDBC driver that doesn't do the conversion you want, you can generally extend the protocols in next.jdbc to "force" the conversion but you have to be a bit careful since such conversions will be global to your application.#2023-01-3022:25nigelExcellent. Thanks for the help.#2023-02-0218:47seancorfieldThanks to @camsaul for suggesting this migration enhancement!#2023-02-0219:17refsetHi, has anyone here already looked at Julia's FunSQL library and formed an opinion about how HoneySQL compares? This is a nice overview of roughly how FunSQL works in contrast to more typical query builders: https://mechanicalrabbit.github.io/FunSQL.jl/stable/two-kinds-of-sql-query-builders/ My crude impression is that FunSQL somehow offers a more abstract level of representation & composition. In any case I wonder whether there are new/useful ideas that could be borrowed and applied on top of HoneySQL (potentially in another lib altogether), e.g. the ability to do things like https://mechanicalrabbit.github.io/FunSQL.jl/stable/reference/#FunSQL.Bind-Tuple: > In a scalar context, the Bind node is translated to a correlated subquery. When Bind is applied to the joinee branch of a Join node, it is translated to a JOIN LATERAL query.#2023-02-0220:00seancorfieldI have to be honest, I find those Julia examples much, much harder to comprehend than a HoneySQL query with explicit aliases used to disambiguate the inner/outer table references...#2023-02-0220:02seancorfieldI also find the idea of ordering of clauses affecting the generated SQL to be just a potential for all sorts of weird bugs. HoneySQL (and most of those other SQL builders) is not order sensitive, which makes programmatic building of queries much easier -- and how could you be order sensitive when the underlying data representation is a hash map?#2023-02-0220:03slipsetThe quote given turns me off with out knowing anything about funsql. The beauty of honeysql for me is that it has a fairly simple mapping to plain old sql, and I can combine bits of honey with the usual suspects from the core library.#2023-02-0220:03seancorfield(in fact, that's a specific issue that HoneySQL provides a way to control: join ordering, because that can be sensitive to clause order and a user needs to have control over that)#2023-02-0220:04seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.972/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#join-by -- for the cases where JOIN order actually matters (and I feel like saying #notalldatabases here since I believe only some databases are sensitive to this issue?).#2023-02-0220:05seancorfieldAnd, yeah, what @U04V5VAUN said: context-sensitive changes to semantics are nearly always problematic.#2023-02-0220:06seancorfieldBut if there are specific things that FunSQL can do that you'd like to see added to HoneySQL @U899JBRPF please feel free to create issues on GH so I can take a look at those use cases! I'm always open to specific ways to improve the library.#2023-02-0220:07seancorfield(Datalog clauses are order sensitive, right? That's why they use vectors...?)#2023-02-0221:29refsetThank you for the responses! I will give this some more reflection soon üôÇ > Datalog clauses are order sensitive, right? That's why they use vectors...? The compsci definition of Datalog is fully declarative (first-order logic), but some implementations use the user-provided clause ordering to determine the physical execution plan (rather than having an optimizer doing statistics and join planning).#2023-02-0308:35Cam SaulRE join order: Postgres and MySQL are sensitive about the order of joins. H2 is not. Not sure about anything else. I can write a test and run it against the 14 SQL databases we support in Metabase and get a more detailed answer if it would be useful #2023-02-0311:54refsetI learned recently that SQLite has a CROSS JOIN https://www.sqlite.org/optoverview.html#:~:text=SQLite%20treats%20the%20CROSS%20JOIN%20operator%20specially.%20The%20CROSS%20JOIN%20operator%20is%20commutative%2C%20in%20theory.%20However%2C%20SQLite%20chooses%20to%20never%20reorder%20tables%20in%20a%20CROSS%20JOIN.%20This%20provides%20a%20mechanism%20by%20which%20the%20programmer%20can%20force%20SQLite%20to%20choose%20a%20particular%20loop%20nesting%20order.: > SQLite https://www.sqlite.org/lang_select.html#crossjoin. The CROSS JOIN operator is commutative, in theory. However, SQLite chooses to never reorder tables in a CROSS JOIN. This provides a mechanism by which the programmer can force SQLite to choose a particular loop nesting order.#2023-02-0817:51marrs@U899JBRPF I'd not heard of FunSQL before so I've just read the article you linked to in your first post. My gut reaction to it is that it's an abstraction too far removed from the underlying database to want to use it instead of an AST like HoneySQL. I might however wish to implement something like it on top of HoneySQL. It seems from the examples that you can get much of the same experience by just changing the order in which you build your map. Just write {:from, :select} rather than {:select, :from}. But that's by the by. The article says that "syntax-oriented query builders are harder to use". I guess that depends on what you're trying to use them for. Fundamentally, I'm writing SQL whether I know it or not, and that's what I'm going to be working with if ever I have to debug a broken query, or optimise a slow query, or whatever. I'm going to be reading and comprehending SQL and, once I've worked out how to fix it, I'm then going to be trying to work out how to change my library code to generate that fix. HSQL is essentially a one-to-one mapping. You can intuit just by looking at it what SQL it will produce. That's a big win when fighting with queries. Another thing worth noting about HoneySQL that you should always look for in libraries: it has an escape hatch. If ever the library can't do what you need (or you can't work out what it can do) you can just use :raw to write SQL directly and move on with your life. Frankly, that is worth way more to me than any level of architectural purity. Having said that, I've not looked at this library, so I'm not saying anything about it specifically. These are just the things I would be considering if I were evaluating it for use in one of my projects.#2023-02-0817:55slipsetEspecially about the :raw#2023-02-0918:19marrs@U899JBRPF This may interest you: https://walkable.gitlab.io/. It's at a similar level of abstraction to FunSQL. Again, I have no practical experience with it#2023-02-1121:56seancorfieldMore compatibility with 1.x; improvements to extension machinery:#2023-02-1606:21seancorfield@thenonameguy gratitude for finding and reporting that bug so quickly!#2023-02-1720:22stopadropping by to say...oof honeysql is so cool and useful! Maybe the best sql builder I've ever used. Great work!#2023-02-1801:39seancorfieldThank you! It's always nice to hear praise (instead of complaints!).#2023-02-1903:52hifumi123Yup. At first I didn‚Äôt like HoneySQL because I thought it was just handwriting SQL statements in vectors. But the ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment for me was being able to use HoneySQL to build ‚Äútemplate‚Äù queries and merge data together in ways that‚Äôs simply impossible with SQL itself. I‚Äôve also found it really nice to have EDN files act as data for migration scripts. I do this with the ragtime library, which doesn‚Äôt officially support my use case, but there‚Äôs a nice way to make it work together with HoneySQL. Super convenient stuff#2023-02-2016:09henrikPlaying around with H2 and HoneySQL. Very cool! A question regarding variables; I‚Äôm inserting a bunch of rows where one value is a foreign key. It‚Äôs the same foreign key for all entries, so I‚Äôd like to look up the foreign key once, bind it to a variable. Doing the lookup inline in the :insert-into looks like it might become a bit verbose when there are many entries. Long story short, is there syntax for binding the result of a select into a variable that I can use in the insert?#2023-02-2122:40nigelIs there are way to quote a field or column only in special edge cases? Say I have a quote-for-safety? fn that returns a bool if a word contains certain special characters. I suppose I could register a new dialect and create a new :quote fn that only quotes conditionally. Alternatively, is there any way to map onto the just the keywords and columns of a honeysql expression?#2023-02-2122:54seancorfield@U0ZCYC77T Can you explain what problem you are trying to solve? Or is this just a preference in terms of the generated SQL?#2023-02-2123:07nigel@U04V70XH6 Here's the specific problem I'm running into: 
; I want this quoting behavior, but with :sqlserver quotes
(sql/format {:select [:some##field :another-field]})
;; => ["SELECT \"some##field\", another_field"]
;; 
;; passing a dialect quotes everything
(sql/format {:select [:some##field :another-field]} {:dialect :sqlserver})
;; => ["SELECT [some##field], [another-field]"]
;; 
;; turning quoting off passes the first field unquoted
(sql/format {:select [:some##field :another-field]} {:dialect :sqlserver :quoted false})
;; => ["SELECT some##field, another_field"]
using com.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:mvn/version "2.4.969"}#2023-02-2123:23seancorfieldRight, but what problem are you trying to solve? Quoting all the fields is not a problem in itself.#2023-02-2123:23seancorfieldThat's why I asked if this is just preference on your part?#2023-02-2123:24seancorfieldYou can set the (default) dialect globally -- is that what you're asking about?#2023-02-2123:25seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.980/api/honey.sql#set-dialect!#2023-02-2123:30seancorfieldWas that the answer? You wanted the default dialect to be SQL Server, rather than ANSI?#2023-02-2123:30nigelOh, sorry. I'm migrating a codebase from HoneySQL 1 -> 2, was just trying to match the existing behavior. I'm actually not sure if quoting everything will cause a problem in our case, I'll try that.#2023-02-2123:30nigelAnd, I just figured out what I needed: 
(sql/format {:select [:some##field :another-field]} {:dialect :sqlserver})
;; => ["SELECT [some##field], [another-field]"]
;;
(sql/format {:select [:some##field :another-field]} {:dialect :sqlserver :quoted nil})
;; => ["SELECT [some##field], another_field"]
#2023-02-2123:32nigel:quoted nil restores the default quoting strategy (only quoting unusual entity names) Many thanks @U04V70XH6#2023-02-2123:32seancorfieldYou have multiple DB dialects in play? Else you could just set one as the global default: 
user=> (require '[honey.sql :as h])
nil
user=> (h/set-dialect! :sqlserver)
nil
user=> (h/format {:select [:some##field :another-field]})
["SELECT [some##field], another_field"]
user=>
#2023-02-2123:33nigelWe do, we're using honey.sql in a data warehouse coordinator system#2023-02-2123:33nigelETL from a bunch of source DBs#2023-02-2123:34nigelThanks again!#2023-02-2123:35seancorfieldI'll create an issue to review the docs around the :dialect option and make sure it's clear that you can explicitly use the "default quoting" via :quoted nil#2023-02-2123:35nigelI'm happy to work on that#2023-02-2123:37seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/463#2023-02-2123:37seancorfieldIf you want to send a PR for it, that would be great since I may not get to it for a few weeks.#2023-02-2123:38nigelWill be happy to.#2023-02-2414:13p-himikIs there a better way to CAST(... AS INTEGER[]) than using [:raw "integer[]"]? Tried [:array :integer] and got yelled at:

format-expr-list expects a sequence of expressions, found: class clojure.lang.Keyword
