Do I understand it correctly that a proper way to do it is to register a custom function?#2023-02-2718:08seancorfieldYes, register-fn! will let you add special syntax. This sounds worth being added to core -- can you create an issue with a link to the relevant PG docs and I'll take a look?#2023-02-2721:14p-himikDone: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/471#2023-03-0105:55seancorfieldFor anyone interested in trying out the potential solution to this, develop has been updated with :*foo style keywords in function arguments being treated as a interspersed SQL keywords -- see these tests for examples: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/test/honey/sql_test.cljc#L1112-L1132 -- the syntax is still open to debate but the machinery seems reasonable.#2023-02-2718:08seancorfieldYes, register-fn! will let you add special syntax. This sounds worth being added to core -- can you create an issue with a link to the relevant PG docs and I'll take a look?#2023-03-0105:55seancorfieldFor anyone interested in trying out the potential solution to this, develop has been updated with :*foo style keywords in function arguments being treated as a interspersed SQL keywords -- see these tests for examples: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/test/honey/sql_test.cljc#L1112-L1132 -- the syntax is still open to debate but the machinery seems reasonable.#2023-02-2613:06Daniel Shrikihi y‚Äôall üôÇ I want to use jdbc/execute-batch! for updating several records with batch. how can I use it with honeysql? honey.sql/format function is working only for 1 record and not batch. tnx!#2023-02-2613:13p-himikA somewhat similar previous discussion: https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C66EM8D5H/p1625797454111000 That doesn't exactly answer your question, but if you need that to insert multiple items then there's insert-multi!.#2023-02-2613:35Daniel ShrikiUnfortunately it‚Äôs not the use-case‚Ä¶#2023-02-2613:36Daniel ShrikiI need to update values in batch, so I‚Äôm searching something with this template:#2023-02-2613:38Daniel Shriki
(jdbc/execute-batch! ds
                        "UPDATE agent_event SET seen = TRUE WHERE (agent_id = ?) AND (event_id IN (?))"
                     [["id1" "eid1"] ["id2" "eid2"] ["id3 "eid3"]])
Only that I want to use honey.sql to build the sql statement instead of writing the statement itself#2023-02-2613:38Daniel Shrikitrying to figure out what will work on this case#2023-02-2614:04p-himikNot sure whether it's the best approach but you can create a regular sqlmap where all the positional parameters are represented by [:raw "?"].#2023-02-2614:04p-himik
(honey.sql/format {:update :agent-event
                   :set    {:seen [:inline true]}
                   :where  [:and
                            [:= :agent-id [:raw "?"]]
                            [:in :event-id [[:raw "?"]]]]})
=> ["UPDATE agent_event SET seen = TRUE WHERE (agent_id = ?) AND (event_id IN (?))"]
#2023-02-2614:36Daniel ShrikiThanks üôè I had [:raw "?"] missing üôÇ#2023-02-2718:12seancorfieldPerhaps slightly less ugly: 
user=> (honey.sql/format {:update :agent-event
  #_=>                    :set    {:seen [:inline true]}
  #_=>                    :where  [:and
  #_=>                             [:= :agent-id :'?]
  #_=>                             [:in :event-id [:nest :'?]]]})
["UPDATE agent_event SET seen = TRUE WHERE (agent_id = ?) AND (event_id IN (?))"]
#2023-02-2718:12seancorfield:' allows for "literal" symbols#2023-02-2814:14stopa
(println (hsql/format
          {:with [[:foo {:select :* :from :foo}]
                  [:bar {:select :* :from :bar}]]
           :select :* :from :bar}
          {:pretty true}))

; (out) [
; (out) WITH foo AS (SELECT * FROM foo), bar AS (SELECT * FROM bar)
; (out) SELECT *
; (out) FROM bar
; (out) ]
Hey team! I noticed that newlines don't come in in the with part of the CTE. Is there a way I could see the string in a more pretty way?#2023-02-2814:31markaddlemanI recently discovered https://github.com/vertical-blank/sql-formatter . It does a decent job of formatting SQL#2023-02-2815:05stopaThis works great! Thanks @U2845S9KL#2023-02-2814:28p-himikWould you say that format-entity is OK to use when I need to have a table name in plain string format but still want to use keywords in the code to facilitate searching? Like in: 
{:select :relispopulated
 :from   :pg-class
 :where  [:= :relname (sql/format-entity :my-table)]}
#2023-02-2818:15seancorfieldYes, anything listed in the ns docstring should be considered fair game. Be aware that format binds a lot of dynamic Vars that affect formatting and you don't get those if you call something like format-entity outside of format.#2023-02-2818:17seancorfieldIf you want full-featured, full control, I'd use format instead, which understands expressions too: 
user=> (honey.sql/format :my-table)
["my_table"]
user=> (honey.sql/format :my-table {:dialect :sqlserver})
["[my-table]"]
user=>
#2023-02-2818:18seancorfield(although in all these cases, you'll get a string back and if you have [:= :relname "[my-table]"] that will turn into relname = ? unless you flag it as an :inline expression)#2023-02-2818:19seancorfieldi.e., 
user=> (honey.sql/format {:select :relispopulated
  #_=>  :from   :pg-class
  #_=>  :where  [:= :relname (honey.sql/format-entity :my-table)]})
["SELECT relispopulated FROM pg_class WHERE relname = ?" "my_table"]
user=>
#2023-02-2818:23seancorfield@U2FRKM4TW You would probably be better off using the :entity special syntax: 
user=> (honey.sql/format {:select :relispopulated
  #_=>  :from   :pg-class
  #_=>  :where  [:= :relname [:entity :my-table]]})
["SELECT relispopulated FROM pg_class WHERE relname = my_table"]
user=>
#2023-02-2819:59p-himikOh, didn't realize there's :entity, thanks!#2023-02-2819:59p-himikAh, wait - there should be quotes there, relname = 'my_table'.#2023-02-2820:49seancorfieldOh... you wanted the table as a string?!? Then, yeah, format-entity is going to be your best path.#2023-02-2820:49seancorfield(unless you need all the format bells and whistles, in which case (first (format :my-table)) üôÇ#2023-02-2816:45AkizHi, I am trying to solve one problem. I am using HoneySQL and Next.jdbc. 1. Generally speaking - when you load JSON from DB, it is converted to hash-map‚Ä¶. 2. But when you have query like this 
[[:coalesce :column1
      [:case [:= [:->> :attributes "is-required"] "true"]
       (j/write-value-as-string {:is-active true})
       :else
       (j/write-value-as-string {:is-active false})]] "new column"]
It will fail because ERROR: CASE types jsonb and text cannot be matched 3. If you update the first part of query to 
[:cast :column1 :text]
4. Then it won‚Äôt fail but you will receive string and not map anymore 5. I would like to get back hashmap as I do in this example: 
[[:coalesce :column1 [(j/write-value-as-string {:is-active false})]] "new-column"]
6. What am I missing? üôÇ#2023-02-2818:21seancorfieldCan you explain what SQL you are trying to generate? I suspect the problem is that you are generating a (JSON) string from the Clojure data structure -- so HoneySQL sees a string, not a (JSON) data structure.#2023-02-2818:26seancorfieldYou'll need to wrap the data in :lift so it is not parsed as part of the DSL: 
user=> (require 'honey.sql.pg-ops)
nil
user=> (honey.sql/format {:select [[[:coalesce :column1
  #_=>       [:case [:= [:->> :attributes "is-required"] "true"]
  #_=>        [:lift {:is-active true}]
  #_=>        :else
  #_=>        [:lift {:is-active false}]]] "new column"]]})
["SELECT COALESCE(column1, CASE WHEN (attributes ->> ?) = ? THEN ? ELSE ? END) AS \"new column\"" "is-required" "true" {:is-active true} {:is-active false}]
user=>
(I doubt that's what you're trying to generate but it should be closer) edited to require the #2023-02-2818:43AkizLIFT did not help me, it seems that the ‚Äúproblem‚Äù is on SQL level. I mean, this generated SQL (5th step) works: 
COALESCE(column1, '{"is-active": true}')
but this SQL (that I am generating) does not: 
coalesce(column1,
CASE WHEN (attributes ->> 'is-required') = 'true' 
THEN '{"is-active": true}'
ELSE '{"is-active": false}'
END)
‚Ä¢ it works once i cast JSONs in THEN and ELSE to ::jsonb. ‚Ä¢ I do not understand why SQL interprets string in first example as a JSONB but it is a different story for the second example#2023-02-2818:45AkizSo, this is the solution (if there is nothing better ;-)) So it is not related to the honeysql / next.jdbc in the end.. 
[[:coalesce :column1
      [:case [:= [:->> :attributes "is-required"] "true"]
       [:cast (j/write-value-as-string {:is-active true}) :jsonb]
       :else
       [:cast (j/write-value-as-string {:is-active false}) :jsonb]]] "new column"]
#2023-02-2818:47seancorfieldYou could wrap the CAST around the CASE so you only have one of them...#2023-02-2818:54AkizI asked ChatGPT about this one‚Ä¶ üòÖ > In PostgreSQL, the simple coalescence operator COALESCE returns the first non-null value in a list of expressions. When you use a string literal as a JSON value in a COALESCE expression, PostgreSQL implicitly casts it to a JSON value and returns it. > However, when you use the same string literal in a nested CASE expression, PostgreSQL may not be able to implicitly cast it to a JSON value. This is because the CASE expression has multiple possible return types, and PostgreSQL may not be able to determine which type to cast the string to.#2023-02-2819:24seancorfieldMy experiences with ChatGPT have been less than stellar: it has very confidently told me stuff that is blatantly false and easily provable to be so. YMMV. I pretty much don't trust anything it generates.#2023-02-2821:41AkizYep, that answer is not quite right. I‚Äôve had a moment to think about it. I believe it‚Äôs because COALESCE‚Äôs arguments must all be convertible to a common data type, so it‚Äôs easy to guess what the second string should be converted to if the first element is JSON. But in the case of CASE, it‚Äôs not so easy, so it makes sense to explicitly convert it.#2023-02-2817:29Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)Hello good people! I want to write 
SELECT '{"kids":[{"name":"Jo"}]}'::jsonb -> 'kids'
using Honey. Is the following really the best I can do: 
(honey.sql/format {:select [[[honey.sql.pg-ops/-> [[:raw "'{\"kids\":[1,2]}'::jsonb"]] [:inline "kids"]]]]})
? Mainly I guess there is no way to avoid the :inline so Honey with [:-> :column [:inline "x"] [:inline "y"]] will always be more noisy than SQL‚Äôs column -> 'x' -> 'y' , right? üôè Also in SQL I can write ~ SELECT <some jsonb> -> 'kids' -> 0 ->> 'name' which in Honey becomes {:select [[[:->> [:-> <some jsonb> [:inline "kids"] [:inline 0]] [:inline "name"]]]]} .#2023-02-2818:23AkizYou can not use anonymous sql params as? (honey.sql/format {:select [[[honey.sql.pg-ops/-> [[:raw "'{\"kids\":[1,2]}'::jsonb"]] "kids"]]]})#2023-02-2818:30seancorfield@U0522TWDA Either of these close to what you need? 
user=> (require 'honey.sql.pg-ops)
nil
user=> (honey.sql/format {:select [[[:-> [:cast [:lift {"kids" [{"name" "Jo"}]}] :jsonb] "kids"]]]})
["SELECT CAST(? AS JSONB) -> ?" {"kids" [{"name" "Jo"}]} "kids"]
user=> (honey.sql/format {:select [[[:-> [:cast [:lift {"kids" [{"name" "Jo"}]}] :jsonb] "kids"]]]} {:inline true})
["SELECT CAST({\"kids\" [{\"name\" \"Jo\"}]} AS JSONB) -> 'kids'"]
user=>
#2023-02-2818:31seancorfield(I suspect you don't need the cast if you pass a data structure here rather than a string?)#2023-02-2819:03Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)Sorry for being unclear, I do not care here about the jsonb input, that is just for demo, in practice it would be a :some-column. What bothers me is that I must :inline the arguments to :->, which IMO doesn't make sense (I don't believe Pg supports params at those positions).#2023-02-2819:05Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)@UBRV1HXPD when I don't wrap kids with :inline then I end up with ? in the sql#2023-02-2819:23seancorfield@U0522TWDA OK, that makes (more) sense to me now. The ->, ->> etc operators are all generic at the moment, so they have the exact same semantics in the DSL as anything else. I could force them to inline their second/subsequent arguments if that is the case that no dialect of SQL uses them in a way that doesn't require literal SQL strings for arguments. Feel free to create an issue on GH. [:-> :col "a" "b" "c"] would then become col -> 'a' -> 'b' -> 'c'#2023-02-2819:24Akiz@U0522TWDA Ah, if you don‚Äôt want input parameters, you can do (hsql/format query {:inline true})#2023-02-2819:25seancorfieldRight, but that inlines everything in the query which is not always safe.#2023-02-2819:26AkizYeah, but the params at those positions should be supported by pg, no?#2023-02-2819:26seancorfield(I was under the impression that PG actually understood JSON directly but when I read the docs it seems that it just treats certain strings as JSON instead which definitely makes using JSON with HoneySQL more painful!)#2023-02-2819:27seancorfield@UBRV1HXPD You mean ? -> ? should be legal in PG? I would have expected so as well but apparently not?#2023-02-2819:33AkizYeah, i have just tried this example, seems fine. https://www.loom.com/share/75e20bf54af343ce8e443d48e77336ab#2023-02-2820:29Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)I am sorry, you are right. I have not expected Pg to be able to do that üòÖ Thank you for your support!#2023-03-0118:46p-himikGiven :record, there's no way to write ("record").* without using :raw, right?#2023-03-0118:50seancorfieldThe literal SQL needs double-quotes in it?#2023-03-0118:53seancorfieldCan you link me to some sql/db docs that explain what that syntax means? I've never seen anything like it...#2023-03-0119:02p-himikDouble quotes are just escaping of record. That syntax is record expansion in PostgreSQL. For example, you have to use it here to get a proper table instead of a column of records: 
SELECT (v).*
FROM (SELECT v, row_number() OVER () rn FROM (VALUES (1, 2), (2, 3)) v(a, b)) v2
WHERE rn = 2;
#2023-03-0119:03p-himikIf you use just v, it'll return a column of records. If you use v.*, it'll complain with [42P01] ERROR: missing FROM-clause entry for table "v".#2023-03-0119:06p-himikThe docs mention it here: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/rowtypes.html#ROWTYPES-USAGE > PostgreSQL will apply this expansion behavior to any composite-valued expression, although as shown above, you need to write parentheses around the value that .* is applied to whenever it's not a simple table name.#2023-03-0119:27seancorfieldGods, I hate PostgreSQL because of stuff like this üôÇ#2023-03-0119:28seancorfieldCan you create a GH issue and I'll give it some thought... if you have any suggestions for a suitable syntax, feel free to share...#2023-03-0119:29seancorfieldThere's already :composite but it wouldn't support column selection of the result -- although maybe there's a way to expand that syntax?#2023-03-0119:30seancorfield[:composite :record.*] perhaps? Not sure if that would break any existing code since [:composite :record.a :record.b] is valid today and means (record.a, record.b)#2023-03-0119:31seancorfield(and so it wouldn't help with (record).x would it...)#2023-03-0120:26p-himik> I hate PostgreSQL because of stuff like this To the best of my knowledge, every DB has its own idiosyncrasies. :) Sometimes justified, sometimes not so much.#2023-03-0120:30p-himikCreated: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/474 BTW, why does :raw require a vector? I see that it can be used with a single argument, as in [:raw "value"] but you can't use [:raw "(" "stuff" ")"], you have to wrap all those in a vector. Otherwise, "stuff" and ")" will be silently ignored.#2023-03-0120:34seancorfieldI don't know -- I'd have to compare v1 and v2 to see why I chose to do it that way...#2023-03-0121:26seancorfieldHow would something like this be: 
user=> (sql/register-fn! :project (fn [_ [expr col]] (let [[sql & params] (sql/format-expr expr)] (into [(str "(" sql ")." (sql/format-entity col))] params))))
...
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:project :v :*]]]})
["SELECT (v).*"]
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:project :v :*]]]} {:quoted true})
["SELECT (\"v\").*"]
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:project :v :a]]]} {:quoted true})
["SELECT (\"v\").\"a\""]
user=>
#2023-03-0121:29p-himikSeems alright!#2023-03-0121:29seancorfield
user=> (sql/format {:select [[[:project [:myfunc :b] :a]]]} {:quoted true})
["SELECT (MYFUNC(\"b\")).\"a\""]
Functions returning composites too.#2023-03-0121:30seancorfieldI'm not in love with the name so suggestions welcome...#2023-03-0121:31seancorfieldMaybe :field since it selects a field (or *) from a composite?#2023-03-0121:33p-himik:field feels better. As an alternative, maybe it should be a combination of :nest and e.g. :dot. :dot is actually useful by itself to some extent, at least for me because I used to use qualify from v1 and now I have it in my own code (dynamic field names).#2023-03-0121:34p-himikSo [:dot [:nest [:myfunc :b]] :a].#2023-03-0121:34p-himikOh, dots are actually "legal but not documented" characters in keywords, so maybe even :.. :D#2023-03-0121:35seancorfieldHmm... can you explain what your use of :dot would be (without :nest)?#2023-03-0121:37p-himik[:dot table-name :some-field] or [:dot :my-table some-field]. E.g. suppose a user orders a table in the UI. The column name is sent as is to the backend and then used with :dot to add it to :order-by. It's not always that you can use the column name as is because you can potentially have multiple tables used in the same query that have the same column.#2023-03-0121:38p-himik(Needless to say, I was kinda surprised that qualify was removed in v2.)#2023-03-0121:38seancorfieldAh, OK. That's reasonable.#2023-03-0121:39seancorfieldSo... :. or '. seems like the obvious compact syntax -- datalog style '{select (((. (nest (myfunc b)) a)))}#2023-03-0121:40p-himikYeah!#2023-03-0121:40seancorfieldI'll update the ticket...#2023-03-0209:01p-himikIs it a reasonable proposal to automatically inline everything that can't be used for injections? Like numbers or dates.#2023-03-0210:45kolstaeThis would potentially reduce the effect of statement-caching + increase the parsing overhead of your queries (server-side). But this might not be that important#2023-03-0211:07p-himikI don't know where the overhead will come from given that there's plenty of instance?-like checks there already, but the point about caching is a good one, I haven't thought of it. Still yet to use caching in my projects.#2023-03-0211:12kolstaeWhen using postgres, statement-caching is enabled by default. I found https://dev.to/yugabyte/postgres-query-execution-jdbc-prepared-statements-51e2 to be an excellent explanation#2023-03-0211:13p-himikAh, we're talking about different caches. That's good to know about JDBC. But HoneySQL itself has a cache: https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.980/doc/getting-started/general-reference?q=cach#caching#2023-03-0211:15kolstaeRight - yeah I was not thinking about that üôÇ#2023-03-0216:31slipsetI believe tha eg Oracle keeps several caches around for performance. Eg a query needs to be planned. If you use prepared statements, (again, I believe) that each instance of the prepared statement gets the same plan, whereas if you inline the params, it‚Äôd need to create a plan for each instance. #2023-03-0216:54seancorfieldRight now, HoneySQL doesn't know how to inline dates anyway so that would have to be fixed first... üòï#2023-03-0217:11seancorfield(and its not clear what that would need to look like for ClojureScript)#2023-03-0300:12Tanner EmersonHello, we are trying to migrate from honey 1.x to 2.x. We are currently hung up on one of our usages of do-update-set! from honeysql-postgres. Here is our working example. 
(honeysql.core/format (-> (SQL/insert-into :foo-table)
                          (SQL/values [{:id 1 :data 42}])
                          (PSQL/upsert (-> (PSQL/on-conflict :id)
                                           (PSQL/do-update-set! [:state "enabled"]
                                                                [:modified (HSQL/call :now)])
                                           (SQL/where [:= :state "disabled"])))))
When we have a conflict, our goal is to update the state to enabled iff the current value of state is disabled. It seems like we are able to set the state when there isn‚Äôt a where clause in the upsert. Once we introduce the where, we get a ClassCastException. Is this a supported use case? I included our attempts at writing with honeysql 2.X. 
;; GOAL (fails: setting values with a where clause)
(honey.sql/format (-> (sql/insert-into :foo-table)
                      (sql/values [{:id 1 :data 42}])
                      (sql/upsert (-> (sql/on-conflict :id)
                                      (sql/do-update-set {:state "enabled"
                                                          :modified [:now]})
                                      (sql/where [:= :state "disabled"])))))

;; WORKS (where but uses excluded values)
(honey.sql/format (-> (sql/insert-into :foo-table)
                      (sql/values [{:id 1 :data 42 :state "foo" :modified [:now]}])
                      (sql/upsert (-> (sql/on-conflict :id)
                                      (sql/do-update-set :state :modified)
                                      (sql/where [:= :state "disabled"])))))

;; WORKS (no where but we can set values)
(honey.sql/format (-> (sql/insert-into :foo-table)
                      (sql/values [{:id 1 :data 42}])
                      (sql/upsert (-> (sql/on-conflict :id)
                                      (sql/do-update-set {:state "enabled"
                                                          :modified [:now]})))))
#2023-03-0303:42seancorfieldThat sounds like a bug. Can you create a GH issue with a small repro case so I can investigate @U04DSRYBQ3H? Thanks.#2023-03-0323:43eccentric JRandom idea: Has anyone created a spec that can validate common query types like selects, joins, create table, etc...? Or would it be a massive, sprawling undertaking?#2023-03-0400:16seancorfieldIt's been discussed from time to time. There was a GH issue created years ago to discuss it (but ultimately closed): https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/146#2023-03-0400:17seancorfieldI think "massive" and "sprawling" are apt words for this idea üôÇ#2023-03-0400:29eccentric JI see. One thought came to mind, is this a reasonable approximation\starting place?#2023-03-0400:30eccentric JHmm that looks off#2023-03-0400:31seancorfieldHahaha... I wouldn't trust ChatGPT any further than I could throw it... it very confidently produces incorrect code... sometimes it's obviously incorrect, sometimes it's just subtly incorrect.#2023-03-0400:33eccentric JNot unreasonable, but it was worth a shot as a starting place. If I were to begin such a project I'd probably start very small with a separate library and get at least one type of query covered to publish and see community interest\attract collaborators.#2023-03-0400:33seancorfieldIt's completely wrong about strings -- HoneySQL uses keywords or symbols. Strings are values that are generally lifted out as parameters.#2023-03-0400:34eccentric JOn the other hand, it's not like the dbs it targets doesn't tell you exactly what's wrong with the resulting sql if it's invalid#2023-03-0400:35seancorfieldDDL syntax is horrifically variable across databases and HoneySQL supports a lot of it by basically assuming "you know what you're doing" and accepting fairly arbitrary sequences of keywords and (sub-)sequences of stuff.#2023-03-0400:35eccentric JI see. Probably not worth the trouble#2023-03-0400:36seancorfieldhttps://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.1002/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#create-table-with-columns and https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.1002/doc/getting-started/sql-special-syntax-#column-descriptors should give you an idea of how... flexible... create table syntax can be üôÇ#2023-03-0400:38seancorfieldThere's also the interesting issue that there are plenty of valid-to-HoneySQL data structures that produce absolute garbage SQL -- and what's valid SQL for one DB might be invalid for another DB, just to add to the fun.#2023-03-0400:43eccentric JYeesh yeah I'm tapping out. Thanks for humoring me üòõ#2023-03-0409:48p-himikA spec could be useful for invalid-to-HoneySQL data structures. Consider a few examples: 
=> (honey.sql/format {:select [[[:array #{}]]]})
Execution error (ExceptionInfo) at honey.sql/format-expr-list (sql.cljc:483).
format-expr-list expects a sequence of expressions, found: class clojure.lang.PersistentHashSet
;; ^ Doesn't let you know the context where the set was found, could problematic to quickly find when you have a lot of dynamic parameters.

=> (honey.sql/format {:where nil})
Execution error (ExceptionInfo) at honey.sql/format-dsl (sql.cljc:1258).
These SQL clauses are unknown or have nil values: :where
;; ^ Obvious with this simple query but hard to find with deeply nested SQL with a lot of dynamic `:where`

=> (honey.sql/format {:select [[[:raw "(" 1 ")"]]]})
["SELECT ("]
;; ^ No error but still incorrect usage of `:raw` which might potentially even produce syntactically correct SQL, making it hard to debug.
But it's actually hard to come up with the examples. Before the fresh release, it was possible to create errors like Unable to convert: class clojure.lang.Keyword to Object[] but not sure how to produce those ones now. And even without a spec, potentially HoneySQL could report most of the errors itself along with the context. E.g. instead of that :where error there would something like (for a more nested query) These SQL clauses have nil values: :where (at [:from 0 0 :where]). But hard to say how useful that would be and how hard it is to implement it.#2023-03-0419:29seancorfieldTo be fair with those first two, ex-data helps here (I should mention that in the docs): 
user=> (honey.sql/format {:select [[[:array #{}]]]})
ExceptionInfo format-expr-list expects a sequence of expressions, found: class clojure.lang.PersistentHashSet  clojure.core/ex-info (core.clj:4739)
user=> (ex-data *e)
{:exprs #{}}
user=> (honey.sql/format {:where nil})
ExceptionInfo These SQL clauses are unknown or have nil values: :where  clojure.core/ex-info (core.clj:4739)
user=> (ex-data *e)
{:where nil}
#2023-03-0419:30seancorfieldI need to think about :raw -- I suspect that was an unintended (or poorly thought out) change from 1.x üòï#2023-03-0419:30p-himikAh, right. But still - it shows just the value, not where it is. It's already helpful but having a "data stack trace" (i.e. a get-in-like path) would be even more helpful.#2023-03-0419:33seancorfieldI could probably create something from the stacktrace, walking back for honey.sql$format_ matches (on invokeStatic) to report a better context there, since it is full-on recursive descent formatting. :thinking_face:#2023-03-0419:38seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/476 and https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/477#2023-03-0422:29seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/476 is fixed on develop -- that was an unintended change so 1.x compatibility should be better now.#2023-03-0422:29seancorfieldhttps://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/476 is fixed on develop -- that was an unintended change so 1.x compatibility should be better now.#2023-03-0400:14seancorfield#2023-03-1311:06orestisI love how I can read the tests for all these PRs to see how would this affect me ‚ù§Ô∏è#2023-03-0422:35seancorfield‚òùÔ∏è:skin-tone-2: What I had intended in 2.x was that :raw could take both literal SQL fragments and expressions, so that [:raw "@foo := " [:myfunc 42]] would work and produce ["@foo := MYFUNC(?)" 42] because that was pretty much impossible in 1.x -- but I accidentally made :raw unary in the process so you actually had to write [:raw ["@foo := " [:myfunc 42]]] instead. The "current" unary behavior is unchanged, but the variadic behavior of 1.x is restored, with the addition of making it possible to embed expressions as well -- so [:raw "@foo := " [:myfunc 42]] works now as well (it previously produced ["@foo := "] which was not what I intended!).#2023-03-0422:35seancorfieldAgain, thanks @p-himik for uncovering my mistake!#2023-03-0607:10p-himikWould it make sense to add support for COLLATE to HoneySQL? So e.g. [:collate [:lower :name] :C] results in (LOWER(name)) COLLATE "C". One immediate issue though is that, according to a quick test with SQL Fiddle, different DBs require different syntax: ‚Ä¢ PostgreSQL requires for the collation name to be quoted ‚Ä¢ MySQL doesn't care at all ‚Ä¢ MS SQL Server requires for it to be unquoted I'm using PostgreSQL so currently I have this: 
(sql/register-fn! :collate
                  (fn [f [thing collation]]
                    (assert (keyword? collation))
                    (let [result (sql/format-expr thing)]
                      (update result 0
                              (fn [sql]
                                (str "(" sql ") " (sql/sql-kw f) " \"" (name collation) "\""))))))

Seems nice during destructuring to allow for values to carry more clarity of what they are#2023-03-1420:32azIt's really the first time I've needed to rename keys like this. Basically doing this now


(defn get-formatted-production-line-items
  [production-id]
  (let [raw (->
             (hh/select :*)
             (hh/from :production_line_items)
             (hh/where [:= :production_id production-id])
             db/execute!)]
    (mapv (fn [p] (rename-keys p {:id :production-line-item/id
                                  :qty :production-line-item/qty
                                  :production_id :production-line-item/production
                                  :recipe_id :production-line-item/recipe
                                  :created_at :production-line-item/created-at
                                  :updated_at :production-line-item/updated-at}))
          raw)))
#2023-03-1420:33seancorfieldWhy not use qualified keywords in the first place? HoneySQL is fine with those. #2023-03-1420:36seancorfieldWhat is db?#2023-03-1420:36az!!!#2023-03-1420:36az
(defn execute!
  [q & {:keys [connection opts]
        :or {connection conn
             opts {}}}]
  (jdbc/execute! connection (format-sql q)
                 (merge {:return-keys true
                         :builder-fn rs/as-unqualified-lower-maps
                         :pretty true} opts)))

#2023-03-1420:37seancorfieldWell, there's your problem!#2023-03-1420:37azthank you again, lots of lessons here#2023-03-1420:37seancorfieldNot sure what :pretty true is supposed to be doing in a next.jdbc/execute! call...?#2023-03-1420:38seancorfield(it's a HoneySQL option)#2023-03-1420:38azthis is great. I'm going to get this updated, and no need for all the remapping.#2023-03-1420:40seancorfieldLook at https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/next.jdbc/1.3.862/api/next.jdbc#snake-kebab-opts if you want :table-name/column-name (with my caveat above about mixing layers of abstraction and naming).#2023-03-1420:42azThank you so much, this is perfect, I just love the work you've done#2023-03-1722:57seancorfield#2023-03-2112:27slipsetSo at work, we do quite a bit of logging, and in that logging we add a trace-id so we can correlate log messages to the same request. This is not rocket science.
It turns out however, that if we do

=> /* trace-id: 123456789 */ select * from foo;

from the psql console, that comment gets propagated to the logs as:

2023-03-21 11:47:23.146 UTC [29737] LOG:  duration: 36.834 ms  statement: /* trace-id: 123456789 */ select * from foo;

Which would then let us correlate (slow) queries to specific requests, which would again make it very much easier to debug performance problems.
Because of how we‚Äôve structured our code, this would be very easy to implement if honey-sql had a (hh/comment ) fn, so we could say something like:

(->> (hh/comment (str "trace-id: " id))
     (hh/select ..))  

which would render out a comment before the actual statement.
Is this already possible (and if not, would it be possible to add)?#2023-03-2119:39seancorfieldTBH, that sounds a bit more like something next.jdbc should be providing but it's an interesting question and certainly something that is easy to add to HoneySQL -- as you found with register-clause! üôÇ Is it (comments preceding SQL) an ANSI feature or something peculiar to PG?#2023-03-2119:40slipsetI don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs ANSI or not.#2023-03-2119:42slipsetBut, say I wanted to register :comments so that it is added before :insert , :update, :delete :with as well? do I just supply all those keywords as last args?#2023-03-2119:44seancorfieldJust pick the earliest one you need it to be before...#2023-03-2119:45slipsetSo basically :with (and then honey will figure out that if :with is not present, it will go before whatever comes after :with)?#2023-03-2119:46seancorfield
(def ^:private default-clause-order
  "The (default) order for known clauses. Can have items added and removed."
  [;; DDL comes first (these don't really have a precedence):
   :alter-table :add-column :drop-column
   :alter-column :modify-column :rename-column
   :add-index :drop-index :rename-table
   :create-table :create-table-as :with-columns
   :create-view :create-materialized-view :create-extension
   :drop-table :drop-view :drop-materialized-view :drop-extension
   :refresh-materialized-view
   ;; then SQL clauses in priority order:
   :raw :nest :with :with-recursive :intersect :union :union-all :except :except-all
   :table
   :select :select-distinct :select-distinct-on :select-top :select-distinct-top
...
#2023-03-2119:47seancorfieldNot sure whether you'd want this to be "before" raw/nest, but with sounds like a reasonable starting point?#2023-03-2119:48slipsetWe‚Äôre not currently using :raw at top-level, and I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre using :nest but we‚Äôre deffo using :with#2023-03-2113:37slipsetI guess something along the lines of

(honey.sql/register-clause! :comment
                      (fn [clause x]
                        [(str"/* " x " */")])
                      :select)
#2023-03-2116:11azHi all. Wondering how I might achieve the following sql chunk:


ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT (i.name)) FILTER (WHERE i.name IS NOT NULL)

I have this in honey, but can't figure out how to not use a aggregate function as explained in the docs

[[:array_agg 
  [:distinct :i.name] 
  [:filter {:where [:not= nil :i.name]}]]]

If I don't use something like :%count, the filter clause doesn't show up in the output. Any thoughts?#2023-03-2116:18p-himik
(sql/format {:select [[[:filter
                        [:array_agg [:distinct :i.name]]
                        {:where [:is-not :i.name nil]}]]]})
=> ["SELECT ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT i.name) FILTER (WHERE i.name IS NOT NULL)"]

Documented at https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.980/doc/getting-started/sql-special-syntax-#filter-within-group#2023-03-2116:20azHi @U2FRKM4TW, thank you. I just don't see how to create a filter without an aggregate. My query doesn't work when I use Count#2023-03-2116:20p-himikNot sure what you mean. What exactly do you want as an output?#2023-03-2116:21az
ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT (i.name)) FILTER (WHERE i.name IS NOT NULL)

#2023-03-2116:21p-himikAnd how is it different from my code snippet?#2023-03-2116:21azNot


ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT (i.name)) COUNT(*) FILTER (WHERE i.name IS NOT NULL)

#2023-03-2116:21p-himikRead my code snippet again. :)#2023-03-2116:21azI'm so sorry! I just saw the link to the docs#2023-03-2116:22p-himikYeah, :filter is a modifier on top of an aggregate. Not an argument.#2023-03-2116:23azThank you so much this is perfect!#2023-03-2215:27Noah BogartI have a v1 insert-into with `query-values` that formats to "insert into temp_table (with "rows" as (select * from ...) ...)": `(-&gt; (insert-into :temp-table) (query-values (-&gt; (with [:rows (-&gt; (select :*) (from :other) ...)]) ...))`, and i want to transform this to v2. reading the docs, i feel like it should be `(-&gt; (insert-into [:temp-table (-&gt; (with [:rows (-&gt; (select :*) (from :other) ...)]))] ...))` but that doesn't give me the right output.#2023-03-2215:43Noah BogartHmm, seems i need to leave off the vector from the insert-into call#2023-03-2216:13Noah Bogartopened a github issue about this misunderstanding (and related misunderstandings) https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/480#2023-03-2218:01seancorfieldI'm not sure if I understand where the root of the confusion is, so I asked a question there to clarify...#2023-03-2216:13Noah Bogartopened a github issue about this misunderstanding (and related misunderstandings) https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/480#2023-03-2315:35Daniel StephensHi all, does anyone know how to use postgres' on-conflict stuff where the update should increment a value from honeysql.
Something like:

(honey/format
  {:insert-into   :table
   :values        [{:id "id" :counter 1}]
   :on-conflict   [:id]
   :do-update-set [:+ :counter 1]})

this is made up, but results in:

["INSERT INTO table (id, counter) VALUES (?, ?) ON CONFLICT (id) DO UPDATE SET + = EXCLUDED.+, counter = EXCLUDED.counter, ? = EXCLUDED.?"
 "id"
 1
 1
 1]

whereas I want something like:

["INSERT INTO table (id, counter)
   VALUES (?, ?)
   ON CONFLICT (id)
   DO UPDATE SET
   counter = table.counter + ?"
  "id"
  1
  1]

Probably a bit specific or unusual as a case, but just in case!#2023-03-2315:58seancorfieldYou want the hash map form of :do-update-set:

user=> (sql/format {:insert-into :table :values [{:id "id" :counter 1}] :on-conflict [:id] :do-update-set {:counter [:+ :counter 1]}})
["INSERT INTO table (id, counter) VALUES (?, ?) ON CONFLICT (id) DO UPDATE SET counter = counter + ?" "id" 1 1]
user=>
#2023-03-2315:59seancorfieldIf you specifically need table.counter:

user=> (sql/format {:insert-into :table :values [{:id "id" :counter 1}] :on-conflict [:id] :do-update-set {:counter [:+ :table.counter 1]}})
["INSERT INTO table (id, counter) VALUES (?, ?) ON CONFLICT (id) DO UPDATE SET counter = table.counter + ?" "id" 1 1]
user=>
#2023-03-2316:00seancorfieldThe vector form of :do-update-set only sets excluded columns.#2023-03-2316:05Daniel Stephensha, amazing, thanks @U04V70XH6 that was speedy! I appreciate the help, I did look through some docs FWIW and didn't notice this option https://cljdoc.org/d/seancorfield/honeysql/2.0.0-rc2/doc/getting-started/postgresql-support#upsert#2023-03-2316:55seancorfieldCan you create an issue on GH for me to make that clearer? So i guess I will use inline for now, cheers for the assistance appreciated üôÇ#2023-03-2915:29seancorfield@UU67HFS2X I've seen that with different versions of MySQL: older versions allowed you to omit grouped columns/expressions from the SELECT but later versions required you provide them (although there was a DB setting to relax the new restriction). I think if you add that [:substring ..] call into the :select with an alias, you will be able to :group-by that alias.#2023-03-2918:15olydoes the same apply for postgres ? that's my target in this instance I also realized the cast above is wrong as it should be ::integer not ::int when using the cast function so will need to retry that#2023-03-2918:16seancorfieldGiven the ERROR: column "accounts_address.postcode" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function error you're getting, I'm going to say "Yes, it applies to PostgreSQL" üôÇ#2023-03-2918:30olyokay I will give it a try cheers for the tip üôÇ#2023-03-2919:28p-himikFWIW in PostgreSQL you cannot mention in GROUP BY aliases defined in SELECT.#2023-03-2910:59olyif you have not thought of doing this, using the chat gpt style apps are pretty good at generating you honeysql code with the correct format, I just asked you chat this question.

give me an example of using a summed case statement using honeysql version 2

Which saved me piecing the parts together, surprised how good it is considering honeysql is a bit more niche#2023-03-2911:06olyha, very impressed it does entire queries and if you specify give it to me in threading macro style it can even use the helper functions which are much nicer to read üôÇ#2023-03-2915:25seancorfieldBeware of very confident but completely wrong answers from ChatGPT: it will happily invent new functions in libraries, just on the basis that the names sound like they solve the problem -- remember that it is a language model and has no real understanding of Clojure or the specifics of any library!#2023-03-2919:33olyyeah very true, but its handy to give me an idea of the general syntax else I keep having to reference existing queries or lookup in the docs for the format I need, but I have noticed it does get things wrong often just close enough to save me some time üôÇ#2023-03-3118:11markaddlemanI think I found a bug in honey‚Äôs formatting of partition-by#2023-03-3118:12markaddleman
(-> {:select [[[:over [[:lead :event]
                         {:partition-by [[:upper :a]]}]]
                 :random]]
       :from   [[:foo :foo]]}
      (honey.sql/format)
      (first))

produces SELECT LEAD(event) OVER (PARTITION BY upper a) AS random FROM foo AS foo#2023-03-3118:12markaddlemanI expected the partition by to be PARTITION BY UPPER(a)#2023-03-3118:13markaddlemanthis honey produces the correct result

(-> {:select [[[:over [[:lead :event]
                         {:partition-by [[[:upper :a]]]}]]
                 :random]]
       :from   [[:foo :foo]]}
      (honey.sql/format)
      (first))

SELECT LEAD(event) OVER (PARTITION BY UPPER(a)) AS random FROM foo AS foo#2023-03-3118:13markaddlemanIf this is not user error, I‚Äôll open an issue#2023-03-3118:16p-himikPretty sure it's user error as :partition-by can accept many columns.
Zero nesting, a single keyword - a single column
One level of nesting - >= 1 columns
Two levels - same but with aliases
Three levels - same but with function calls#2023-03-3118:16p-himikSame as with :select.#2023-03-3118:17markaddlemanSQL partition-by allows aliases?  I‚Äôm not sure what that would mean#2023-03-3118:18p-himikIt probably doesn't, but I believe that vector nesting is handled in a generic way.#2023-03-3118:18markaddlemanthat would make sense.  If that‚Äôs the case, I contend it‚Äôs a bug but, of course, Sean is arbiter üôÇ#2023-03-3118:19markaddlemanbtw

(-> {:select [[[:over [[:lead :event]
                         {:partition-by [[[:upper :a] :A]]}]]
                 :random]]
       :from   [[:foo :foo]]}
      (honey.sql/format)
      (first))

produces SELECT LEAD(event) OVER (PARTITION BY UPPER(a) A) AS random FROM foo AS foo#2023-03-3118:23seancorfieldNot a bug. Portions of HoneySQL are generic, just to keep maintenance manageable (because SQL is so f***ing complex) -- and there are many, many ways to persuade HoneySQL to generate invalid SQL üôÇ#2023-03-3118:24markaddlemanUnderstood#2023-03-3118:25markaddlemanSo, just double wrap functions in the partition by clause?#2023-03-3118:35seancorfieldExactly like select, yes.#2023-03-3118:36seancorfieldThis is documented, BTW:

> :partition-by accepts the same arguments as :select above (even though the allowable SQL generated is much more restrictive).
From https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.1011/doc/getting-started/sql-clause-reference#window-partition-by-and-over#2023-03-3118:36markaddlemanI should have RTFM.  Thanks!#2023-03-3118:38seancorfieldAll of the following are formatted like SELECT:

:select          #'format-selects
         :select-distinct #'format-selects
         :select-distinct-on #'format-selects-on
         :delete          (check-where #'format-selects)
         :from            #'format-selects
         :using           #'format-selects
         :cross-join      #'format-selects
         :partition-by    #'format-selects
         :returning       #'format-selects
#2023-04-1311:48rpatrellemessage moved to #sql#2023-04-1523:07seancorfieldThanks to several folks who highlighted missing syntax support over the last month or so!#2023-04-1710:04Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)Hello, good people! I am not able to find out how to make Honey produce truncate table cascade
I have tried (assoc (hh/truncate _:table_) :raw "cascade") but that renders "CASCADE TRUNCATE table" üò≠ üôè#2023-04-1710:08p-himik
(sql/format {:truncate [:my-table :cascade]})
=> ["TRUNCATE my_table CASCADE"]
#2023-04-1710:08p-himikAnd with a helper function:

(sql/format (hh/truncate [:my-table :cascade]))
=> ["TRUNCATE my_table CASCADE"]
#2023-04-1710:20Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)many thanks! I would never have figured that out üòÖ#2023-04-1710:24p-himikSearching on GitHub brings answers in the speediest of manners. :)#2023-04-1710:26Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)What did you search? I searched the honesql GH repo for ‚Äúcascade‚Äù in vain#2023-04-1710:29p-himikThat's actually exactly what I did. It's just that I look at commits and issues as well.
The search landed me on this commit where I quickly saw the highlighted line which made it obvious how to specify :cascade: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/commit/e8ea9283cc3cae5939750a0b540518143b87ff39#diff-49952233047493b6ede50abf2fce16b71d9c717d3b7c050f64e86a4514a1db1bR599#2023-04-1720:57marrsCan honeysql quote table and column names to prevent clashes with names reserved by the DBRMS and are there any strong opinions about whether or not one should do this?#2023-04-1720:58p-himikYes, quoting is very well documented. And you should definitely do that. There's no good reason not to quote your identifiers.#2023-04-1721:26marrsAh, I found the relevant part in the doc.  I guess the deeper question is, should one avoid using reserved words even if one is quoting?#2023-04-1721:40p-himikI would say no. E.g. "order" is way too good of a name to pass it up just because the DB reserved it in its unquoted form.#2023-04-1721:40p-himikBut you probably shouldn't name your columns &%!@# even if quoted. ;)#2023-04-1721:47marrsyeah, that seems fair#2023-04-1721:47marrsthanks for sharing your opinion#2023-04-2113:28Bingen Galartza IparragirreHi! is it possible to use the WITH _storage_parameter=value`_ ` options  in the create table/view ddl operations using HoneySQL?

I don't know if it's part of the SQL standard or PSQL specific.
https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-creatematerializedview.html#2023-04-2415:14iarenaza@UK14W219B This should do the trick:


user> (sql/format {:create-materialized-view [:product [[:with [:= :storage-parameter "value"]]]]
                   :select [:*]
                   :from [:table]
                   :where [:= :column "value"]
                   :with-data false})
["CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW product WITH(storage_parameter = 'value') AS SELECT * FROM table WHERE column = ? WITH NO DATA"
 "value"]
#2023-04-2415:42Bingen Galartza IparragirreGreat! Thanks a lot#2023-04-2412:15Daniel VieiraHi, is there a way to use :quoted together with if exists?

(sql/format (hh/drop-view [:if-exists] :aBc) {:quoted true})
; => ["DROP VIEW  IF EXISTS ABC"]

(sql/format (hh/drop-view :aBc) {:quoted true})
; => ["DROP VIEW \"aBc\""]

Expected:
(sql/format (hh/drop-view [:if-exists] :aBc) {:quoted true})
; => ["DROP VIEW  IF EXISTS \"aBc\""]#2023-04-2412:18p-himik
(sql/format (hh/drop-view :if-exists :aBc) {:quoted true})
=> ["DROP VIEW IF EXISTS \"aBc\""]
#2023-04-2615:28Ben Liebermanbit of a niche thing I suppose but H2's JAVA_OBJECT type requires the keyword :java_object in order to work correctly. Is there a way to support kebab casing here?#2023-04-2618:31seancorfieldCan you provide more context/examples & maybe link to some docs?#2023-04-2619:10Ben LiebermanThat type is documented http://www.h2database.com/html/datatypes.html#java_object_type. I'm getting some data from an API into our (test) database and among other things it includes positional data that looks like this

{"type" "Point", "coordinates" ["a-lat" "a-lon"]}

H2 has a GEOMETRY type for this but it doesn't support the additional type parameter so I'm just serializing it as is.

It really is not terribly important and is more of an observation that if I write something like

(hsql/format {:create-table :foo
              :with-columns [[:bar :java-object]]})

it gives me back ["CREATE TABLE foo (bar JAVA OBJECT)"] which doesn't pass muster with H2.#2023-04-2619:13seancorfieldAh, gotcha... Not much you can do to get around that at the moment.#2023-04-2619:14Ben LiebermanNo worries, thanks for HoneySQL, it's awesome!!#2023-04-2805:56flowthingI‚Äôm a bit late with this, but it‚Äôs been a while since we updated our deps‚Ä¶ it looks like commit https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/commit/3073d2852587186e1a1489c3a07b032e014881ac breaks backwards compatibility in that HoneySQL no longer allows hash sets as :values:


Œª clj -Srepro -Sdeps '{:deps {com.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:git/url "" :sha "737699c11acae0863b6c9e76921a2f8c92902ca4"}}}'
Clojure 1.11.1
user=> ((requiring-resolve 'honey.sql/format) {:insert-into :foo :values #{{:bar "baz"}}})
["INSERT INTO foo (bar) VALUES (?)" "baz"]

vs.


Œª clj -Srepro -Sdeps '{:deps {com.github.seancorfield/honeysql {:git/url "" :sha "3073d2852587186e1a1489c3a07b032e014881ac"}}}'
Clojure 1.11.1
user=> ((requiring-resolve 'honey.sql/format) {:insert-into :foo :values #{{:bar "baz"}}})
Execution error (ExceptionInfo) at honey.sql/format-values (sql.cljc:768).
:values expects sequences or maps

Is this an intentional change?#2023-04-2807:46p-himikI'd argue that it's not a breaking change because hash sets were never intended to be used as :values.
The docs state:
>  :values accepts either a sequence of hash maps representing row values or a sequence of sequences, also representing row values.
And sets are not sequences.
So I'd say you were relying on undefined behavior. Especially given that insertion order is meaningful in general whereas sets are unordered.#2023-04-2807:49flowthingMakes sense, thanks. üëç#2023-04-3021:13marrsI've just noticed that :join and :inner-join get added to a query in a different order when combined with :left-join.  Is that deliberate?#2023-04-3021:29seancorfieldThe DSL is a hash map: it is inherently unordered.

There's a :join-by construct in the DSL if you need JOINs in a specific order for your database (the behavior with multiple JOINs differs between databases... because of course it does).#2023-05-0112:15marrsThanks, I switched to that already.  I just wondered if I was missing a trick.  I've noticed that hashmaps tend to be ordered by key alphabetically, and since inner-join and join are both ahead of left-join, I was wondering if you were forcing the behaviour for some reason.#2023-05-0116:02seancorfieldSmall hash maps stay in key order because they use an array but that's a pure implementation detail and should never be relied on:

user=> {:b 2 :a 1}
{:b 2, :a 1}

What HoneySQL does is process clauses in "precedence order" and it uses a vector to determine that, so I've probably got all the JOIN-related clauses in alphabetical order just for maintenance purposes: https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/src/honey/sql.cljc#L1228-L1238 but modified by https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/blob/develop/src/honey/sql.cljc#L709-L717#2023-05-0511:21PratikOur codebase is in honeysql 1.x version and I am trying to get this query working

SELECT *
FROM
    schemes s
    LEFT JOIN progress p ON p.scheme_id = s.id
    AND s.term = 1
    AND p.date > '2023-04-27'
WHERE
    p.driver_id = '123'
    ORDER BY p.date DESC
    LIMIT 10 OFFSET 0;

and till left join it‚Äôs working as below:

(-> (sqle/select* [:*])
    (helpers/from [:schemes :s])
    (helpers/left-join [:progress :p] [:= :p.scheme-id :s.id])
    (honeysql.core/format))

but I am not sure how to add the

AND s.term = 1
AND p.date > '2023-04-27'

part in honeysql(I want it to be there instead of where condition because it optimizes the query by filtering records at join time).#2023-05-0511:34p-himikWrap [:= ...] in [:and ...].

Also, are you sure about that "it optimizes the query" statement? I would be rather surprised if that's the case since it seems to be a very obvious optimization that a query planner can do on its own. Have you run EXPLAIN ANALYZE on that query and compared it to the one where the conditions are in the WHERE clause?#2023-05-0511:45Pratiktried placing [:and [:= :s.term 1]] inside the left-join as well as after it but it‚Äôs not working:

(-> (sqle/select* [:*])
    (sqlh/from [:schemes :s])
    (sqlh/left-join [:progress :p] [:= :p.scheme-id :s.id])
    ([:and [:= :s.term 1]])
    (sqlc/format))

is giving ; Key must be integer error.#2023-05-0511:46PratikAnd yes, the query with AND statements is giving less execution time on average than the query with ‚ÄúWHERE‚Äù conditions. It was suggested by a colleague and I was also surprised(It‚Äôs 30-40% improvement) on running it with explain analyze#2023-05-0512:04p-himikI meant to wrap the existing := in :and: (sqlh/left-join [...] [:and [:= ...] [:= ...]]).#2023-05-0512:09p-himik> And yes, the query with AND statements is giving less execution time on average
Intersting. Are there differences in actual plans?
On my end, I can only see "hash join" vs "hash right join" and they don't result in any difference time-wise.#2023-05-0512:10p-himikOh, hold on - in your case it's actually quite important because it's a left join and not an inner join. Putting the conditions in a different place will result in different results. Didn't happen on my end because there were always entries in the joined table for any row in the main table.#2023-05-0512:11p-himikSo, there shouldn't be a difference if you have an inner join - both result- and performance-wise.#2023-05-0516:28Pratik
(-> (sqle/select* [:*])
    (sqlh/from [:schemes :s])
    (sqlh/left-join [:progress :p] [:= :p.scheme-id :s.id] [:and [:= :s.term 1]]) 
    (sqlc/format))

["SELECT * FROM schemes s LEFT JOIN progress p ON p.scheme_id = s.id"]

that‚Äôs not working either, it seems like it‚Äôs just ignoring the end part#2023-05-0516:29p-himikWhy do you keep putting that original [:= ...] outside of the [:and ...]?#2023-05-0516:29p-himikIt should be (sqlh/left-join [:progress :p] [:and [:= :p.scheme-id :s.id] [:= :s.term 1]]).#2023-05-0516:30p-himikIn other words, you need to be joining on :and, not on :=.#2023-05-0516:30PratikI see, that worked!#2023-05-0516:31PratikThanks a lot!#2023-05-1915:14Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)Hi! How do I tell Honey that DEFAULT is a Postgres keyword and not a column name that should be quoted? This

(-> (hh/update table)
      (hh/set {:col :DEFAULT})
      (honey.sql/format {:quoted true}))

produces UPDATE "snapshot" SET "col" = "DEFAULT" while I need UPDATE "snapshot" SET "col" = DEFAULT . I did not find anything in the docs other than [:raw "DEFAULT"] . Is that it, or is there a better way? Thank you!#2023-05-1915:20p-himikTry using [:default] instead of :DEFAULT.#2023-05-1915:20Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)Doesn‚Äôt that produce default() which is a function call?#2023-05-1915:21p-himikYou're a single REPL execution away from checking. ;)#2023-05-1915:21p-himik
(sql/format {:update :t 
             :set    {:col [:default]}})
=> ["UPDATE t SET col = DEFAULT"]
#2023-05-1915:21p-himik[...] is context-dependent.#2023-05-1915:22Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)You are right. Sometimes I feel HoneySQL is too magic and beyond my understanding‚Ä¶ üòÖ#2023-05-1915:22Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)thanks a lot!#2023-05-1915:24p-himikAddendum to my "context-dependent" message - [...] is also content-dependent.
E.g. :default in a vector expands to DEFAULT but :x expands to x(). So in this case it's just that HoneySQL treats :default in a special way.#2023-05-1916:15seancorfieldI don't want to be that guy but... https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.1026/doc/getting-started/sql-special-syntax-#constraint-default-references has examples üôÇ#2023-05-1916:15seancorfieldBut, yes, the docs for :update could certainly be beefed up...#2023-05-1916:17Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)Ah, I have been on the page but haven't thought of searching it for default üòÖ#2023-05-1916:17seancorfieldFeel free to add notes to https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/489#2023-05-2116:49DrLj√≥tssonAnyone aware of efforts to turn string SQL queries into honey sql? Via an AST maybe? This was my first hit when I googled for a sql parser https://github.com/JSQLParser/JSqlParser#2023-05-2117:01refsetThe XTDB 2.x SQL parser & AST rewrite namespace might be a reasonable starting point for such a thing https://github.com/xtdb/xtdb/blob/2.x/core/src/main/clojure/xtdb/sql/plan.clj#2023-05-2117:03refsetMaybe something more simplistic could be built specifically for HoneySQL without needing the full semantic analysis machinery, but I wouldn't bet on it :thinking_face:#2023-05-2117:04seancorfieldIt's been asked repeatedly over the years but SQL parsing is a massive effort -- as the XTDB folks know -- and completely out of scope for HoneySQL.#2023-05-2117:05seancorfieldSee https://github.com/seancorfield/honeysql/issues/182 for at least one thread on it -- and why an ANSI SQL parser alone is not sufficient.#2023-05-2117:26DrLj√≥tssonYeah, I see the issues with being dialect neutral. For me it would be a one-off thing to convert lots of pretty standard MySQL queries into HoneySQL. So I was interested in hearing if anyone has done something similar for migration rather than a general solution. #2023-05-2123:20seancorfieldI'm not sure if anyone here is trying to use ClojureCLR but I just pushed some changes to HoneySQL to get at least basic compatibility in place... testing and feedback welcome!#2023-05-2211:29valeraukoI'm running into some trouble with using postgres enums. I have an user-defined type for an enum called user_status. I'd want to use it from a query like this

{:select [:*]
 :from [:users]
 :where [:= :status [:user-status input-value]]}

where input-value is provided as a parameter. The problem is that quoted-snake doesn't seem to work (well) with this and generates WHERE (status = USER STATUS("...")) . It works fine if I use :user_status in the dsl. My options are :check :strict :quoted-snake true.

Is there any way to achieve what I'm trying to do?#2023-05-2211:32p-himikWhy not simply use :user_status?#2023-05-2211:37p-himikThis behavior is documented here: https://cljdoc.org/d/com.github.seancorfield/honeysql/2.4.1026/doc/readme?q=function#functions

And, as it says, you should also be able to use :'user-status.#2023-05-2212:16valeraukobecause i hoped to be able to use kebab-case everywhere. but i guess the ambiguity isn't worth it and i'll just make it a human-lint-rule to use snake_case for db-side stuff.#2023-05-2212:19p-himikHoneySQL distinguishes between - and _ - it's part of the DSL.
I usually use kebab-case for schemas/tables/columns and snake-case for functions.#2023-05-2315:57Jakub Hol√Ω (HolyJak)In my experience, transforming between kebab and other case is a nightmare. We use camelCase for columns, and I use them as-is in the code and the API. Otherwise I never knew whether at a particular point in code I was dealing with one or the other.#2023-05-2212:18valeraukoIs the discrepancy between how honey.sql formats quoted-snake and how the next.jdbc built-in as-kebab-maps formats the results known?

honey.sql (imo correctly) just replaces - with  while camel-snake-kebab that next.jdbc uses inserts a - between different character classes too. I ran into this problem because I had an emailmd5 column that I could query as :email-md5 but the result would come out as :email-md-5#2023-05-2216:52seancorfieldCSK is an external library that I don't control but people were commonly using it for round-tripping kebab -> snake -> kebab with next.jdbc so I decided to just depend on it and offer shortcuts to use it.

I don't like using that conversion, personally, and prefer to just use snake case around the database -- you can always write your own builder if the CSK-based builder does not suit your needs.#2023-05-2300:50valeraukoyeah, i wrote a simple replace for this to work around the problem. it just felt weird that the "built-in" conversion worked on the querying side but not on the result side#2023-05-2317:58Ben LiebermanI'm getting this exception from the SQL Server JDBC driver
